All Rights Reserved


157 of 413 DOCUMENTS




MailOnline


April 18, 2018 Wednesday 4:17 PM GMT 


GDPR: All you need to know


BYLINE: MADHVI MAVADIYA


SECTION: NEWS; Version:1


LENGTH: 961 words



  • •

    The GDPR compliance deadline for the European Union is fast approaching 

  • •

    GDPR will ensure that tech firms like Google and Facebook follow stricter rules 

  • •

    The directive came into force in May 2016 after the EU agreed to the final text 

The GDPR compliance deadline for European Union member states is fast approaching, with many tech companies updating their data protection for the 21st century in order to effectively replace the Data Protection Act 1998.

The General Data Protection Regulation has been formulated to ensure that organisations like  Google and Facebook  follow stricter rules and regulations amid concerns over how private data is collected and shared. 

This concern was exacerbated after the 2016 US Election which led to Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg having to sit down before Congress to discuss the Cambridge Analytica scandal.

With over 87 million users estimated to have had their data mined through the 'This Is Your Digital Life' quiz, it has also emerged that private Facebook Messenger conversations may have also fallen into the hands of Cambridge Analytica. But what is GDPR?

What is GDPR?

The General Data Protection Regulation has been created over the course of four years in order to strengthen data protection in an era in which people are continuously giving social media websites permissions to use their personal information in exchange for 'free' services.

GDPR will be replacing the Data Protection Act 1998, which itself was brought into law so that the 1995 EU Data Protection Directive could be implemented and give people more control over how organisations use data.

The regulation also introduced penalties for those who do not comply with the new rules and in turn, suffer from data breaches. It also standardised all data laws across the European Union.

A significant change in the new regulation is that if companies fail to provide adequate security to protect data, they could be fined heavily under GDPR.

Why do we need GDPR?  

The advent of the Internet and the emergence of the cloud led to organisations being able to use personal user data for their own purposes, which caused problems when individuals wanted to know how their information was being used.  

GDPR was planned because of the EU's need to align data protection law with the 21st century, a time where people use free services like  Amazon, Google, Twitter and Facebook and offer their information openly.

Alongside this, the EU wanted to align data protection law across all member states so that companies are clear about what they need to comply with.

When will the GDPR be implemented?

The GDPR will apply from May 25, 2018 in all EU member states automatically, without the need for each country having to draw up their own legislation.

While businesses have until May 25 to ensure they have applied the new rules, the directive came into force on May 24, 2016 after the EU agreed to the final text.

Who does the GDPR apply to?

GDPR will apply to those who decide how and why personal data is processed, the controllers, as well as those who actively process the data, otherwise known as the processors. This means that GDPR could apply to anyone working in a company, charity, government or IT firm.

It will also apply to controllers and processors that are based outside the EU, but deal with data that belongs to EU residents. Controllers are responsible for ensuring that processors abide by the new law and process data lawfully, who themselves are required to maintain records of their activities.

After the GDPR is put in place, data must be processed with consent and transparently, for a purpose and once it is no longer needed, data should be deleted. Alongside this, consent must be granted in an active fashion by the user, not passively with pre-ticked boxes.

What is personal data?

Under the GDPR, the European Union has expanded the definition of 'personal data' to include other online identifiers such as IP addresses, mental health, cultural and economic information about an individual.

Individuals already have the right to access information that a company has obtained and to know how and why their data is being processed, as well as who will see it. Data can also be rectified, changed or deleted at any time by the person it belongs to.

How much are GDPR fines?

When a data breach occurs, the people who are at risk of being affected must be told within 72 hours of the company being aware of it. Those who do not meet this deadline could face a penalty of two per cent of their annual worldwide revenue, or (EURO)10 million (£8.7m), whichever is higher.

Then, the data protection authority should be contacted and in the UK, this means the Information Commissioner's Office, or the ICO. The authority should be given information about the nature of data breach, how many people have been affected, what the consequences could be and what measures have been actioned.

If people's rights are ignored, the fine could reach up to (EURO)20 million (£17m) or four per cent of your global annual turnover, whichever is higher.

Does Brexit affect GDPR?

With Article 50 being triggered in March 2017, the UK has two years in which to leave the European Union, but this means that the GDPR will be implemented before this time. 

In August 2017, the UK government put forward a new Data Protection Bill, which replicates the requirements of GDPR ahead of Brexit. The new bill allows the ICO to issue fines of up to £17 million, or four per cent of global turnover, whichever is highest.


LOAD-DATE: April 18, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDM



Copyright 2018 Associated Newspapers Ltd.
All Rights Reserved


158 of 413 DOCUMENTS




MailOnline


April 18, 2018 Wednesday 6:48 AM GMT 


Facebook plans to bring back facial recognition in Europe and Canada despite promising regulators it would drop the technology over privacy concerns


BYLINE: TIM COLLINS FOR MAILONLINE and AFP


SECTION: SCIENCE; Version:5


LENGTH: 1214 words



  • •

    Facebook will begin rolling out changes this week on how it handles private data 

  • •

    Users will be asked to review and make choices about ads they receive  

  • •

    They will also be asked to choose what to share about their personal data 

  • •

    This will include political, religious and relationship information on their profiles 

  • •

    Users will be allowed to opt in or out of use of its facial recognition technology  

  • •

    Move is likely to ruffle feathers in the wake of the Cambridge Analytica debacle  

A controversial Facebook AI tool could soon be making a return to Europe and Canada.

Facial recognition, launched in 2010, suggests names for people it identifies in photos uploaded by users.   

It was suspended for users in Europe in 2012 over privacy concerns, but still lives on in the US and other regions worldwide.

Now the firm says it will make a comeback, using the new European data protection regulations as a chance to collect more information if users opt in.  

The move to reintroduce the image scanning software is likely to ruffle feathers, coming in the wake of the Cambridge Analytica data handling debacle.

Private information taken from 87 million users was supplied to the consultancy firm, which was working for Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign.

Scroll down for video 

Facebook claims its facial recognition technology helps people manage their identity online.

It can also help the visually impaired know who is shown in a photo. 

But it also provide Facebook with a huge amount of data on an individual, such as who they are friends with and where their location.  

Facebook will begin to ask users if they want to opt in or out of the facial recognition feature under the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) this week, ahead of it coming into force on May 25.

Under the new policy, Facebook users will also be asked to review and make choices about ads they receive, including whether they want Facebook to use data from third parties.

They will also be asked to review and choose what to share about the political, religious, and relationship information on their profiles.

These are designed to ensure the Menlo Park, California, firm complies with the forthcoming EU rules, with European residents seeing the measures first. 

'Everyone - no matter where they live - will be asked to review important information about how Facebook uses data and make choices about their privacy on Facebook,' chief privacy officer Erin Egan and deputy general counsel Ashlie Beringer said in a written statement.

The statement also said users will be told that facial recognition is optional, but that it could offer some benefit, such as being notified when someone is using an unauthorised picture.

'We not only want to comply with the law, but also go beyond our obligations to build new and improved privacy experiences for everyone on Facebook,' Ms Egan and Ms Beringer wrote.

GPDR aims to strengthen and unify data protection for all individuals within the European Union.

This means cracking down on how companies use and sell the data they collect on their users.

The law will mark the biggest overhaul of personal data privacy rules since the birth of the internet.

Under GDPR, companies will be required to report data breaches within 72 hours, as well as to allow customers to export their data and delete it.

The laws will be welcome news to anyone affected by the Cambridge Analytica scandal.

Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg faced ten hours of questioning in two congressional panels last week, following revelations that personal data was harvested by the British consultancy.

Zuckerberg testified that Facebook intends to offer the same privacy protections embodied in GDPR for its worldwide users, but that there could be some differences in format.

Ms Egan and Ms Beringer said Facebook users in the EU will start seeing the requests this week so they can make choices before May 25.

'As part of our phased approach, people in the rest of the world will be asked to make their choices on a slightly later schedule,' they said.

They added that Facebook would take steps to comply with the EU rules that limit advertising and public viewing of data for teens. 

This will mean no use of facial recognition for anyone under age 18 and limitations on who can see certain information teens have shared.  

To comply with GDPR, Facebook will also limit what it shows to users between the ages of 13 and 15 unless they get permission from a parent.

On Monday it emerged a US federal judge has ruled Facebook will face a class action law suit in the wake of its privacy scandal. 

Allegations of privacy violations emerged when it was revealed the app used a photo-scanning tool on users' images without their explicit consent. 

Under Illinois state law, the company could be fined $1,000 to $5,000 (£700 to £3,500) each time a person's image was used without consent. 

It is believed that the function runs afoul of Illinois state law on protecting biometric privacy. 

Judge James Donato ruled the claims by Illinois residents Nimesh Patel, Adam Pezen, and Carlo Licata were 'sufficiently cohesive to allow for a fair and efficient resolution on a class basis.

'Consequently, the case will proceed with a class consisting of Facebook users located in Illinois for whom Facebook created and stored a face template after June 7, 2011,' he said, according to the ruling. 

Facebook rolled out its 'tag suggestions' feature in June 2011.

The feature is not currently available to users in most countries, including the UK - and can be turned off in settings for US users. 

Facebook believe that the lawsuit should be pursued by individual as the total amount of damages could 'amount to billions of dollars,' U.S. District Judge James Donato wrote in the ruling.

The judge has ruled that the Illinois law is clear: Facebook has collected a 'wealth of data on its users, including self-reported residency and IP addresses,' reports Bloomberg.   

Facebook has acknowledged that it can identify which users who live in Illinois have face templates, he wrote.

A face template can be generated from ten or more photos and is used to generate a profile on Facebook's database.

'Although many individuals may not have had enough tagged photos to generate a face template in Facebook's database, in January 2011 [when Facebook implemented tag suggestions for all users] the average user was tagged in 53 photos, far more than the 10 needed to generate a face template,' according to a December court filing.

A Facebook spokeswoman said the company was reviewing the decision, adding: 'We continue to believe the case has no merit and will defend ourselves vigorously.'

Facebook also contends it has been very open about the tool since its inception.

As well as allowing users to turn the feature off, the Zuckerberg-owned app lets users prevent themselves from being suggested in photo tags. 

It also emerged this week that secret surveillance software created by a former Israeli intelligence officer is harvesting Facebook photos.

The firm behind it, Face-Int i, is taking profile images from the social network, YouTube and other sites to build a huge facial recognition database.

Its creators say the software could lead to the identification of terror suspects, captured in promotional and other material posted online.


LOAD-DATE: April 18, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDM

159 of 413 DOCUMENTS




mirror.co.uk


April 18, 2018 Wednesday 1:33 PM GMT 


Facebook announces privacy changes for GDPR - and brings facial recognition to the UK;
The General Data Protection Regulation will become law for any data processing affecting EU citizens in May


BYLINE: By Jeff Parsons


SECTION: TECHNOLOGY; Version:2


LENGTH: 1062 words


Facebook is struggling to reassert a positive public image in the wake of theCambridge Analyticascandal.

Co-founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg has appeared in front of US lawmakers and pledged to do more to support privacy concerns.

However, it is the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), thatFacebookhas to worry about in the short term as it comes into force on May 25 and will impose strict fines for breaches of privacy.

The social network has today revealed the steps it is taking to comply with GDPR and some privacy experts are sceptical. 

How has technology changed? The biggest advancements in tech and how they've changed our lives

Ablog postfrom Erin Egan , Facebook's VP and Chief Privacy Officer for Policy and Ashlie Beringer VP and Deputy General Counsel explained what the company is doing.

"Everyone - no matter where they live - will be asked to review important information about how Facebook uses data and make choices about their privacy on Facebook. We'll begin by rolling these choices out in Europe this week," they said.

Web searches to delete Facebook DOUBLED in the UK following Cambridge Analytica data breach

Among the changes are new options for people to review how Facebook uses their information with particular emphasis on special categories of data - such as political, religious or health-based information that draws the requirement of explicit consent under GDPR.

"If you've chosen to share political, religious, and relationship information on your profile, we'll ask you to choose whether to continue sharing and letting us use this information," the blog post says.

"As always, including this information on your profile is completely optional. We're making it easier for people to delete it if they no longer want to share it."

Facebook doesn't sell adverts based on this information, but it also doesn't make it easy to opt out of having this data processed. Users will have to manually go into their settings to make sure collection of this information is disabled.

Hackers have become so 'lazy' they're just using automated attacking tools, study finds

The General Data Protection Regulation includes biometric data as a form of personal data for the first time in privacy law and Facebook tackles this with its new policy on facial recognition tech. So far, the face-scanning part of the network hasn't been available in the EU - but that's going to change if users want to have it.

"We've offered products using face recognition in most of the world for more than six years. As part of this update, we're now giving people in the EU and Canada the choice to turn on face recognition," the blog post says.

Again though, if you want to switch it off, you'll need to navigate through the settings to switch it off - rather than just hitting the big, blue "Accept and Continue" button.

"It's a useful feature that can make sure people know about the photos of them floating around,"wrote TechCrunch's Josh Constine.

"But here the lack of granularity is concerning. Users might want to see warnings about possible impersonators using their face in their profile pics, but not be suggested as someone to tag in their friends' photos. Unfortunately, it's all or nothing."

FB GDPR 1

Facebook is getting sued over its facial recognition system that suggests people to 'tag' in photos

Under GDPR, companies wanting to process the personal data of anyone below the age of 16 must have consent for a parent or guardian. Crucially, member states have the option to lower this if they choose. The UK has already indicated it will drop the age of consent to 13.

Facebook says it has made a number of changes that will affect younger users.

"For example, advertising categories for teens are more limited, and their default audience options for posts do not include "public."

"We also keep face recognition off for anyone under age 18 and limit who can see or search specific information teens have shared, like hometown or birthday.

"Under GDPR, people between the ages of 13 and 15 in some EU countries need permission from a parent or guardian to allow some features on Facebook - seeing ads based on data from partners and including religious and political views or "interested in" on your profile.

"These teens will see a less personalized version of Facebook with restricted sharing and less relevant ads until they get permission from a parent or guardian to use all aspects of Facebook."

However, Facebook seems to make it very easy for anyone to be a selected parent or guardian - all the teen has to do is enter an email address or select another friend designated as their guardian. That person (or alternate email address) can then give consent.

Why you won't #DeleteFacebook even though everyone says you should

Mark Zuckerberg seemed to be pro-GDPR at his recent testimonials in front of Congress, but the social network has a vested interest in collecting as much personal data as possible.

With fines amounting to as much as 4% of global annual turnover for noncompliance, GDPR is one rule that Facebook has to pay attention to. And the principles laid out in the regulation are likely to become the new base level of privacy by design given it applies to any product or service that targets an EU national.

FB for GDPR 2

GDPR does say that lawful processing criteria for personal data includes that which is manifestly made public by the data subject.

Facebook is also within its rights to say processing is necessary for the performance of a contract to which the data subject is party.

So while the social network is bringing its compliance up to the minimum acceptable standard, privacy experts continue to be doubtful about how much it will really change.

Mark Weinstein, one of the world's foremost privacy advocates, told Mirror Tech: "Even with GDPR, Facebook won't give up its way of doing business. Skin deep fixes yes, for compliance sake, but not an inch more.

"Facebook will make minimal changes not fundamental ones, no way. Even with full transparency, the company will never be fully transparent.

"And if the truth doesn't gibe with the company's bottom line, they'll find a way to bury it underneath the announcement of an amazing new feature.


LOAD-DATE: April 19, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDMI

All Rights Reserved


160 of 413 DOCUMENTS




telegraph.co.uk


April 18, 2018 Wednesday 10:21 AM GMT 


Facebook to stop teenagers sharing sexual preferences without parent's permission


BYLINE: By Margi Murphy


SECTION: TECHNOLOGY INTELLIGENCE; Version:1


LENGTH: 432 words


Facebook will stop teenagers from sharing religious and sexual preferences without parental permission, in a bid to toe the line with incoming data protection law.

Those who have created a profile and stated that they are aged between 13 and 15 will be prompted to remove these categories from their profile, or get a parent or guardian to consent to them sharing.   

Facebook is making the sweeping changes to stay compliant with European data protection law, the General Data Protection Regulation, which comes into force on May 25.

Under GDPR, people under 15 will need permission from a parent or guardian to allow some features on Facebook like seeing ads based on data from partners and including religious and political views or "interested in" on their profile.

Teenagers can nominate someone to approve sharing these preferences by selecting someone from their friends list or by entering an email address. Facebook will not independently verify the nominee is their parent or guardian.

Accounts for this age group will have the default "public" post settings switched off and face recognition on photos will be turned off those those under 18.

Facebook said it will ask every teenager if they want to see adverts based on information from third parties and remind them when they are including personal information in their profiles, a privacy control, even though the law does not require this.

The changes follow revelations that Facebook had allowed a researcher to mine personal information of 87 million unsuspecting users, which was later sold to Cambridge Analytica, a company employed by Donald Trump and Ted Cruz during the run-up to the 2016 presidential election. Cambridge Analytica employee Brittany Kaiser said that she was certain that this was one of many colossal databases harvested from Facebook and later used by private companies to influence and snoop on people's online behaviours.

Interactive: what does facebook know about you?

Facebook's chief privacy officer Erin Egan said: "As soon as GDPR was finalised, we realized it was an opportunity to invest even more heavily in privacy.

"We not only want to comply with the law, but also go beyond our obligations to build new and improved privacy experiences for everyone on Facebook."

People of all ages will start to see changes on the social network, including pop-ups on their news feed alerting them of how facial recognition will work and improved Settings and Privacy shortcuts, where people can find details on how their information is being used to attract advertisers.

Technology intelligence - newsletter promo - EOA


LOAD-DATE: April 18, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDTNS



Copyright 2018 Telegraph Media Group Limited

161 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Times (London)


April 18, 2018 Wednesday  
Edition 1;
National Edition


No easy way to stop Facebook's new photo grab


BYLINE: Mark Bridge


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 20


LENGTH: 618 words


Facebook is asking Britons to consent to the use of controversial facial-recognition technology while making it difficult to opt out, experts say.

The social network uses the technology in the US to tag people in photos, but not in Europe because of concerns that it breaches EU privacy laws. However, the company said recently that it would introduce it under an opt-in system.

The move comes as Facebook is placed under pressure from MPs and regulators after the Cambridge Analytica scandal over its failure to safeguard privacy. The UK consultancy, which is accused of electoral interference, obtained the data of tens of millions of Facebook users without their consent. 

In Britain Facebook users have started to see messages asking them to agree to facial recognition. Jennifer Cobbe, a researcher in technology law at Cambridge University, said that it was difficult to opt out.

The message says that facial recognition is beneficial because it can alert users if someone impersonates them, and can tell people with visual impairments who is in a photo. There is no obvious "No" button; users who wish to opt-out need to go to a settings page.

Ms Cobbe told Business Insider: "By framing the request for consent to facial recognition as being about the user experience, about the user's security and about making Facebook more accessible for visually impaired people, rather than what it's actually about - which is Facebook's all-encompassing surveillance machine in which privacy is not an option - they're going about getting consent in a fundamentally dishonest and manipulative way."

She believes that the technology would be illegal in Britain and the EU next month when the general data protection regulation (GDPR), comes into force, arguing that Facebook would have to scan the faces of people who opt out of facial recognition to check that they did not get treated as those who had given consent.

She said: "So how does Facebook know that a face in a photo belongs to someone who hasn't consented to facial recognition? By using facial recognition. In practice Facebook won't just be using facial recognition for users who have consented - it is likely to be doing it for users who have explicitly said no as well as for people who appear in photos but don't even have Facebook accounts. You can't escape this by saying no. You can't even escape this by not having Facebook. Facebook will still scan your face."

Jim Killock from the Open Rights Group, the privacy group, said: "We agree that this agreement for facial recognition is unclear and will result in people agreeing to something they do not want. As such it is unlikely to be GDPR-compliant."

This week Facebook was served with a class action lawsuit in the US from users who claim that facial recognition breaches state laws on privacy. In Illinois the district judge James Donato ruled that the social network must face the suit over allegations that it gathered biometric information without the explicit consent of users.

Facebook's lawyers say that the case has no merit and they will defend the company vigorously.

A Facebook spokeswoman said yesterday that the company was working to make sure that its services complied with GDPR: "We recently began to preview some of the changes. These included the opportunity to opt in to facerecognition features. We also provided information about improved privacy controls and details of how our services work." ? Facebook enabled developers to access the data of friends of app users without their knowledge until two weeks ago, despite claiming to have closed the loophole in 2014. This enabled Cambridge Analytica to gather data on "far more" than 87 million people, a whistleblower has claimed.


LOAD-DATE: April 18, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: TIM



Copyright 2018 Times Newspapers Limited
All Rights Reserved


162 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Times (London)


April 18, 2018 Wednesday  
Edition 1;
Scotland


No easy way to stop Facebook's new photo grab


BYLINE: Mark Bridge


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 22


LENGTH: 618 words


Facebook is asking Britons to consent to the use of controversial facial-recognition technology while making it difficult to opt out, experts say.

The social network uses the technology in the US to tag people in photos, but not in Europe because of concerns that it breaches EU privacy laws. However, the company said recently that it would introduce it under an opt-in system.

The move comes as Facebook is placed under pressure from MPs and regulators after the Cambridge Analytica scandal over its failure to safeguard privacy. The UK consultancy, which is accused of electoral interference, obtained the data of tens of millions of Facebook users without their consent. 

In Britain Facebook users have started to see messages asking them to agree to facial recognition. Jennifer Cobbe, a researcher in technology law at Cambridge University, said that it was difficult to opt out.

The message says that facial recognition is beneficial because it can alert users if someone impersonates them, and can tell people with visual impairments who is in a photo. There is no obvious "No" button; users who wish to opt-out need to go to a settings page.

Ms Cobbe told Business Insider: "By framing the request for consent to facial recognition as being about the user experience, about the user's security and about making Facebook more accessible for visually impaired people, rather than what it's actually about - which is Facebook's all-encompassing surveillance machine in which privacy is not an option - they're going about getting consent in a fundamentally dishonest and manipulative way."

She believes that the technology would be illegal in Britain and the EU next month when the general data protection regulation (GDPR), comes into force, arguing that Facebook would have to scan the faces of people who opt out of facial recognition to check that they did not get treated as those who had given consent.

She said: "So how does Facebook know that a face in a photo belongs to someone who hasn't consented to facial recognition? By using facial recognition. In practice Facebook won't just be using facial recognition for users who have consented - it is likely to be doing it for users who have explicitly said no as well as for people who appear in photos but don't even have Facebook accounts. You can't escape this by saying no. You can't even escape this by not having Facebook. Facebook will still scan your face."

Jim Killock from the Open Rights Group, the privacy group, said: "We agree that this agreement for facial recognition is unclear and will result in people agreeing to something they do not want. As such it is unlikely to be GDPR-compliant."

This week Facebook was served with a class action lawsuit in the US from users who claim that facial recognition breaches state laws on privacy. In Illinois the district judge James Donato ruled that the social network must face the suit over allegations that it gathered biometric information without the explicit consent of users.

Facebook's lawyers say that the case has no merit and they will defend the company vigorously.

A Facebook spokeswoman said yesterday that the company was working to make sure that its services complied with GDPR: "We recently began to preview some of the changes. These included the opportunity to opt in to facerecognition features. We also provided information about improved privacy controls and details of how our services work." ? Facebook enabled developers to access the data of friends of app users without their knowledge until two weeks ago, despite claiming to have closed the loophole in 2014. This enabled Cambridge Analytica to gather data on "far more" than 87 million people, a whistleblower has claimed.

163 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Times (London)


April 18, 2018 Wednesday  
Edition 1;
Northern Ireland


No easy way to stop Facebook's new photo grab


BYLINE: Mark Bridge


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 20


LENGTH: 618 words


Facebook is asking Britons to consent to the use of controversial facial-recognition technology while making it difficult to opt out, experts say.

The social network uses the technology in the US to tag people in photos, but not in Europe because of concerns that it breaches EU privacy laws. However, the company said recently that it would introduce it under an opt-in system.

The move comes as Facebook is placed under pressure from MPs and regulators after the Cambridge Analytica scandal over its failure to safeguard privacy. The UK consultancy, which is accused of electoral interference, obtained the data of tens of millions of Facebook users without their consent. 

In Britain Facebook users have started to see messages asking them to agree to facial recognition. Jennifer Cobbe, a researcher in technology law at Cambridge University, said that it was difficult to opt out.

The message says that facial recognition is beneficial because it can alert users if someone impersonates them, and can tell people with visual impairments who is in a photo. There is no obvious "No" button; users who wish to opt-out need to go to a settings page.

Ms Cobbe told Business Insider: "By framing the request for consent to facial recognition as being about the user experience, about the user's security and about making Facebook more accessible for visually impaired people, rather than what it's actually about - which is Facebook's all-encompassing surveillance machine in which privacy is not an option - they're going about getting consent in a fundamentally dishonest and manipulative way."

She believes that the technology would be illegal in Britain and the EU next month when the general data protection regulation (GDPR), comes into force, arguing that Facebook would have to scan the faces of people who opt out of facial recognition to check that they did not get treated as those who had given consent.

She said: "So how does Facebook know that a face in a photo belongs to someone who hasn't consented to facial recognition? By using facial recognition. In practice Facebook won't just be using facial recognition for users who have consented - it is likely to be doing it for users who have explicitly said no as well as for people who appear in photos but don't even have Facebook accounts. You can't escape this by saying no. You can't even escape this by not having Facebook. Facebook will still scan your face."

Jim Killock from the Open Rights Group, the privacy group, said: "We agree that this agreement for facial recognition is unclear and will result in people agreeing to something they do not want. As such it is unlikely to be GDPR-compliant."

This week Facebook was served with a class action lawsuit in the US from users who claim that facial recognition breaches state laws on privacy. In Illinois the district judge James Donato ruled that the social network must face the suit over allegations that it gathered biometric information without the explicit consent of users.

Facebook's lawyers say that the case has no merit and they will defend the company vigorously.

A Facebook spokeswoman said yesterday that the company was working to make sure that its services complied with GDPR: "We recently began to preview some of the changes. These included the opportunity to opt in to facerecognition features. We also provided information about improved privacy controls and details of how our services work." ? Facebook enabled developers to access the data of friends of app users without their knowledge until two weeks ago, despite claiming to have closed the loophole in 2014. This enabled Cambridge Analytica to gather data on "far more" than 87 million people, a whistleblower has claimed.


LOAD-DATE: April 18, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: TIM

164 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Daily Telegraph (London)


April 14, 2018 Saturday  
Edition 1;
National Edition


Weight of compliance;
Letters to the Editor


SECTION: LETTERS; Pg. 21


LENGTH: 220 words


sir - It appears that all businesses, large or small, are to be bound by extremely onerous new rules under General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which come into force on May 25. I attended a seminar on them, and here is a taster of what I will have to do. 

I have to contact everyone on my e-newsletter subscription list and ask them to re-subscribe all over again and confirm their email address in writing by either email or surface mail.

I then have to confirm they have agreed to receive this at the address posted. Once they confirm this, I can tell them that their subscription has been accepted and that they can unsubscribe at any time.

I have to ask everyone currently receiving invitations to antiques fairs if they wish to continue this by both email and surface mail.

I must ask everyone on my clients' inquiries lists if they still wish to be notified when I have an item in stock.

I have to ask everyone on my database if they are content to remain there and confirm what data I am holding for them.

Paper proof must exist of all these interactions. And so it goes on. I cannot afford to take on extra staff just to ensure that I am fully compliant with GDPR. Failure to comply carries fines of up to (EURO)20million (£17 million). David Harvey Managing Director W R Harvey & Co (Antiques) Ltd Witney, Oxfordshire


LOAD-DATE: April 14, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: DTL



Copyright 2018 Telegraph Media Group Limited
All Rights Reserved


165 of 413 DOCUMENTS




telegraph.co.uk


April 13, 2018 Friday 11:01 PM GMT 


Letters: United action against chemical attacks is undermined by Germany


SECTION: OPINION; Version:1


LENGTH: 1810 words


SIR - No wonder Germany declares it will take no military action over the chemical attack in Syria. The Gazprom scandal ( report, April 13 ) lays bare the hypocrisy of the EU and Germany.

On the one hand Britain is told we can't have a bespoke trade deal, as the same rules apply to all 27 nations. On the other, Germany "negotiates" a deal with Russia's state-backed Gazprom to receive gas more cheaply than other EU nations. This goes against EU regulations, but, since it is Germany, a blind eye is turned, while poorer neighbours suffer far higher rates.

To add insult to injury, Germany then pushes Gazprom's agenda with Brussels to undermine EU regulations further, yet no action is taken.

Moral cowardice and an agenda that serves Germany's economy above all others in the EU are clear for all to see. 

Having served in the military, I lived in Germany for 12 years and loved the people and the country. They have clearly lost their way.

Mike McKone Kirkby Stephen, Cumbria

SIR - Watching the news and seeing the apparent willingness of France and Britain to side with President Donald Trump of the United States over the alleged chemical attack in Syria (foolish though that may seem), I wondered why Germany for all its size was not supporting the initiative.

Now I've read in The Daily Telegraph about the cosy arrangement that Germany has with Russia for its gas supplies, it has become clear.

Germany spends less than Britain on overseas aid, and is not, it seems, paying its correct contribution to Nato. It clearly intends to prosper to the detriment of its EU partners.

George Gooden Woodbridge, Suffolk

SIR - It is all very well for various politicians and commentators to encourage Theresa May to take action against the Syrian regime without recourse to Parliament, but they could establish a precedent that, heaven forfend, could enable a future prime minister, Jeremy Corbyn, to do likewise. And goodness knows whom he would have in his sights.

Michael Burke Manchester

SIR - At this dangerous moment for Britain and the world, we should recall that a month ago the Government was considering scrapping key naval ships and a Royal Marine commando.

Malcolm Allen Berkhamsted, Hertfordshire

What happens next in Syria - could Britain be drawn into World War Three?

SIR  - I expect an American President to be statesmanlike, dignified, measured and a model of integrity in times of international crisis.

Instead we are treated to outbursts of a kind that one would expect from a precocious but immature sixth-former.

Richard Cousens Monkton Deverill, Wiltshire

SIR - If the Russians did interfere to help Mr Trump win the US presidency, are they now regretting their actions?

Anthony Whitehead Bristol

Burglars not pursued

SIR - Your front-page report "Police abandon two in three burglary victims as crime soars" ( April 7 ) was no surprise to me.

I provided the police with clear CCTV footage of two women coming into my driveway and going behind the garage to the back gate. The footage of them leaving clearly showed their car and registration number. All the police had to do was check the registration number with the DVLA, approach the owner of the vehicle and ask for an explanation.

All they said was: "The registration alone, on this occasion, does not allow us to identify these females."

Is it any wonder that very few people can find a good word to say about the police?

Elayne M Benjamin London NW4

Weight of compliance

SIR - It appears that all businesses, large or small, are to be bound by extremely onerous new rules under General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which come into force on May 25. I attended a seminar on them, and here is a taster of what I will have to do.

I have to contact everyone on my e-newsletter subscription list and ask them to re-subscribe all over again and confirm their email address in writing by either email or surface mail.

I then have to confirm they have agreed to receive this at the address posted. Once they confirm this, I can tell them that their subscription has been accepted and that they can unsubscribe at any time.

I have to ask everyone currently receiving invitations to antiques fairs if they wish to continue this by both email and surface mail.

I must ask everyone on my clients' inquiries lists if they still wish to be notified when I have an item in stock.

I have to ask everyone on my database if they are content to remain there and confirm what data I am holding for them.

Paper proof must exist of all these interactions. And so it goes on. I cannot afford to take on extra staff just to ensure that I am fully compliant with GDPR. Failure to comply carries fines of up to (EURO)20 million (£17 million).

David Harvey Managing Director W R Harvey & Co (Antiques) Ltd Witney, Oxfordshire

At a glance | Your data rights Sore throat test

SIR - Dr Tony McAllister ( Letters, April 11 ) asks why quick tests for diagnosing sore throats are not available at GPs.

We have recently returned from Austria where two of our daughters had sore throats tested in the local doctor's surgery. The doctor took a pin prick of blood, which was then analysed to detect whether they were suffering from a viral or bacterial infection. It took less than two minutes and on receipt of the results appropriate medication was administered.

What concerned us was how amazed we were that such "modern" medicine existed. Clearly our NHS is something out of the third world.

Rachel Butterworth Andover, Hampshire

SIR - The Longitude Committee decided to award a substantial amount of money to the person or team who devised a simple, fast and cheap test to distinguish between viral and bacterial infection.

Has the prize been awarded?

Dr P E Pears Coleshill, Warwickshire

The risks from planes roaring over London

SIR - Surely it is time to act when the Queen says that the aircraft noise over London is excessive ( report, April 10 ).

In 1955, while visiting London to watch the Boat Race, I could see that it was unsafe to have routine flights over Fulham football ground - which can contain 25,000 people.

The only thing that has changed is that there are more flights.

Geoffrey Cullington Dorchester

UK's busiest airports

SIR - The Queen makes a very good point, having, as she does, a house at each end of Heathrow's runway. Here in mid-Sussex, fast becoming one of the more densely populated areas of the country, the intrusion into normal life and conversation is continual.

Many moons ago, we were assured that there would be a ban on jets between 11 at night and six in the morning. We were also told that pilots, with the co-operation of air traffic control, would operate a continuous descent procedure, meaning less noise and less pollution. It would appear that both of these promises have been eroded to a farcical extent.

If the jet ban were in place, why would Gatwick's operations in the middle of the night be disrupted by  a lack of controllers, as was recently reported?

Why too is there a holding pattern in Sussex between Ditchling Beacon and Hickstead, now an area of housing development, when the procedure could be moved south and out to sea?

Peter Kilkelly Cuckfield, West Sussex

Bad therapy

SIR - I read the article on Anne Craig, a "personal development coach" accused of encouraging her clients to sever all contact with their families ( Magazine, April 7 ), with my heart in my mouth.

I have a daughter who used to be very close to me, but after having cognitive therapy she has refused to have any contact with me for many years. Therefore, I have no contact with my grandchildren either. I am disabled and not in good health, which I know someone has told her, but still nothing.

I have been advised that the damage is done, and there is probably nothing I could do now to heal the situation.

It is terrifying that vulnerable people seeking help through therapy should be turned against their families in this way. Clearly the law needs to be changed.

Jane Alexander Winchester, Hampshire

No tripe boiling

SIR - I acquired my property deeds from my solicitor (Letters, April 13) and they make fascinating reading.

I particularly like the instructions that there must not be any trade or business as a publican, beerhouse keeper, broken-soap boiler, sugar baker, distiller, dyer, glass maker, tripe boiler or tallow-candle maker.

Furthermore, there can be no tempering of saws, steel or cast iron and no steam or engine house. Finally, I cannot have a slaughter house but it must be a private dwelling house.

What a loss it would have been had this information disappeared because the deeds had been destroyed.

Susan Apedaile Bolger Sheffield, South Yorkshire

How to reset your sundial in time for summer

SIR - Because the Earth circles the Sun in a strange ellipse (the analemmatic curve), clock time and Sun time are only in harmony four times a year. Tomorrow, Sunday April 15, is one of these days, Christmas Day being one of the others.

Mid-afternoon tomorrow, if the Sun shines, is an ideal time to synchronise your garden sundial to the correct clock time. Simply rotate the sundial until it shows the correct time by your watch and your garden will be perfectly prepared for when summer arrives.

R A Collings Presteigne, Radnorshire

Spoiler alert

SIR - Part of the fun of watching BBC One's Antiques Roadshow is the occasional and unexpected eye-popping valuation.

It is a pity then that this weekend's edition, including the valuation of a spectacular Fabergé ornament, has already been given full coverage in the latest Radio Times.

Walter Walker Cowden, Kent

Pet peeve

SIR - Our dog so dislikes University Challenge she leaves the room as soon as she hears the introductory music.

To our surprise, she also walked out when she heard Jeremy Paxman introducing Have I Got News for You. We thought her aversion was only to the buzzer.

Elizabeth Stevens Stroud, Gloucestershire

Copyright 2018 Telegraph Media Group Limited
