171 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Guardian(London)


April 11, 2018 Wednesday 7:00 AM GMT 


Mark Zuckerberg's Facebook hearing was an utter sham;
Now that the initial show trial is done, we need the real dealFive things we learned from Mark Zuckerberg's Facebook hearingZuckerberg put on back foot as House grills Facebook CEO over user tracking


BYLINE: Zephyr Teachout


SECTION: OPINION; Version:9


LENGTH: 842 words


On Tuesday, Mark Zuckerberg was in the hot seat. Cameras surrounded him. The energy in the room - and on Twitter - was electric. At last, the reluctant CEO is made to answer some questions !

Except it failed. It was designed to fail. It was a show designed to get Zuckerberg off the hook after only a few hours in Washington DC. It was a show that gave the pretense of a hearing without a real hearing. It was designed to deflect and confuse.

Each senator was given less than five minutes for questions. That meant that there was no room for follow-ups, no chance for big discoveries and many frustratingly half-developed ideas. Compare that to Bill Gates' hearing on Microsoft, where he faced lawyers and staff for several days, or the Kefauver hearings, which were over a year. By design, you can't do a hearing of this magnitude in just a couple of hours.  

We shouldn't be begging for Facebook's endorsement of laws, or for Mark Zuckerberg's promises of self-regulation

The worst moments of the hearing for us, as citizens, were when senators asked if Zuckerberg would support legislation that would regulate Facebook. I don't care whether Zuckerberg supports Honest Ads or privacy laws or GDPR. By asking him if he would support legislation, the senators elevated him to a kind of co-equal philosopher king whose view on Facebook regulation carried special weight. It shouldn't.

Facebook is a known behemoth corporate monopoly. It has exposed at least 87 million people's data, enabled foreign propaganda and perpetuated discrimination. We shouldn't be begging for Facebook's endorsement of laws, or for Mark Zuckerberg's promises of self-regulation. We should treat him as a danger to democracy and demand our senators get a real hearing.

Related: Zuckerberg got off lightly. Why are politicians so bad at asking questions? | Jonathan Freedland

The best senators understood this was a show, and used it as such. "Your user agreement sucks," said John Kennedy. "Are you a monopoly?" asked Lindsey Graham. (Zuckerberg "comically" responded: "It certainly doesn't feel like that to me.") Richard Blumenthal said we needed laws, not promises or apologies.

Because each senator was limited to under five minutes, Zuckerberg tried to run the clock by talking about mission, philosophy or what he believed in. There were some good questions, but there was little chance for follow up. You could almost see him, well-trained to count the minutes, playing for time when things got a little hot.

Senators Mazie Hirono and Cory Booker, for instance, both pointed out the damning reporting by Julia Angwin at ProPublica, which showed that employers and landlords were using Facebook for discriminatory ads. Zuckerberg defended the company by saying they were hard to flag, and that they depend on community flagging to stop them.

The tools Facebook provides make discrimination easy. Facebook has monopoly profit margins, so it could easily provide real staffing to protect against discrimination, if it wanted to. It doesn't want to.

Hirono and Booker could have shown that, but, like the rest of the senators, they each had only a few minutes for a line of questioning. Zuckerberg replied with vague answers about how their comments were "important" or "interesting" or "an important conversation to have".

Some of the hearing seemed designed to figure out whether Zuckerberg is a good or bad man, or whether he has a good or bad - or bizarre - political philosophy. Zuckerberg strikes me as reliably self-serving. That doesn't make him that interesting as the CEO of a corporate monopoly; it makes him a run-of-the-mill robber baron.

Asking Zuckerberg philosophical questions, such as how he thinks we should deal with questions of hate speech, treats him as a thought leader. Accepting his failures to catch discriminatory housing ads, for instance, treats him as a good-hearted actor with limited resources, instead of someone who is making monopoly margins and billions in profits.

In my view, we need to break up Facebook from Instagram and the other potential competitors that Facebook bought up. We need to - at a minimum - move towards opt-in, we need to hold Facebook responsible for enabling discrimination, and we need to require interoperability.

But that's not enough. There is so much we don't know about Facebook. We know we have a corporate monopoly that has repeated serious violations that are threatening our democracy. We don't know how their algorithm treats news organizations or content producers, how Facebook uses its own information about Facebook users or how tracking across platforms works, to just give a few examples.

Now that the initial show trial is done, we need the real deal, one where no senator gets cut off after a few minutes. The real hearing would allow for unlimited questions from each of our senators, who represent millions of people. If it takes two months of sitting in Washington DC, let it take two months. This is our democracy.


  • •

    Zephyr Teachout is an American academic, political activist and former political candidate 


LOAD-DATE: April 11, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBGNS



Copyright 2018 The Guardian, a division of Transcontinental Media Group Inc.
All Rights Reserved


172 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Independent (United Kingdom)


April 11, 2018 Wednesday 9:55 AM GMT 


Mark Zuckerberg's private notes from Facebook hearing accidentally revealed;
They show criticism of Apple and how he would have answered calls for him to be fired


BYLINE: Andrew Griffin


SECTION: NEWS; Version:3


LENGTH: 427 words


Mark Zuckerberg expected senators to ask him to resign, his private notes have revealed.

The Facebook boss would have made clear that he had made mistakes and that the company had faced "big challenges", they show. But he would say that it had faced such challenges before and succeeded, and would do the same this time around. 

During his grilling by congress, Mr Zuckerberg left open the notes that he or an aide had prepared for the questioning. And the notes, which show the variety of ways that Mr Zuckerberg prepared, reveal what he was expecting from the questioning.

In the end, the questions were far more easy to deal with than the ones that Mr Zuckerberg had prepared for. As well as preparing for the unasked question ofwhether he would step down, the notes concentrate on other big questions - such as whether the company should be fined for harvesting data - but the questioning was largely kept to explaining Facebook's business model.

Mr Zuckerberg's notes were briefly visible to an Associated Press photographer during a hearing Tuesday in which he answered questions about privacy, election interference and other issues.

Read more

Zuckerberg claims Facebook doesn't have a monopoly

The bullet-pointed pages include sections on "diversity," "competition," and GDPR, the European data-privacy rules that go into effect next month. Zuckerberg's notes warn him, "don't say we already do what GDPR requires."

The notes even refer to Tim Cook, the Apple CEO who recently criticized Facebook. One note says there are "lots of stories about apps misusing Apple data, never seen Apple notify people."

Most of the notes are written in such a style. Under the heading "compensation", for instance, the notes read "No credit card information or [Social Security numbers] shared" - apparently suggesting that Mr Zuckerberg would reject the idea of paying users caught up in the scandal because they had not lost out monetarily.

Another part of the notes reads "breaking up", which was presumably prepared in casesenators brought up the often suggested move that Facebook should be split up into different companies to stop it being a monopoly. "US tech companies key asset for America; break up strengthens Chinese companies," the notes read.

Mr Zuckerberg had undergone intense preparation for the two sets of hearings and other meetings on Capitol Hill, which have been called partly in response to the Cambridge Analytica controversy. As well as the detailed notes, he also underwent mock hearings with Facebook staff role playing as the senators asking him questions.


LOAD-DATE: April 11, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBI



Copyright 2018 Independent Digital News and Media Limited
All Rights Reserved


173 of 413 DOCUMENTS




MailOnline


April 11, 2018 Wednesday 9:42 PM GMT 


Instagram will soon let you download your data, too: Facebook-owned app to launch tool revealing every photo, video, and message you've shared


BYLINE: REUTERS and ANNIE PALMER FOR DAILYMAIL.COM


SECTION: SCIENCE; Version:3


LENGTH: 702 words



  • •

    Instagram will launch a data portability tool that lets users download their info  

  • •

    It's only limited to photos and videos, not other data like followers or comments 

  • •

    Facebook introduced a similar 'Download Your Information' tool in 2010  

  • •

    User data privacy has come into focus in the wake of Facebook's privacy scandal  

Facebook's massive privacy scandal has highlighted the importance of user data protection and privacy.  

Now it seems Instagram is taking some new steps to give users more control over their data on the app. 

The Facebook -owned social media platform says it will soon allow users to download a copy of all the content they've uploaded on the platform. 

That includes data like photos and videos, according to TechCrunch.  

Scroll down for videos  

Until now, Instagram has lacked a data portability tool and users don't have the option of saving their photos after they've already been posted to the app. 

That's despite Facebook introducing a similar feature, called the Download Your Information tool, in 2010. 

'We are building a new data portability tool,' an Instagram spokesman said via email.

'You'll soon be able to download a copy of what you've shared on Instagram, including your photos, videos and messages'.  

Importantly, the tool lets users control the data they've uploaded to the platform, but not necessarily all the data Instagram has collected on them. 

It's unclear whether the tool will also let users download lists of users they follow or who follow their account, likes, comments or Stories, TechCrunch said. 

Thus far, users have been forced to use potentially unsecure or scammy third-party apps to download their data from Instagram, via apps like Instaport.           

If the tool is launched before May 25, it will help Instagram comply with upcoming European privacy laws that require data portability, TechCrunch noted. 

The soon-to-launch General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) laws also require companies to delete user data upon request.  

Instagram, which has some 800 million users worldwide, did not say when it expects to launch the tool.  

Facebook's 'Download Your Information' tool allows users to download everything off their profile, including things like friends lists, events, messages, wall posts and photos, among other things.

It's been a helpful tool for users who want to learn more about what information Facebook has collected on them. 

It also makes it easier for users to move off the platform should they decide to delete their account in favor of using a different social media service.  

But it's also been somewhat of a wake up call for users who were shocked to learn that the firm was scraping data like call logs and text messages. 

In the wake of Facebook's privacy scandal, many users and experts have criticized platforms like Instagram, Twitter and Google for being similarly tight-lipped about the amount of data they collect on their users. 

Some users have said that they would move to using only Instagram after being outraged by Facebook's data collection practices.

However, many were quick to point out that other top social media platforms, like Instagram and WhatsApp, are both owned by Facebook and, therefor, likely to be just as suspicious when it comes to user data privacy. 

A recent study by internet search engine Duck Duck Go found that a majority of Americans don't know that Facebook actually owns Instagram. 

A survey of 1,153 US adults showed that 56.9% of them didn't know the social media giant owns Instagram. 

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg was questioned about this when he testified on Capitol Hill on Tuesday and Wednesday. 

Zuckerberg answered questions from lawmakers about the firm's massive privacy scandal, which resulted in 87 million users' data being harvested without their knowledge from the platform by Cambridge Analytica, a political consultancy.   

Senators asked Zuckerberg to name some of Facebook's legitimate competitors, to which he said Google, Apple, Amazon and Microsoft. 

He added that internet users tend to use an upwards of eight different apps on a regular basis.   

Critics pointed out, however, that Facebook owns many of those apps, including Instagram, WhatsApp, Messenger and the core Facebook app. 


LOAD-DATE: April 12, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDM



Copyright 2018 Associated Newspapers Ltd.
All Rights Reserved


174 of 413 DOCUMENTS




mirror.co.uk


April 11, 2018 Wednesday 5:56 PM GMT 


Mark Zuckerberg says you can download EVERYTHING Facebook has on you - here's how;
The Facebook boss is appearing in front of US lawmakers for a second day


BYLINE: By Jeff Parsons


SECTION: TECHNOLOGY; Version:2


LENGTH: 666 words


Mark Zuckerberg has appeared for a second day in front of US lawmakers to defendFacebookin the ongoing row over user privacy.

When asked repeatedly about how the social network collects and uses data, Zuck insisted that users can - at any point - download all the data Facebook has on them.

This isn't a feature that's been around for ages - so you'd be forgiven for not knowing about it until now. 

If you are prepared to download all the data, you may be surprised at just how much Zuckerberg's company knows about your private life.

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg says his OWN data was sold to Cambridge Analytica

"I believe that all of your information is in that file," Mr. Zuckerberg told Congress in America during a hearing today.

In order to download all your data, click the small arrow in the corner of the app and select the Settings option.

Scroll down to "Download a copy of your Facebook data" and the social network will put all of it into an archive for you.

The EU's incoming GDPR law gives Europeans the right to data portability which means data controllers are required to share your data with other controllers of your choosing if you instruct them to do so. So, theoretically, Facebook could be instructed to move all your data to another social network if you want to swap to a different platform.

How to keep your data safe online - the easy steps you can take to protect your information

Will you ever delete your Facebook account?

Mr Zuckerberg's testimony is drawing attention from the UK government.

Speaking at a cyber security conference in Manchester, Home SecretaryAmber Ruddsaid Facebook "have some questions to answer" and urged the firm and Cambridge Analytica to "engage with the inquiry that the Information Commissioner has already started."

She told guests: "I do think that we are engaged in a sea change at the moment, particularly in terms of the public's awareness of what's happening with their own private data, and what they are trading for their free access to social media sites.

How to unsend WhatsApp messages and other tips and tricks: the ultimate guide to the global chat app

"They may still want to do it on the scale that's taken place.

"But I feel with my conversations with my friends and with my children in their 20s that there is an awareness which is now settling in of what actually maybe happening.

"I also think that social media sites like Facebook and other major internet sites like Google have been taking many more steps then they have in the past about engaging with what needs to be done in terms of cleaning up their sites."

She added: "I do think they are waking up to the fact that they do have much more of a responsibility to ensure that the sort of activity that we see, and we all agree is illegal offline, doesn't take place online."

Simon Migliano, head of research atTop10VPN.comtold us that the Cambridge Analytica data breach shows how freely available personal information has become.

"As the scandal continues to rumble on, people are increasingly becoming aware of the fact that their own data could well be being used without their knowledge - or their explicit consent," he said.

"For those who aren't quite ready to completely delete their social media accounts and apps, there are ways that users can protect themselves without completely erasing their online profile.

"Taking more care on social media, for example, can reduce your visibility to these companies. Turn off location finding settings, delete any personal info you wouldn't want in the public domain - even if it tells you it's only visible to you - and be wary of using the likes of Facebook to log into third party sites.

"It's also worth doing a complete audit of app permissions on your mobile devices - does that app need access to the camera? If not, then revoke it. Also be wary of installing apps that ask seemingly unnecessary permissions."


LOAD-DATE: April 13, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDMI



Copyright 2018 Trinity Mirror, Plc.
All Rights Reserved


175 of 413 DOCUMENTS




telegraph.co.uk


April 11, 2018 Wednesday 11:26 AM GMT 


Snapshot of Mark Zuckerberg's Congress notes answers questions he wasn't asked


BYLINE: By Matthew Field


SECTION: TECHNOLOGY INTELLIGENCE; Version:3


LENGTH: 602 words


Mark Zuckerberg was last night grilled for five hours by US senators, although their questions failed to elicit many new revealing answers about the data controversy that has gripped the company.

What did reveal some of Facebook's own thinking, however, was Mark Zuckerberg's crib sheet of notes prepared ahead of the hearing.

The two sheets of A4, photographed by the Associated Press, reveal some of the key issues Facebook has been responding to, the questions he was ready for, and the questions senators failed to capitalise on. 

Within the notes, underlined sections included comments that "NO credit card/SSN [social security number] info" was taken, as well as one note on whether Zuckerberg should "Resign?" or have Facebook broken up. One of the most extensive sections included a comeback to Apple chief executive Tim Cook, who has criticised the company's handling of the crisis.

It also included some pre-prepared lines and counter arguments that Zuckerberg should give. One comment reads: "If attacked: Respectfully, I reject that"; another says: "Let's be clear: Facebook doesn't sell your data".

He also prepared to responses on Facebook as a monopoly, including dropping hints about how China was developing major tech companies and it was important to protect US business.

Here are some of the key questions Zuckerberg prepared for:

On Cambridge Analytica


  • •

    "Kogan sold [data] to CA [Cambridge Analytica] in violation of our terms; when we found out, told them to delete data". 

  • •

    "Confirmed they had - now seems untrue" 

Zuckerberg apologised for the data that was used by Cambridge Analytica, but made it clear it was Aleksandr Kogan, the Cambridge University researcher, who violated Facebook's guidelines, not a data breach.

On his position


  • •

    "Fire people for CA?: It's about how we designed the platform. That was my responsibility. Not going to throw people under the bus." 

  • •

    "Resign?: Founded Facebook. My decisions. I made mistakes. Big challenge, but we've solved problems before, going to solve this one. Already taken action." 

Zuckerberg wanted to stress he took responsibility for how the platform was designed, but added he was not going to resign.

On Tim Cook


  • •

    "Lots of stories about apps misusing Apple data, never seen Apple notify people" 

  • •

    "Important you hold everyone to the same standard" 

Zuckerberg clearly feels affronted by attacks from Tim Cook during the Facebook data scandal. He came equipped to fire back at the iPhone giant, hitting out at Apple's high prices: "at [Facebook] we try hard to charge you less. In fact we're free".

On advertising


  • •

    "Let's be clear: Facebook doesn't sell data. You own your information. We give you controls." 

Awkwardly, more than one senator seemed confused about how Facebook made money, with one questioning how it even made revenue if it didn't get paid subscriptions.

Mark Zuckerburg faces Congress | The six questions that left us wincing On wellbeing


  • •

    "Time spent fell 5% Q4; pivot to MSI" 

One of Facebook's new motto is to move to "Meaningful social interactions", which could mean some people spend less time on the platform.

On EU data rules


  • •

    "GDPR (Don't say we already do what GDPR requires)" 

Perhaps anticipating a slip up over questions on new EU data privacy rules (general data protection regulation), Zuckerberg's team highlighted he shouldn't say the company already complies with the rules .

Technology intelligence - newsletter promo - EOA


LOAD-DATE: April 11, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDTNS



Copyright 2018 Telegraph Media Group Limited
All Rights Reserved


176 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Guardian(London)


April 10, 2018 Tuesday 5:00 AM GMT 


Congress wants to 'inflict pain' on Mark Zuckerberg. Is he ready for it?;
Facebook CEO will testify before committees over data misuseA major test for Zuckerberg's communication skillsMark Zuckerberg testifies before Congress over Facebook data scandal - live


BYLINE: Olivia Solon in San Francisco


SECTION: TECHNOLOGY; Version:2


LENGTH: 855 words


Mark Zuckerberg would like you to know one thing - Facebook messed up. During a rare press conference last week, Zuckerberg was grilled by journalists over Facebook's privacy lapses. His message was consistent: mistakes were made, he takes responsibility and the company has made sweeping changes to better protect user data.

"We didn't take a broad enough view of what our responsibility is, and that was a huge mistake. It was my mistake," he said.  

While some of the questions were tough, it was merely a dress rehearsal for a much more consequential grilling in Washington DC this week. On Tuesday, Zuckerberg will testify before a joint hearing of the Senate commerce and judiciary committees over data misuse, following revelations that Cambridge Analytica acquired millions of profiles of US citizens and used it to build a software program to predict and influence voters. The next day, Zuckerberg will testify on the same topic before the House energy and commerce committee.

Taking the stand will be a major test for Zuckerberg's communication skills. Unlike when he deals with the media, his public relations team won't be there to cherry-pick questions from friendly parties. And Congress wants its pound of flesh.

"Congress is theatre. More than what they are going to want to learn [about the data lapses], they are going to want to inflict pain. They are going to want to be seen as being responsive to public disgruntlement with how Facebook handled the issue," said Ari Ratner, founder of communications consultancy Inside Revolution and former Obama administration official.

Adam Hodge, a crisis communications veteran from SKDKnickerbocker, agrees. "I expect members of Congress are going to grill him intensely and if they feel like they aren't getting straight answers they are going to lose their patience pretty quickly," he said.

Zuckerberg will want to come across as authentic and apologetic, and will, according to his testimony published on Monday, highlight the sweeping changes that the company has announced already to its privacy tools and to the way third parties can access data on the platform as well as a verification process for political advertisers and page administrators. He will probably also want to talk about Facebook's global compliance with General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), a broad set of privacy protections being introduced in the European Union in May.

"He clearly has to deeply, personally apologise and hope he will satisfy and blunt any attempt at US regulation," said Jeffrey Chester, executive director of the Center for Digital Democracy. "He does not want to see strong regulatory oversight."

Although Zuckerberg will likely continue to blame "bad actors" misusing the platform, it will be difficult to deflect questions about Facebook's core business model of continually tracking and monetising individuals and their relationships.

"This is a long-standing problem, not a bug in the Facebook system. It's a feature," said Robyn Caplan, a researcher at Data & Society, pointing out that Facebook lured third-party developers by offering them access to user data.

"The main issue is not whether or not entities have individual data but how that data is being used. How are advertisers or political campaigns using that data to come back onto the Facebook system and seed content to particular users," she added. "We know very little about how this targeting works."

Chester agrees: "People have no idea what is operating behind the Facebook curtain. They don't know about data mining, analytics and digital ad practices," he said.

The company is pouring money into its defence, hiring US law firm WilmerHale, led by Reginald Brown, previously a special adviser to President George W Bush, to coach Zuckerberg on the best strategies for handling the heat, according to the New York Times.

At the same time Facebook is bolstering its lobbying capabilities. The company spent almost $12m on lobbying in 2017 and is currently on a "hiring spree" for policy communications specialists. In spite of this investment, Zuckerberg can't expect an easy ride - as the bosses of other companies in industries facing public and political ire have found.

One tactic policymakers might use is to fixate on tiny symbolic details that might tarnish Facebook rather than questions that go to the core of the problem. This happened in 2008 when the CEOs of Ford, Chrysler and General Motors took private jets to Washington to request taxpayer bailout money.

"They came to discuss the fate of a major industry and Congress hit them on 'why did you fly here?'" said Ratner. "He's going to have to be prepared for that."

A few rounds of public humiliation might just be the price Zuckerberg has to pay to appease regulators, provided he is generous with his time and detailed and contrite in his responses. The only real imminent regulatory threat to his company is the Federal Trade Commission's investigation, which could lead to huge fines.

"Symbolically he's going to be taken to the political woodshed, but will probably be let off without any serious consequences at a federal level," said Chester.


LOAD-DATE: April 10, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBGNS



Copyright 2018 The Guardian, a division of Transcontinental Media Group Inc.
All Rights Reserved


177 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Times (London)


April 10, 2018 Tuesday  
Edition 1;
Ireland


Data watchdog denies conflict of interest over INM speech


BYLINE: Michael Cogley


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2


LENGTH: 544 words


The country's data watchdog has said that there was no conflict of interest in delivering the keynote speech at a cybersecurity conference organised by Independent News and Media (INM).

Helen Dixon, the data protection commissioner (DPC), spoke at the media company's Dublin Data Sec 2018 event yesterday on the issue of general data protection regulation (GDPR) - the European Union's effort to harmonise privacy laws across Europe. Ms Dixon is investigating an alleged data breach at INM. She said there were "no issues whatsoever" when asked about a possible conflict of interests. She said that she booked to attend the meeting months in advance and received no fee for her appearance because it was "part of the job".

INM is at the centre of an alleged data breach scandal after the Office of the Director of Corporate Enforcement (ODCE) applied to the High Court to appoint inspectors to look into the company's affairs. The ODCE has also filed an affidavit with the court that outlines claims relating to the alleged unauthorised access of past and present staff emails. The case will come before the High Court next Monday. 

In her speech Ms Dixon said it was essential to have clear policies in place for staff regarding the consequences of a breach of GDPR. She identified transparency as a key area in the new EU-wide regulation.

"Organisations need to know that there will be a way of holding them to account if they do not shoulder responsibility," Ms Dixon told delegates. "Issues arise when organisations don't think before they act, and don't take the time to implement the legislation."

When asked whether or not there was a conflict of interest in attending the INM event, Ms Dixon said: "No issues whatsoever, it's just one of a series of events to promote compliance with GDPR."

The new regulations will come into effect on May 25 and will introduce guidelines for the handling of personal data. The main changes centre around right to access, the right to be forgotten, breach notification and data portability. Citizens will be able to request the deletion of any personal data about themselves stored by a private company. Fines will also apply for businesses found not to be complying with GDPR, which can be up to 4 per cent of a company's turnover up to a limit of (EURO)20 million.

INM allegedly failed to tell the commissioner last year that the copying of its computer servers under the direction of Leslie Buckley, the company's former chairman, involved the transfer of personal information. The publisher notified the data regulator's office of a potential data breach last August after it emerged that Mr Buckley had authorised a British firm to access the servers without informing the company's board or management. The DPC quickly decided that no data breach had occurred but has now revealed that INM only disclosed that the issue related to the British company not having a contract. The Sunday Times reported that the DPC has sent INM a list of questions that must be answered this week as part of a scoping exercise. This followed a second breach notification from the company on March 26. The DPC is expected to launch a targeted investigation into the newspaper group this month. Mr Buckley has denied any wrongdoing.

Lise Hand, page 13


LOAD-DATE: April 10, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: TIM

178 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Guardian(London)


April 9, 2018 Monday 6:07 PM GMT 


Oyster cards, passengers' privacy and data protection laws;
Lauren Sager Weinstein, Transport for London's chief data officer, explains what happens to its customers' information. Plus Jon Baines on the General Data Protection Regulation


BYLINE: Letters


SECTION: TECHNOLOGY; Version:1


LENGTH: 415 words


We take protecting the privacy of our customers extremely seriously ( How to keep data truly safe? Don't collect it in the first place, 4 April). Aside from cases where it is essential that we know the identity of a holder of an Oyster card - such as when checking customers are entitled for free or discounted travel - there is no requirement for anyone to share their personal details with us. 

For all cards, including those Oyster cards where proof of identity is required, we deliberately break the link in our systems between the card and the journeys made with it as soon as that link is no longer required for customer support, such as processing fare refunds.

Paying to top up an Oyster with a bank credit or debit card, or making a journey with a contactless payment card, does not result in us holding any personal data about that customer, in line with payment industry rules.

All customers have an option to register their personal details with us so that we can provide additional services, such as the ability to view their full personal journey history online. Such details are, of course, essential to ensure that we are only sharing that customer's information. Any personal data given to us is never shared with anyone else, except where disclosures are made under highly prescribed circumstances, largely to law enforcement agencies where it is permitted by law or when the individual has given their consent.

Our only interest is in making travel in London as convenient and straightforward as possible, while protecting the privacy of our customers. Lauren Sager WeinsteinChief data officer, Transport for London

· Jack Schofield says "The European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which comes into force on May 25,will govern the storage and processing of data rather than its collection" ( Ask Jack, theguardian.com, 29 March). However, the GDPR, just like its predecessor, the 1995 European Data Protection Directive, expressly covers the collection of personal information about us. The history of Europe in the 20th century shows the chilling risks inherent in the collection of names - and ethnic identities - on lists. The scope of data protection law is very broad, and for good reason. Jon BainesData protection adviser, Mishcon de Reya LLP

· Join the debate - email guardian.letters@theguardian.com

· Read more Guardian letters - click here to visit gu.com/letters


LOAD-DATE: April 9, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBGNS



Copyright 2018 The Guardian, a division of Transcontinental Media Group Inc.
All Rights Reserved


179 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Guardian(London)


April 9, 2018 Monday 7:53 AM GMT 


'A mix of junk and important stuff': how we sorted out our charity data for GDPR;
Preparing for the new EU data protection regulation is a huge headache for an organisation like ours. Here's how we tackled it


BYLINE: Philippa Frankl


SECTION: VOLUNTARY SECTOR NETWORK; Version:1


LENGTH: 1330 words


Dealing with the European Union's tough new data protection law General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) feels like moving house and confronting the piles of boxes in the attic. They're full of stuff you haven't touched in years. You know you have to clear them out, but you also know they contain a mixture of junk and important stuff. You're going to have to read every last scrap of paper and do a mega sort-out.

On top of the day job, dealing with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) is a massive piece of work. Ahead of the compliance deadline on 25 May our team at the School for Social Entrepreneurs (SSE) has had to sort through 21 years of personal data about the social entrepreneurs and charity leaders we support across an international network of 11 schools. That includes email addresses, marketing preferences, phone numbers, financial information about other organisations, sensitive data - the works.

Related: GDPR: how can I email data securely to comply with the new regulations? 

SSE was founded in 1997 and, although our customer relationship management system has been updated since then, there are still records lurking in a plethora of places - there are probably even Filofaxes and Rolodexes to go through. A digital audit revealed we had data stored on platforms such as MailChimp, Eventbrite and Paperless Post, and staff were stashing documents stuffed with data on their desktops for certain projects.

Discussions about how to tackle GDPR started in February 2017 after the organisation signed five-year funding agreements with Lloyds and the Big Lottery Fund, but the bulk of the work is happening now. The confusing terminology has made it a daunting task. I have read endless articles on GDPR that have succeeded only in confusing me more. One catchy phrase that often pops up is having a "valid lawful basis in order to process personal data". A lot hinges on this, since processing someone's data is different from being allowed to contact them.

The best free guide I've found is Charity Finance Group's GDPR: a guide for charities. It is comprehensive and comprehensible, and encourages you to look at the processes of the whole organisation through the lens of GDPR, not just fundraising and marketing.

In the end, I found it helpful to pay for some support for the team. Two members paid £49 to attend a workshop with solicitors Russell-Cooke, which was helpful. I also hired a freelance GDPR consultant for some initial guidance and to ensure we were on track, and spoke to the law firm Linklaters, with whom we have a pro bono relationship. It helped us update contracts and rewrite our data protection policy. Trustlaw can also be helpful for charities and social enterprises looking for pro bono support.

Related: GDPR: how charities should prepare for data protection changes

After developing a plan, my team needed to share it with the wider organisation. GDPR involves far more people than you might think, and everyone needs to be briefed on how to handle personal data.

This has been a complex but valuable process. As an organisation, we are now much more confident in the completeness of our data. Our processes have been streamlined and staff now understand the permission needed when we contact people. We have a greater understanding of how to protect sensitive data about the people we support, and how we can use that to measure our impact.

Much like a spring clean, getting to grips with GDPR is arduous and time consuming. But you'll feel much better once it's done.

Philippa Frankl is the director of programmes and learning at the School for Social Entrepreneurs

Sign up now for our free, monthly Voluntary Sector newsletter, and share your view with us via @Gdnvoluntary

Looking for a role in the not-for-profit sector, or need to recruit staff? Take a look at Guardian Jobs

Much like a spring clean, getting to grips with GDPR is arduous and time consuming. But you'll feel much better once it's done. mirror.co.uk


April 9, 2018 Monday 3:28 PM GMT 


Cambridge Analytica is currently recruiting for 'trustworthy and reliable' data protection staff;
The company under investigation by the ICO is currently recruiting for a data protection assistant


BYLINE: By Jeff Parsons


SECTION: TECHNOLOGY; Version:1


LENGTH: 595 words


Cambridge Analytica is actively hiring data protection staff that it claims should be "trustworthy and reliable" despite currently being under investigation forharvesting the Facebook data of millions of users.

In a jobposting to the Indeed recruitment website, the data analytics company, explains it is looking for "an individual who has an interest in and enthusiasm for data protection."

The job listing has provoked scorn from some data protection experts who say it is a sign of "disrespect" to the users that had their Facebook data harvested in order to win elections. 

Described as a "temporary" role, the job listing appears to be centered around the incoming GDPR law in May.

How to keep your data safe online - the easy steps you can take to protect your information

It says the successful candidate will have "significant experience as an administrator, probably in an executive support, compliance or assurance role and have an ability to unfailingly meet deadlines and work under pressure."

There is no salary listed, but the qualifications require the candidate to be: "completely trustworthy and reliable, demonstrate attention to detail, and be comfortable using own initiative."

When asked about the job posting by Mirror Tech,Cambridge Analyticahas so far declined to comment.

Others see the move as a being a case of too little, too late.

"Hiring new employees and growing operations is a clear sign of disrespect to public concerns about how private digital trails are used for political manipulation without user's informed consent," Evgeny Chereshnev, CEO and founder ofBiolink.Tech, told Mirror Tech.

"I hope that with GDPR coming into effect, companies like CA will finally start caring about digital private property, which is our data, or go out of business."

Cambridge Analytica chief Alexander Nix sets date for another grilling from MPs to explain 'inconsistencies' in his evidence

Alexander Nix, the suspended CEO, is currently preparing to appear for a second time in front of Parliament's Digital, Culture, Media and Sport committee on April 17th.

Cambridge Analytica suspended Nix after footage was broadcast of him boasting to undercover reporters that the firm could entrap politicians using bribes and beautiful Ukrainian women to give their clients political advantage.

But the firm doesn't appear to be slowing down recruitment plans in his absence.

Some have argued it is futile for the company to try and proceed.

"For many, Cambridge Analytica's plans to hire a Data Protection Assistant will look like an exercise in futility - like sticking a plaster on a sword wound," Simon Migliano, head of research atTop10VPN.comtold Mirror Tech.

"The Facebook breach aside, you'd have assumed that a company operating in Cambridge Analtyica's line of business would already have a fully resourced data protection team in place with the integral GDPR regulations kicking in," he said.

Future File podcast: Facebook fallout and the state of privacy on the social network

"Hiring someone into this role now might be well-intentioned but it's hard to avoid seeing this as a belated PR move to redeem its alleged wrongdoings.

"Quite simply, to the outside world this all seems too little too late.

"As the debate around use of personal information on the web continues to gather pace and sucks in more and more players, it's going to be hard for companies caught up in this vortex right now to extricate themselves without it becoming a bit messy."

181 of 413 DOCUMENTS




Express Online


April 8, 2018 Sunday 3:01 PM GMT 


Tesco turnaround: CEO to say profits have bounced back to £1.1bn


BYLINE: Geoff Ho


LENGTH: 551 words


TESCO will unveil pre-tax profits of more than £1 billion and say that its recovery is firmly on track at its annual results on Wednesday, according to City analysts.

GETTY

Tesco has generated pre-tax profits of £1.1 billion, says CEO Dave Lewis

Chief executive Dave Lewis is expected to say that Tesco generated pre-tax profits of £1.1 billion for the 12 months to the end of February, compared to just £145 million for the year before, as it continues to put the troubles of the past behind it. 

Profits are expected to leap more than six fold because of improved trading, lower debt repayment costs and a sharp reduction in the level of business write-offs that Tesco had to make during the year. Additionally, revenues are tipped to be 3.1 per cent higher at £57.7 billion.

Lewis is also set to bring cheer to the supermarket giant's long-suffering investors, by confirming that it will pay a final dividend of 2p per share, which will cost the firm approximately £195.4 million.

Combined with the 1p interim dividend it declared last October, its first in three years, it brings the total payout to investors for the 2017/18 financial year to approximately £293.1 million.

Related articles Cheapest supermarket UK: THIS is the best value chain to buy food from Tesco launches scheme 'bags with barcodes' giving customers discounts

Shore Capital head of research Clive Black said: "Dave Lewis can say confidently that Tesco has left the intensive care unit, it has left the medical ward and can leave the hospital, but it still has some recovering to do. "We're looking for good, solid numbers from the UK business, where it has outperformed its peers."

Phil Dorrell, partner at consultant Retail Remedy, said: "Tesco has had a steep climb over the last three-and-a-half years since Lewis took over, but it is on track and it should be happy with its progress."

According to data from market research group Kantar Worldpanel, Tesco's share of the grocery market stabilised over the course of the 2017/18 financial year, falling just 0.1 percentage points to 27.9 per cent, despite the ongoing price war waged by its traditional rivals and German discounters Aldi and Lidl.

Lewis was parachuted in to Tesco in September 2014 to replace chief executive Philip Clarke, who was ousted after two profit warnings and the discovery of accounting errors.

As part of his turnaround plan, Tesco has cut its prices and ranges, closed unprofitable stores, pared back its overseas empire and improved customer service.

It has also acquired Britain's biggest food wholesaler Booker and investors expect Lewis to update the market as to how the integration is going.

Investors will also be looking for Lewis to provide teasers as to how Tesco will grow its margins.

However, Dorrell warned that they will never get back to historic levels because of the impact of Aldi and Lidl.

Elsewhere, online fashion retail powerhouse Asos is expected to say that its interim pre-tax profits have jumped 54 per cent to £42.1 million on Wednesday, thanks to surging sales in the US, Europe and other overseas markets.

Related articles Private equity does not benefit businesses or society, says GEOFF HO Lidl, Morrisons, Asda & Co-op URGENTLY recall products and warn cus... GDPR 2018: Will GDPR changes in May spell disaster for Britain's bu...


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDE



Copyright 2018 Northern and Shell Media Publications
All Rights Reserved


182 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Observer(London)


April 8, 2018 Sunday 7:00 AM GMT 


Don't just blame Facebook for taking your data - most online publishers are at it too;
Online surveillance is rife but there are plenty of tools available to help preserve your privacy


BYLINE: John Naughton


SECTION: OPINION; Version:1


LENGTH: 955 words


If a picture is worth a thousand words, then a good metaphor must be worth a million. In an insightful blog post published on 23 March, Doc Searls, one of the elder statesman of the web, managed to get both for the price of one. His post was headed by one of those illustrations of an iceberg showing that only the tip is the visible part, while the great bulk of the object lies underwater. In this case, the tip was adorned with the Facebook logo while the submerged mass represented "Every other website making money from tracking-based advertising". The moral: "Facebook's Cambridge Analytica problems are nothing compared to what's coming for all of online publishing."

The proximate cause of Searls's essay was encountering a New York Times op-ed piece entitled Facebook's Surveillance Machine by Zeynep Tufekci. It wasn't the (unexceptional) content of the article that interested Searls, however, but what his ad-blocking software told him about the Times page in which the essay appeared. The software had detected no fewer than 13 hidden trackers on the page. (I've just checked and my Ghostery plug-in has detected 19.) 

In our current online world, only the paranoid thrive

And the point of this? The NYT is just doing what every other publication that lives off "adtech" does: tracker-based advertising. These publications, Searls wrote, "don't just open the kimonos of their readers. They bring readers' bare digital necks to vampires ravenous for the blood of personal data, all for the purpose of aiming 'interest-based' advertising at those same readers."

This is what security guru Bruce Schneier meant when he observed that "surveillance is the business model of the internet". (Pedantic columnists - like this one - might object that he meant the web rather than the internet, but since many people cannot distinguish between the two, we'll let that pass.) The fundamental truth highlighted by Schneier's aphorism is that the vast majority of internet users have entered into a Faustian bargain in which they exchange control of their personal data in return for "free" services (such as social networking and search) and/or easy access to the websites of online publications, YouTube and the like.

The big question for those of us who study this stuff is whether internet users really appreciate the nature of that pact. And if they don't, what would it take to alert them to it? At the moment, the omens don't look too promising. The huge fuss caused by the Cambridge Analytica revelations, for example, has generated a predictable #deletefacebook frenzy in liberal echo-chambers, but outside of those it's not clear that everyday Facebook users are much affected by the controversy.

Related: A radical proposal to keep your personal data safe | Richard Stallman

Granted, recent opinion polls cast doubt over the level of trust people have in Facebook over privacy, despite advertisements the firm ran in British and US newspapers apologising to users. But I doubt that that scepticism will translate into people actually boycotting Facebook, WhatsApp, Instagram and Messenger. And although the company's share price has tumbled, investment analysts are still unsure about whether this is a temporary blip or a real crisis. It might just turn out to be like the VW "Dieselgate" fiasco, in which the share price plummeted but eventually stabilised.

Big though Facebook is, however, it's only the tip of the web iceberg. And it's there that change will have to come if the data vampires are to be vanquished. The good news is that we already have some useful tools available - most of them free - to every internet user; and some potentially heavy artillery is arriving in May. On the tools front, there are browser plug-ins such as Disconnect Private Browsing, Privacy Badger and Ghostery. Installing any one of these tends to administer a salutary shock, because they instantly reveal (and enable you to block) the startling number of snoopers who are covertly tracking your online activity. And anyone who uses public wifi in cafes, airports and other places really ought to fork out for some VPN (Virtual Private Network) software to protect them from tracking and preserve their anonymity. In our current online world, only the paranoid thrive.

The heavy weaponry is the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which becomes law in May. It says that people must be able to easily learn who has their personal data, and what they are doing with it. And it mandates that people must have confidence that no other parties receive these data. If it's rigorously enforced (which could be a big "if" unless data protection authorities are properly resourced) it could blow a massive hole in the covert ad-tracking racket - and oblige us to find less abusive and dysfunctional business models to support our online addiction. So let's resolve not to allow the coming crisis to go to waste.

What I'm reading

Photon opportunity If you want to put our current squabbles into perspective, ponder Icarus, the furthest star from Earth seen so far by the Hubble space telescope. The photons that hit Hubble's image sensor left Icarus 9bn years ago, which means we're looking at it as it was when the universe was a third of its current age. There's a wonderful account by Katyanna Quach in the Register of why we're able to see it now.

Trash talk Mark Zuckerberg's enthusiasm for " helping people become more open " stands in contrast to his obsession with protecting his privacy. For example, anyone planning to rummage through his rubbish is in for a tough time, as Joe Veix discovered in the  Outline.


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBONS



Copyright 2018 Guardian Newspapers Limited
All Rights Reserved


183 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Sunday Times (London)


April 8, 2018 Sunday  
Edition 1;
National Edition


MONEY MADE EASY NEW DATA RULES;
Best Buys


SECTION: BUSINESS AND MONEY;BUSINESS; Pg. 17


LENGTH: 273 words


You may recently have received emails from businesses and charities asking you to "opt in" to their mailing lists. You may have also been sent updated terms and conditions from your bank or social media provider. 

The messages are part of a new EU law on data protection and privacy, which comes into force on May 25.

What are the rules? The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) covers all organisations that handle data, from multinationals to small firms, schools, charities and NHS trusts. It applies in all EU states and will continue to be law in the UK after Brexit.

Organisations will not be allowed to collect and use personal information without the individual's consent. Also, they must report data breaches to the authorities within 72 hours. If they break the rules, they face fines of up to 4% of global turnover or (EURO)20m (currently £17.5m), whichever is higher.

What does it mean for me? You will be able to ask an organisation for a copy of all the data it holds on you, which must be provided within 30 days. Also, you will be able to insist that Facebook delete your profile or Google erase information in its cloud.

If organisations have previously sought consent to collect your data, the records may not meet GDPR standards, and they will have to ask again.

Top tip Expect to be deluged with emails from companies asking permission to keep you on their mailing lists in the run-up to May 25. If you do not want to remain on a list, do nothing and you will be removed.

If you are unhappy about how an organisation has handled your details, report it to the Information Commissioner's Office (bit.ly/ico-hand). Ruth Emery


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: STS



Copyright 2018 Times Newspapers Limited
All Rights Reserved


184 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Sunday Times (London)


April 8, 2018 Sunday  
Edition 1;
National Edition


HOW SAFE IS YOUR DATA?;
Estate agents know a lot about you. Graham Norwood explains how new rules will help protect your privacy


BYLINE: Graham Norwood


SECTION: HOME;FEATURES; Pg. 11


LENGTH: 892 words


Cambridge Analytica and Facebook may have grabbed headlines over how our personal information is harvested and used, but a much bigger data revolution is coming soon, and it will affect us all.

The new General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) takes effect on May 25. It gives all consumers new rights to access information held about them, makes it mandatory for businesses to manage data securely, and has stiff fines for those who don't fall into line.

Applying to all public and private firms - not just estate agents and developers - it means more rights for buyers, sellers, tenants and landlords. 

The core principles are that personal data should be used only for the purpose intended, with exceptions only with explicit consent. So, for example, an estate agent sponsoring a school fete must not use details held by the organisers as the basis for a mailing list for advertising homes for sale - unless individuals have explicitly agreed their information may be used for marketing, too.

"At the rougher end of estate agency there's a lot of cold-calling, leaflets dropped through doors and wild behaviour - a bit like some 'no win, no fee' lawyers. Some of that will have to stop," says Alex Newall, managing director of Barnes Private Office, a property advisory service working with high networth individuals. Here's what the new data laws may mean for you.

What data is currently held? Estate agents have basic information on sellers and buyers such as phone numbers, email and home addresses, ages and communication preferences. As part of separate antimoney-laundering rules, some agents also hold proof of a buyer's ability to pay for high-value property. Letting agents have even more information, including bank details, proof of immigration status and creditworthiness, and referees.

However, like any other online activity, browsing property sites may leave a data trail. Some agents gather a wealth of "under the radar" information via cookies and other technology - for example, which types of houses you look at, how long you spend on a website and what links you click on. Under GDPR, online identifiers such as a computer IP address will now count as personal data.

How safe is this data? "Consumers should check the 'privacy policy' on agency websites, where they explain how they handle your data, and how you opt in or out of future communications," says Michael Day, who runs Integra Property Services, a consultancy that has been training agents on GDPR.

However, some agents are starting from a low level of data security. Two years ago the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) - the watchdog that will preside over the new regulation - rebuked agents in a report, accusing the industry of undertaking too little formal training in data protection. Customers were often not being told how information would be stored and used, it warned, and there was a lack of awareness about security systems such as encryption.

"More than 500,000 people work in real estate in the UK. That's a lot of people handling a lot of personal data. It's an important responsibility to get that right, and our report suggests there's room for improvement in a lot of sales and lettings agents," the ICO concluded.

How long can agents keep my details? Article 5 of GDPR states data must be kept "no longer than is necessary for the purposes for which the personal data are processed". The vagueness of this may give rise to disputes - if you register as a buyer with an agent, how long can you legitimately continue to receive property details? Agents will vary in their approach to GDPR but it is likely that when you register to sell, buy, let or rent a home you will have separate paperwork setting out how your data will be stored and used, and asking you to opt in or out to allowing its use for future marketing.

Can I get this data removed? Under Article 17 of GDPR individuals have the right to have personal data erased under "the right to be forgotten". In most cases this has to be done by the agent without question, but there are exceptions. "For example, if an agent has a legal obligation to keep financial records for a stipulated period in line with anti-moneylaundering law, such data is not going to be deleted before that legal obligation expires," Day says.

Can agents still cold-call and send me mailshots? Mass leaflet drops across a whole neighbourhood or postcode are likely to continue - they don't use personal data. But highly specific mailshots - for example, communications trying to poach you away from an agency that you are already using to sell your home - may be against GDPR. More generally, if you've recently dealt with an agent and were given the chance to opt out of such marketing but chose not to, the business is entitled to continue sending material to you.

What's the penalty if the law is broken? The current ICO fine for a data breach cannot exceed £500,000, but from May 25 organisations face penalties of up to 2% of their annual turnover or (EURO)10m, whichever is higher, if they breach the GDPR code of conduct. For infringements relating to an individual's personal data, that rises to 4% of turnover or (EURO)20m, whichever is higher. However, these penalties are only for the most extreme cases.

Some agents gather a wealth of 'under the radar' data - the type of houses you look at and links you click on


LOAD-DATE: April 8, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: STS



Copyright 2018 Times Newspapers Limited
All Rights Reserved


185 of 413 DOCUMENTS




Express Online


April 7, 2018 Saturday 9:00 AM GMT 


GDPR 2018: Will GDPR changes in May spell disaster for Britain's businesses?


BYLINE: Owen Gough


LENGTH: 1125 words


GDPR, the EU regulatory ruling, comes into effect May 2018 and will affect EVERY business in the UK. All businesses must comply or risk the consequences. But will non-compliance with the new rulings spell DISASTER for Britain's businesses?

GDPR, or General Data Protection Regulation, requires all businesses to protect and properly manage all customer privacy data. 

The EU regulations, coming into effect May 25, 2018, are designed to revolutionise the way public data is handled by big companies.

The ruling states that businesses must make all efforts to protect and securely manage all private and personal data of any EU citizen or customer that they hold.

The rulings were put in place in response to a sustained spate of major hacks stealing millions of user data.

In these cases, the businesses are at fault for not securely protecting data, putting every customer at risk of having their data stolen and used against them.

Related articles EU rules BLOCK Facebook tool to stop suicides over data protection EU data protection rules to BAN schools from posting students' results

What is GDPR?

Any company that collects and holds data on citizens or customers in the EU will have new expectations to protect private data of users.

In a bid to set a higher bar for consumer rights and security, businesses will now be required to comply with a strict set of rules by the cut-off date. 

The new rules will take over a dated EU regulation formed in 1995, to keep up with modern technology and data gathering.

The new rules will be consistent across all 28 EU states, but the bar is set to a very high standard, with businesses having to make significant investments into their business to comply.

GETTY

GDPR 2018: Will GDPR changes in May spell disaster for Britain's businesses?

What types of privacy data does the GDPR protect?

Basic identity information such as name, address and ID numbers

Web data such as location, IP address, cookie data and RFID tags

Health and genetic data

Biometric data

Racial or ethnic data

Political opinions

Sexual orientation

GETTY

Any business who deals with EU citizen data is liable

What happens if you don't comply?

Non-compliance could be fatal to most businesses, so getting clued up on rules is vital.

Any breach of data from a company will immediately incurs fine of up to £23.6 million or 4 percent of the total worldwide annual turnover, whichever is higher.

No number to be sniffed at.

That fine for one breach would cripple most large companies, let alone any smaller companies caught out.

GETTY

Businesses now need to keep customer data under lock and key

There's some debate about whether high fines will be levied, and in what circumstances, but it's possible that some data regulators will want to send a clear message by making an example of a company for non-compliance.

Apparently, the European Data Protection Board will offer guidance on fines, but that guidance is not yet available and the first few cases are liable to set a precedent.

Most UK businesses will have invested more than £1million in making sure they are fully compliant.

Tamzin Evershed is head of legal at Veritas Technologies, understands that, while many businesses are aware of GDPR, they don't know the consequences of non-compliance.

In an exclusive interview with Express.co.uk, Tamzin said: "One of the key challenges that many companies are facing is the complexities around effectively managing their data regardless of where it sits in their organisation. Companies need to have complete visibility into data, including what information is stored, how it is used, who owns it and who accesses it. 

GETTY

GDPR comes into effect May 25

"They also need to have the ability to search through large volumes of digital data so that it can be accessed quickly to respond to requests from individuals to access, erase, or restrict personal data in a timely manner, in line with GDPR requirements.

"Aside from technology, businesses must also instill a culture of digital compliance and responsibility among employees. Our research found that many businesses are putting in place new processes and policies including training, rewards and updated contracts in support of GDPR compliance.

"As a result, employees will understand the role they play in protecting their organisation's data.

"If businesses focus on implementing the right technologies and processes to better manage their data, the potential business benefits are huge. Those that achieve GDPR compliance expect to benefit from improved customer relationships, a stronger reputation, and improved revenues."

But what about Brexit?

Unfortunately, Brexit will not make any difference when it comes to GDPR.

Our membership in the EU, or soon to be exclusion, is not going to impact the rule changes.

GETTY

Consumers are now more aware of their own protection rights.

Dave Rogers, security product specialist at King of Servers, Told the Express.co.uk: "The UK government has supported the legislation since it was initially read in the European Parliament, and it has already indicated that when the Brexit process is complete it will essentially, 'copy and paste' any EU law the UK is subject to into UK law.

"Some commentators have suggested that perhaps when parliament is able to legislate without interference from Brussels, GDPR will be repealed.

"However, we think this is quite unlikely. As it stands, the EU is one of the UK's biggest trading partners, and in order to continue doing business with countries inside the EU, the UK will need to ensure its own data protection laws match GDPR.

"Failure to do so may impact Britain's ability to do business with countries in the EU."

Richard Potter, CEO of Data science and AI company, Peak, sees this as an opportunity for businesses.

Mr Potter spoke to the Express.co.uk and said: "GDPR presents businesses with a great opportunity to get organised and uncover some of the potential that is currently locked inside their data. Businesses will have to take the required measures to locate, identify and organise their data, keeping only the bits that are useful.

"So, if you're keeping it, why? And what can you do with it? Brands will be able to gain greater insights from a more streamlined and relevant database, allowing them to make better business decisions.

"In terms of risks involved, the hefty fines speak for themselves; up to (EURO)20 million or 4 percent of global revenue, whichever is greater."

Related articles GDPR 2018: What is General Data Protection Regulation? WhatsApp will NOT share YOUR data with Facebook after all Cyber security platform MAILOCK gets a grip on encryption


LOAD-DATE: April 7, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDE



Copyright 2018 Northern and Shell Media Publications
All Rights Reserved


186 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Times (London)


April 7, 2018 Saturday  
Edition 1;
Ireland


The free-for-all with our data couldn't go on;
New EU regulations will be costly for commerce and damaging to small firms but are a welcome brake on tech giants


BYLINE: Emma Duncan


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 17


LENGTH: 895 words


Can I tell you about something that can get those dodgy pictures off the internet for you at the same time as wiping the self-satisfied smile off Mark Zuckerberg's face? That's a slightly dishonest way of introducing the topic of a vast piece of EU legislation, but I thought that if I kicked off with some of the more recondite clauses from the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) you would do what I would under the circumstances, which is to put the newspaper down and wander out into the garden with the dog, wondering vaguely whether spring is ever going to do its usual magic on the muddy battlefield over which the neighbourhood foxes have been waging gang warfare all winter.

Give me a couple of minutes, though, for the GDPR deserves your attention: it may make the future a little less grim than it sometimes threatens to be. 

The new rules, which come into force next month, require companies to be much more careful and upfront about what they do with our data. They would have prevented Cambridge Analytica from gaining access to the data of 87million Facebook users without their www.consent.No longer will companies be able to rely on pre-ticked boxes to gain our permission to email us whenever they like, or sell on information about us. They will have to be much hotter on issues such as security breaches. They will be responsible for enforcing the "right to be forgotten" - deleting both the embarrassing stuff we have put out there at incautious moments and the mendacious stuff other people have put out there about us.

The fines for breaches of the new regulations are eye-watering. Right now, the maximum fine in Britain for breaking the existing law is £500,000. Under the GDPR that will go up to (EURO)20 million (£17.5 million) or 4 per cent of last year's revenues, whichever is higher. The Information Commissioner's Office, which implements data-protection rules, will get more powers. Under the existing rules, it had to wait four days for a warrant to search Cambridge Analytica's office, while employees reportedly carted plastic boxes off the premises.

The risk of breaking the rules inadvertently seems high, for they are 88 pages long and of baffling complexity. All over the country, lawyers are toasting each other in magnums of Château d'Yquem paid for by the countless hours they have spent poring over this legislation with their clients. And it's not just big fat companies whose profit margins can absorb these costs that have to deal with this.

A friend with a tiny art business has been warned that she may be in breach of the regulations if she doesn't contact everybody on her mailing list to check that they really want to be on it. If everybody's inboxes are overflowing with similar emails most of them will drop off, in which case she will not have a business. She's not sure what to do, so she's going to consult a lawyer. More foie gras, waiter!

The regulations will push up the cost of doing business, and companies will pass those costs on to consumers. When you think about how much we get on the internet free - videos, music, stories, maps, and all the knowledge in the world - that's not an insignificant issue. And regulations raise the cost of doing business and so make it harder for entrepreneurs to thrive, thus slowing the pace of innovation and entrenching the power of big companies, those whose misuse of our data is the reason we're all in a stew about the subject right now.

And yet I think we probably need this great regulatory juggernaut, or something like it at least. If my behaviour is anything to go by, consumers are too feckless or ignorant to keep an eye on what the companies that live off their data are doing with it. I neither know nor care which of my secrets they are selling to whom until some scandal makes me pay attention. I agree to everything, and then get outraged when it's too late.

As a society, we therefore have a choice: we can either allow companies to do pretty much whatever they want, and thus gain more and more knowledge about us and power over us, or we can assign to our government the duty to keep those companies in check.

America, whose constitutional protection for freedom of speech limits the scope for data-protection laws, is taking the former route, Europe the latter. Hence the GDPR.

In most spheres of life, I would be horrified by a piece of regulation bound to gum up the wheels of commerce as soundly as this one undoubtedly will. But in the tech sector, I'm not that bothered. Although I regret the fact that it will give big companies an advantage over small ones, I can deal with the idea that the pace of innovation may slow.

Humankind is not built to cope with very rapid change and, at the risk of sounding as though I were 103, the rate at which technology has revolutionised our lives over the past couple of decades has been a little speedy for me. I could do with a bit of stasis before our next alarming lurch into whatever fresh hell artificial intelligence is planning for us.

Thank you for your patience. I'm sorry to have detained you on such a dreary subject, but I think it matters. Not, however, as much as your dog and garden do. They are calling.

Emma Duncan is social policy editor of The Economist Janice Turner is away

Consumers are too feckless or ignorant to watch these companies

Humankind is not built to cope with this very rapid change


LOAD-DATE: April 7, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: TIM



Copyright 2018 Times Newspapers Limited
All Rights Reserved


187 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Times (London)


April 7, 2018 Saturday  
Edition 1;
National Edition


The free-for-all with our data couldn't go on;
New EU regulations will be costly for commerce and damaging to small firms but are a welcome brake on tech giants


BYLINE: Emma Duncan


SECTION: EDITORIAL; OPINION COLUMNS; Pg. 25


LENGTH: 895 words


Can I tell you about something that can get those dodgy pictures off the internet for you at the same time as wiping the self-satisfied smile off Mark Zuckerberg's face? That's a slightly dishonest way of introducing the topic of a vast piece of EU legislation, but I thought that if I kicked off with some of the more recondite clauses from the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) you would do what I would under the circumstances, which is to put the newspaper down and wander out into the garden with the dog, wondering vaguely whether spring is ever going to do its usual magic on the muddy battlefield over which the neighbourhood foxes have been waging gang warfare all winter.

Give me a couple of minutes, though, for the GDPR deserves your attention: it may make the future a little less grim than it sometimes threatens to be. 

The new rules, which come into force next month, require companies to be much more careful and upfront about what they do with our data. They would have prevented Cambridge Analytica from gaining access to the data of 87million Facebook users without their www.consent.No longer will companies be able to rely on pre-ticked boxes to gain our permission to email us whenever they like, or sell on information about us. They will have to be much hotter on issues such as security breaches. They will be responsible for enforcing the "right to be forgotten" - deleting both the embarrassing stuff we have put out there at incautious moments and the mendacious stuff other people have put out there about us.

The fines for breaches of the new regulations are eye-watering. Right now, the maximum fine in Britain for breaking the existing law is £500,000. Under the GDPR that will go up to (EURO)20 million (£17.5 million) or 4 per cent of last year's revenues, whichever is higher. The Information Commissioner's Office, which implements data-protection rules, will get more powers. Under the existing rules, it had to wait four days for a warrant to search Cambridge Analytica's office, while employees reportedly carted plastic boxes off the premises.

The risk of breaking the rules inadvertently seems high, for they are 88 pages long and of baffling complexity. All over the country, lawyers are toasting each other in magnums of Château d'Yquem paid for by the countless hours they have spent poring over this legislation with their clients. And it's not just big fat companies whose profit margins can absorb these costs that have to deal with this.

A friend with a tiny art business has been warned that she may be in breach of the regulations if she doesn't contact everybody on her mailing list to check that they really want to be on it. If everybody's inboxes are overflowing with similar emails most of them will drop off, in which case she will not have a business. She's not sure what to do, so she's going to consult a lawyer. More foie gras, waiter!

The regulations will push up the cost of doing business, and companies will pass those costs on to consumers. When you think about how much we get on the internet free - videos, music, stories, maps, and all the knowledge in the world - that's not an insignificant issue. And regulations raise the cost of doing business and so make it harder for entrepreneurs to thrive, thus slowing the pace of innovation and entrenching the power of big companies, those whose misuse of our data is the reason we're all in a stew about the subject right now.

And yet I think we probably need this great regulatory juggernaut, or something like it at least. If my behaviour is anything to go by, consumers are too feckless or ignorant to keep an eye on what the companies that live off their data are doing with it. I neither know nor care which of my secrets they are selling to whom until some scandal makes me pay attention. I agree to everything, and then get outraged when it's too late.

As a society, we therefore have a choice: we can either allow companies to do pretty much whatever they want, and thus gain more and more knowledge about us and power over us, or we can assign to our government the duty to keep those companies in check.

America, whose constitutional protection for freedom of speech limits the scope for data-protection laws, is taking the former route, Europe the latter. Hence the GDPR.

In most spheres of life, I would be horrified by a piece of regulation bound to gum up the wheels of commerce as soundly as this one undoubtedly will. But in the tech sector, I'm not that bothered. Although I regret the fact that it will give big companies an advantage over small ones, I can deal with the idea that the pace of innovation may slow.

Humankind is not built to cope with very rapid change and, at the risk of sounding as though I were 103, the rate at which technology has revolutionised our lives over the past couple of decades has been a little speedy for me. I could do with a bit of stasis before our next alarming lurch into whatever fresh hell artificial intelligence is planning for us.

Thank you for your patience. I'm sorry to have detained you on such a dreary subject, but I think it matters. Not, however, as much as your dog and garden do. They are calling.

Emma Duncan is social policy editor of The Economist Janice Turner is away

Consumers are too feckless or ignorant to watch these companies
