It is, in the words of the American writer Adam Greenfield, a "marriage of database and truncheon". But it is not just a tool for suppressing dissent and dealing with uppity nationalist movements in Tibet, Xinjiang and Inner Mongolia. It is, at least in theory, a code for mechanising people.

On June 25, 1945, weeks after the Red Army had rolled over Berlin, Stalin stood before a reception in the Kremlin and proposed a toast to the vintiki, the ordinary people who were the innumerable screws in the "state machine" of the USSR. In his grand vision, teachers and writers were the "engineers of the human soul". Society was to be twisted, rewired, recalibrated and where necessary ground down until it operated like a vast production line composed of 170 million bodies moving in unison.

Stalin's screw metaphor became a cliché of the first rank in communist China. Mao loved it and trotted it out frequently in his speeches. "A man's usefulness to the revolutionary cause is like a screw in a machine," a young soldier called Lei Feng is supposed to have written in a diary that has become a staple of Maoist propaganda. "It is only by the many and interconnecting screws that the machine can move freely, increasing its enormous work power. Though a screw is small, its use is beyond estimation."

It is only in the 21st century, though, that the government has acquired the technological means to realise this dream. Some of these tools will be familiar to western readers. Nine years ago China had 2.7 million CCTV cameras, roughly half as many as Britain. By the end of the decade it is forecast to have more than 400 million. These include at least 700,000 in Beijing, which is said to have achieved "100 per cent CCTV coverage", and a million across an urban corridor in the province of Guangdong.

There are also 700 million of the highly portable tracking and eavesdropping devices commonly known as smartphones. Communications are routed through app stores and cables controlled by the state, which shut down the internet for ten months during civil unrest in the province of Xinjiang a decade ago.

Xinjiang, where the authorities are struggling to suppress an occasionally violent Uighur separatist movement, is also the petri dish and justification for a new wave of authoritarian gadgets. The police brandish iris and body scanners at checkpoints. They have begun harvesting DNA and blood samples from every citizen between the ages of 12 and 65, even where there is no suspicion of a crime. Since last summer, all the vehicles in the province's Bayingol prefecture have been required by law to carry satellite tracking devices.

Law enforcement officers wear Google Glass-like headsets equipped with facial recognition scanners to help them to identify criminals. In January Xinjiang started trialling a CCTV-based "alert system" that automatically raises the alarm if an individual of interest wanders more than 300m from his home or workplace. The systems are becoming eerily accurate. In a stunt carried out in Guiyang last year, it took the authorities all of seven minutes to find and arrest a BBC reporter.

But the most subtle and insidious of the technologies is invisible. At the heart of the social credit scheme is a nest of algorithms that suck information out of hundreds of different databases to create a meticulous profile of every individual in the country. The idea is not only to know the whereabouts and the doings of all the people, all the time. It is to be able to predict where they will go and what they will do in the future.

China wants to be the world's leading artificial intelligence power by 2030. Its AIs already scurry around the web scrubbing out violent, pornographic or politically questionable material. Yet the sheer volume of personal data in the hands of the state should allow it to make a supercharged, 21st-century version of the dang'an, the old paper files in which citizens' "performance and attitudes" were logged by the party. Again in Xinjiang, the authorities have begun seizing suspected criminals on the strength of AI predictions about their activities. It is a high-tech incarnation of the pre-crime police force in the film Minority Report.

The social credit system extends the reach of the state into the totality of its subjects' lives. It means to take the apparatus of the police state and install it in the minds of its citizens. And the remarkable thing is that it seems to work. Within months of the launch of one social credit programme, more than 100,000 people had boasted about their scores on Weibo. The silence from the losers is deafening. Self-censorship has to some extent been second nature in China for more than half a century but now it is being automated. The authorities appear largely to have succeeded at what the technology writer Rachel Botsman has neatly described as "gamifying obedience" to the state. Or, as Johan Lagerkvist puts it: "This is the Huxley thing - people are happy-golucky about it."

There is often something a little defensive in our clichés about foreign countries. Perhaps it is a way of disowning the awkward parts of our own identity. When we say that the Germans are addicted to rules, or the Russians are credulous nationalistic dupes, we are simply trying to reassure ourselves that we are none of these things.

The social credit project is a case in point. All of its ingredients are present in the West, albeit in a distributed form. Berlin is testing terroristspotting facial recognition cameras in an experiment one statistician memorably compared to a dice-throwing chimpanzee. Last year The Times revealed that a Chinese company called Hikvision had sold 1.2 million CCTV cameras, some of which can see in the dark, recognise numberplates and count the people entering and leaving buildings, to clients in the UK. The buyers included Stansted airport and two local authorities.

Most of the tools, however, are in private hands. We live in a golden age of corporate mass surveillance. Credit-scoring firms are increasingly dealing in stuff that bears no relation to a bank statement, such as individuals' social networks. Insurance companies kit out cars with tracking transponders to keep tabs on their mileage. Vitality Health, a British medical insurer, gives discounts to some customers if it can see from their Fitbits that they have been exercising properly. Facebook, as it emerged this week, has been hoovering up records of its members' calls and texts, often without their knowing it. Cambridge Analytica notoriously claimed to have amassed more than 4,000 data points on every adult in America.

This is both the promise and the curse of big data. The more that is known about how people behave in aggregate, the more we will be judged on the traces that our choices and actions leave in cyberspace; and the more our future choices and actions will be shaped by these systems. The net effect is a ratchet of conformity that qualitatively, if not quantitatively, resembles the social credit programme. A cynic would say that Beijing is simply pursuing social capitalism with Chinese characteristics.

"Some people see the Chinese system as moving towards digital totalitarianism," Hetan Shah, executive director of the Royal Statistical Society, says. "Whether that's true or not, it does pose a thought experiment for us which we must guard against." Mr Shah sees hopeful signs that Britain will be well protected against abuses of the technology. The government is planning a data ethics centre that will address some of these problems. It is also in the middle of implementing the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), a raft of European legislation intended to give citizens a greater measure of control over how their personal information is used by private companies.

Others are less confident that the West's defences will hold. Gerd Gigerenzer, a psychologist at the Max Planck Institute for Human Development in Berlin, is leading a review of these intrusive practices for the German ministry of justice. It is not likely to be an uplifting read.

Professor Gigerenzer views the episode of the TV series Black Mirror in which a rating app has turned society into a state-sponsored popularity contest as more of a prophecy than a fantasy. If the Chinese social credit project works, he fears that the model of omnipresent, omnipotent government could prove an irresistible alternative to the unholy mess of democracy.

"Chinese officials think the age of democracy is coming to an end," Professor Gigerenzer says. "We need to be very clear about what our values are. One can have an argument that as long as it's a benevolent dictatorship, you're better off than in a democracy that can elect someone like Trump."

It could never happen here. Until, perhaps, it does.

Oliver Moody is science correspondent

The provincial government has begun seizing suspected criminals on the strength of predictions about their activities "


LOAD-DATE: March 31, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Police officers wear facial recognition goggles that can, for example, identify jaywalkers. As in the film Minority Report, starringTom Cruise, officials also aim to predict crimes before they happen

201 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Daily Telegraph (London)


March 30, 2018 Friday  
Edition 1;
National Edition


More than half of British firms are unprepared for new privacy rules;
Technology Intelligence Matthew Field explains what the GDPR means for companies and consumers


BYLINE: Matthew Field


SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 4


LENGTH: 492 words


TECHNOLOGY firms are scrambling to update their privacy settings before the European Commission brings in new data laws in May. GDPR, or general data protection regulation, is an EU-wide set of rules around personal data. 

It applies to data used by businesses and organisations, sets standards for how it is used, brings in rules for reporting data breaches, and requires that organisations gain consent, or an opt-in, for gathering data.

The regulations come into force on May 25, meaning businesses will have to change their notifications for collecting data from users. Importantly for tech giants like Amazon, Facebook and Google, GDPR will apply to companies based outside the EU, and any company handling EU data will have to comply with the rules.

What are the requirements? Article 5 of GDPR sets out principles for collecting personal data. It states that: data must be collected for a specific purpose; it must be limited and relevant; it must be accurate and up to date; it must be kept for no longer than is necessary; and it must be secure.

Individuals also get bulked up rights under GDPR. These include the right to be informed, so users get better and clearer information about the data they are giving up; the right to be forgotten; the right to see what data has been processed; and, importantly, that their data can only be gathered with active consent and not harvested indiscriminately.

In the event of a data breach, businesses must quickly inform users within a 72-hour deadline.

What are the potential fines? GDPR has businesses worried due to the potential fines that can be imposed if they don't comply. The biggest impact will be on companies that suffer a data breach. Firstly, companies must inform users within 72 hours or face a (EURO)10m (£8.7m) fine, or 2pc of their turnover, and those found not to have followed the rules around processing data could face fines of (EURO)20m, or 4pc of turnover.

These are far greater than fines currently meted out under current rules. TalkTalk was fined £400,000 by the Information Commissioner's Office in 2016, a record, but this would have been £59m under the new rules. That said, the ICO is supposed to enact "proportionate" fines, so they may not be so steep.

What impact will Brexit have? While Brexit will change plenty of UK laws, so far GDPR has not been affected. GDPR will come into effect before Brexit next year, and in the Queen's Speech last year the Government set out that GDPR would bring the rules into UK law post Brexit.

Are businesses prepared? In short, no. Most businesses are still working out how they will be affected. According to a report from EY, only a third of businesses around the world said they had a plan for GDPR. A report in February from the Department of Digital, Culture, Media and Sport said that fewer than 50pc of UK firms had made changes to comply with GDPR. The general picture is that plenty of businesses don't realise they need to make changes.


LOAD-DATE: March 30, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: DTL



Copyright 2018 Telegraph Media Group Limited
All Rights Reserved


202 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Daily Telegraph (London)


March 30, 2018 Friday  
Edition 1;
National Edition


Facebook severs ties with data sellers in latest pledge to users;
Technology Intelligence


BYLINE: James Titcomb


SECTION: BUSINESS;NEWS; OPINION; COLUMNS; Pg. 4


LENGTH: 498 words


FACEBOOK has shut down a programme that allows advertisers to target individuals using information obtained from third-party data sellers after the UK's data watchdog raised concerns about the practice. 

In the latest privacy pledge from the social network, which has been fighting a torrent of criticism that it has failed to protect users' privacy, Facebook said it would stop using information from "data brokers" such as Experian, the credit checking agency. Facebook would access the information in exchange for sharing revenue from adverts with the data providers. It was able to use the data to target adverts at particular groups of people even when Facebook users had not given the social network the data themselves.

The programme allowed businesses to direct adverts at groups such as home owners or with certain purchase histories. "While this is common industry practice, we believe this step, winding down over the next six months, will help improve people's privacy on Facebook," Graham Mudd, of Facebook, said.

It is unclear why it took the decision to cut off ties with data brokers, which is likely to mean a significant amount of lost advertising revenue, but the UK's privacy regulator said it had been pushing the firm over the issue and would soon release more details.

Elizabeth Denham, the information commissioner, who has been investigating how data was used for political purposes during the Brexit referendum and last year's election, said: "I have been examining this service in the context of my wider investigation into the use of personal data for political purposes and had raised it with Facebook as a significant area of concern." Frederike Kaltheuner, of campaign group Privacy International, said: "It is extremely hard to learn what data brokers hold on you as an individual. The only time users might be informed about their existence is in the privacy policies of data broker customers like Facebook." Shares in Acxiom, one of the data brokers Facebook used, fell by 20pc yesterday. Facebook, which has been buffeted by allegations it failed to protect users and allowed the data of 50m users to be harvested and retained for years by Cambridge Analytica, the election consultancy, has made a series of privacy pledges in recent days.

Earlier this week it overhauled its privacy settings to prepare for strict European data laws known as the GDPR that will come into force in May. Apple also unveiled a privacy overhaul in anticipation of the new laws. A software update released yesterday will mean users are shown extra information about how personal information is shared with Apple.

The company will also let users delete their accounts, or "deactivate" them so that no personal data is processed by Apple. A new section of Apple's website in May will let users download all data held by the company. Apple says it takes a "comprehensive approach to privacy" and differs from other technology companies in selling hardware rather than online advertising.


LOAD-DATE: March 30, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: DTL



Copyright 2018 Telegraph Media Group Limited
All Rights Reserved


203 of 413 DOCUMENTS




MailOnline


March 30, 2018 Friday 8:29 AM GMT 


Update your iPhone NOW: Apple launches iOS 11.3 with improved battery management, new Animoji and a raft of privacy features to protect your data


BYLINE: ELLIE ZOLFAGHARIFARD FOR MAILONLINE


SECTION: SCIENCE; Version:3


LENGTH: 1092 words



  • •

    Users are shown more information about how personal information is shared 

  • •

    The update will allow users to easily delete or deactivate their Apple accounts  

  • •

    It also includes improved augmented reality features and new Health records 

In the wake of Facebook's privacy scandal, Apple has launched a raft of new tools in iOS 11.3 that will allow consumers to better control how their data is used.

The features mean users are shown more information about the ways in which their personal information is shared with Apple. 

They will also allow users to delete or deactivate their accounts so that Apple is no longer able to process their personal data. 

The latest software update also includes new Animoji characters, improved augmented reality features, and the ability to turn off processor throttling for iPhones with old batteries.

Scroll down for video iOS 11.3 and macOS 10.13.4 now have updated data and privacy information.

Privacy features 

One of the biggest updates in iOS 11.3 and macOS 10.13.4 is improved data management. 

Users will now see a new data privacy information page when they update the software.

This page will be used to explain a new icon which appears when an Apple feature collects personal information.

The icon will not appear on features such as Apple's Maps or Siri, for example, because they do not collect user data, whereas it will appear on the App Store or iTunes.

'Apple believes privacy is a fundamental human right so every Apple product is designed to minimise the collection and use of your data, use on-device processing whenever possible, and provide transparency and control over your information,' the company said.

From May the device-maker will also introduce new privacy management tools on the Apple ID website allowing users to get a copy of all their data held by Apple, request a correction, deactivate or delete their account.

The latest update is an attempt by Tim Cook to distance himself from the likes of Facebook.  

Facebook is currently embroiled in a major privacy scandal after millions of users' data were improperly accessed by a political consultancy. 

It also comes as technology companies strive to bring their services into line with a tough new EU data protection law. 

The European Union General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) enters into force on May 25 and is the biggest shake-up of privacy rules since the birth of the internet.

It introduces stiff fines of up to 4 percent of global turnover for companies found to be in breach of the new rules.

Battery performance

iOS 11.3 adds new features to show battery health of an iPhone and recommend if a battery needs to be serviced. 

These can be found in Settings -> Battery and are available for iPhone 6 and later.

Users can now see if the power management feature that dynamically manages maximum performance to prevent unexpected shutdowns, first introduced in iOS 10.2.1, is on and can choose to turn it off. 

This feature can be found in Settings -> Battery and is available for iPhone 6, iPhone 6 Plus, iPhone SE, iPhone 6s, iPhone 6s Plus, iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus.

The update tool is the result of a barrage of criticism that Apple faced when it was revealed that iOS automatically slows down processor performance in some iPhones to prevent unexpected shutdowns.

The tech giant now faces some 60 lawsuits from users that claim Apple slowed down older iPhones to make them buy new ones.

At least 32 lawsuits had been filed against Apple in January and, since then, the number has continued to climb.

Health records 

The iOS Health app has gained a Health Records section.

The new addition allow patients of almost participating 40 health care institutions in the US can view their health records. 

Apple says that this data is encrypted and protected by a passcode.

Augmented reality

Apple's ARKit augmented-reality apps had one major limitation; it could only recognize horizontal surfaces, such as floors and tables,  when deciding where to place virtual objects. 

With iOS 11.3, apps can now deliver AR experiences that use vertical surfaces like walls and doors, in addition to horizontal surfaces.

They can also more accurately map to irregularly shaped surfaces like circular tables.

'Using advanced computer vision techniques to find and recognize the position of 2D images such as signs, posters and artwork, ARKit can integrate these real world images into AR experiences such as filling a museum with interactive exhibits or bringing a movie poster to life,' Apple says. 

The view of the real world through the camera now has 50 percent greater resolution and supports auto-focus for an even sharper perspective.

Animoji

Four new Animoji characters have been introduced for iPhone X users.

They will bring user expressions to life as a lion, bear, dragon or skull. 

The A11 Bionic chip and TrueDepth camera give users the ability to record and send Animoji messages using their voice and more than 50 different facial muscle movements.

Business chat

Business Chat is a new way for users to communicate directly with businesses using the Messages app on iPhone and iPad. 

From today, Business Chat will be available in beta in the US and business will begin rolling out this new messaging feature for customers. 

When searching for a business in Maps, Safari, Search or Siri on iPhone and iPad, users will see the option to contact the business using Messages to ask a question about a product or service, or make a purchase using Apple Pay. 

These conversations can be continued on Apple Watch or Mac. Users are always in control of whether they share any contact information with a business on Business Chat.

Other features 

Apple Music now streams music videos uninterrupted by ads.

Users can watch the latest videos, classics or ones from their favorite artists back-to-back in new music video playlists.

Apple News makes it easier to stay up-to-date on the most important videos of the day with a new Video group in For You, and improved Top Stories. 

HomeKit software authentication provides a great new way for developers to add HomeKit support to existing accessories while protecting privacy and security.

Support for Advanced Mobile Location (AML) to automatically send a user's current location when making a call to emergency services in countries where AML is supported.


LOAD-DATE: March 30, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDM



Copyright 2018 Associated Newspapers Ltd.
All Rights Reserved


204 of 413 DOCUMENTS




MailOnline


March 30, 2018 Friday 8:29 AM GMT 


Update your iPhone NOW: Apple launches iOS 11.3 with improved battery management, new Animoji and a raft of privacy features to protect your data


BYLINE: ELLIE ZOLFAGHARIFARD FOR MAILONLINE


SECTION: SCIENCE; Version:4


LENGTH: 1092 words



  • •

    Users are shown more information about how personal information is shared 

  • •

    The update will allow users to easily delete or deactivate their Apple accounts  

  • •

    It also includes improved augmented reality features and new Health records 

In the wake of Facebook 's privacy scandal, Apple has launched a raft of new tools in iOS 11.3 that will allow consumers to better control how their data is used.

The features mean users are shown more information about the ways in which their personal information is shared with Apple. 

They will also allow users to delete or deactivate their accounts so that Apple is no longer able to process their personal data. 

The latest software update also includes new Animoji characters, improved augmented reality features, and the ability to turn off processor throttling for iPhones with old batteries.

Scroll down for video iOS 11.3 and macOS 10.13.4 now have updated data and privacy information.

Privacy features 

One of the biggest updates in iOS 11.3 and macOS 10.13.4 is improved data management. 

Users will now see a new data privacy information page when they update the software.

This page will be used to explain a new icon which appears when an Apple feature collects personal information.

The icon will not appear on features such as Apple's Maps or Siri, for example, because they do not collect user data, whereas it will appear on the App Store or iTunes.

'Apple believes privacy is a fundamental human right so every Apple product is designed to minimise the collection and use of your data, use on-device processing whenever possible, and provide transparency and control over your information,' the company said.

From May the device-maker will also introduce new privacy management tools on the Apple ID website allowing users to get a copy of all their data held by Apple, request a correction, deactivate or delete their account.

The latest update is an attempt by Tim Cook to distance himself from the likes of Facebook.  

Facebook is currently embroiled in a major privacy scandal after millions of users' data were improperly accessed by a political consultancy. 

It also comes as technology companies strive to bring their services into line with a tough new EU data protection law. 

The European Union General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) enters into force on May 25 and is the biggest shake-up of privacy rules since the birth of the internet.

It introduces stiff fines of up to 4 percent of global turnover for companies found to be in breach of the new rules.

Battery performance

iOS 11.3 adds new features to show battery health of an iPhone and recommend if a battery needs to be serviced. 

These can be found in Settings -> Battery and are available for iPhone 6 and later.

Users can now see if the power management feature that dynamically manages maximum performance to prevent unexpected shutdowns, first introduced in iOS 10.2.1, is on and can choose to turn it off. 

This feature can be found in Settings -> Battery and is available for iPhone 6, iPhone 6 Plus, iPhone SE, iPhone 6s, iPhone 6s Plus, iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus.

The update tool is the result of a barrage of criticism that Apple faced when it was revealed that iOS automatically slows down processor performance in some iPhones to prevent unexpected shutdowns.

The tech giant now faces some 60 lawsuits from users that claim Apple slowed down older iPhones to make them buy new ones.

At least 32 lawsuits had been filed against Apple in January and, since then, the number has continued to climb.

Health records 

The iOS Health app has gained a Health Records section.

The new addition allow patients of almost participating 40 health care institutions in the US can view their health records. 

Apple says that this data is encrypted and protected by a passcode.

Augmented reality

Apple's ARKit augmented-reality apps had one major limitation; it could only recognize horizontal surfaces, such as floors and tables,  when deciding where to place virtual objects. 

With iOS 11.3, apps can now deliver AR experiences that use vertical surfaces like walls and doors, in addition to horizontal surfaces.

They can also more accurately map to irregularly shaped surfaces like circular tables.

'Using advanced computer vision techniques to find and recognize the position of 2D images such as signs, posters and artwork, ARKit can integrate these real world images into AR experiences such as filling a museum with interactive exhibits or bringing a movie poster to life,' Apple says. 

The view of the real world through the camera now has 50 percent greater resolution and supports auto-focus for an even sharper perspective.

Animoji

Four new Animoji characters have been introduced for iPhone X users.

They will bring user expressions to life as a lion, bear, dragon or skull. 

The A11 Bionic chip and TrueDepth camera give users the ability to record and send Animoji messages using their voice and more than 50 different facial muscle movements.

Business chat

Business Chat is a new way for users to communicate directly with businesses using the Messages app on iPhone and iPad. 

From today, Business Chat will be available in beta in the US and business will begin rolling out this new messaging feature for customers. 

When searching for a business in Maps, Safari, Search or Siri on iPhone and iPad, users will see the option to contact the business using Messages to ask a question about a product or service, or make a purchase using Apple Pay. 

These conversations can be continued on Apple Watch or Mac. Users are always in control of whether they share any contact information with a business on Business Chat.

Other features 

Apple Music now streams music videos uninterrupted by ads.

Users can watch the latest videos, classics or ones from their favorite artists back-to-back in new music video playlists.

Apple News makes it easier to stay up-to-date on the most important videos of the day with a new Video group in For You, and improved Top Stories. 

HomeKit software authentication provides a great new way for developers to add HomeKit support to existing accessories while protecting privacy and security.

Support for Advanced Mobile Location (AML) to automatically send a user's current location when making a call to emergency services in countries where AML is supported.

MailOnline


March 30, 2018 Friday 8:29 AM GMT 


Update your iPhone NOW: Apple launches iOS 11.3 with improved battery management, new Animoji and a raft of privacy features to protect your data


BYLINE: ELLIE ZOLFAGHARIFARD FOR MAILONLINE


SECTION: SCIENCE; Version:6


LENGTH: 1080 words



  • •

    Users are shown more information about how personal information is shared 

  • •

    The update will allow users to easily delete or deactivate their Apple accounts

    It also includes improved augmented reality features and new Health records

Apple Music now streams music videos uninterrupted by ads.

Users can watch the latest videos, classics or ones from their favorite artists back-to-back in new music video playlists.

LOAD-DATE: March 30, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Web Publication

206 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Daily Telegraph (London)


March 29, 2018 Thursday  
Edition 1;
National Edition


Facebook boosts privacy controls for users after data scandal


BYLINE: James Titcomb; James Crisp


SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 5


LENGTH: 443 words


FACEBOOK has pledged to overhaul the social network's privacy settings to allow people to easily delete data, amid a swirling privacy row over the information it collects.

The company said it would introduce tools that let users see all the information held by the website and download their own copy or destroy it. The feature will also allow users to port information to another social media site if they wish to leave Facebook. 

The changes are designed to comply with strict new European privacy laws and were not introduced in response to a Facebook-user backlash over data following the Cambridge Analytica controversy, the company said.

The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which comes into force in May, demands that companies give customers much greater control over their data and comes with heavy fines, of up to 4pc of global revenues, if they break the law.

Facebook is likely to face heavy scrutiny when the law comes into effect due to the Cambridge Analytica controversy that has battered its share price. The firm has been fighting accusations that it failed to protect users' private data when the election consultancy obtained data from 50m accounts before 2015.

Current data laws allow a maximum fine of £500,000 but under the GDPR this would increase to as much as (EURO)1.6bn (£1.1bn). EU sources said a Facebook-style data breach would be likely to draw the most draconian penalty available.

"This data breach would be a clear candidate for the maximum fine," one source told The Daily Telegraph.

Facebook's chief privacy officer Erin Egan admitted that it is currently too difficult for users to stay on top of their privacy. "The last week showed how much more work we need to do to enforce our policies, and to help people understand how Facebook works and the choices they have over their data," she said. "We've heard loud and clear that privacy settings and other important tools are too hard to find."

Facebook yesterday said it had completely redesigned the settings on its smartphone app to make it easier to control what information is being shared with other users and what adverts users see. The changes are designed to replace 20 different privacy pages with one.

Damian Collins, the chairman of the Commons digital, culture, media and sport select committee, also asked Mark Zuckerberg yesterday to reconsider the Facebook boss's snub the day before.

Mr Collins said he planned to question Facebook's chief product officer Chris Cox in April, but that he hoped Mr Zuckerberg would also appear. "Given the seriousness of these issues we still believe that Mr Zuckerberg himself is the right person to give evidence," he said.

Warning on data protection rules;
MIRRORBIZNI


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 48


LENGTH: 36 words


FIRMS need to act now to make sure they're ready for the introduction of new GDPR regulations in May, a breakfast event has heard.

KPMG's Bernard O'Hara added structures need to put in place to react to data breaches.

Express Online


March 29, 2018 Thursday 10:15 AM GMT 


Facebook share price: 'Toxic' Facebook sheds over $80 billion in value after data scandal


BYLINE: David Dawkins


LENGTH: 730 words


FACEBOOK is in danger of stage-managing its own downfall after shedding a massive $80 billion from the social networking giant's market value. Mark Zuckerberg's personal net worth has fallen by $14billion as his firm struggles to respond to a crisis one expert warned could make Facebook a "potentially toxic asset".

GETTY 

Facebook share price: Facebook has shed $80billion in market value Related articles Facebook data scandal: How much information does Facebook store? Facebook shares LATEST: Facebook stock PLUMMETS as forecast is cut

Facebook shares actually finished the day half a percent in the green yesterday but the rebound failed to stem the bleeding that has seen the firm lose 18 percent in market value following the Cambridge Analytica data privacy revelations in the UK, and a pending government investigation in the US.

As tech stocks around the world got dragged in to the downturn, Fiona Cincotta, senior market analyst at City Index said that traders are continuing to rotate out of tech stocks, preferring to sit on the side-lines with so many regulatory questions remaining unanswered.

She said: "Traders will want to have more clarity over where the Facebook data mismanagement scandal is heading and what the resultant regulatory clampdown will look like, not just for Facebook, but for the sector as a whole before any serious buying interest is likely to pick up."

Facebook is no stranger to controversy and has been able to comfortably resist judicial or governmental scrutiny so far.

GETTY

Facebook share price: Users are concerned over how data has been used

Paul MacKenzie-Cummins from Clearly told Express.co.uk that for the best part of a decade, "Facebook has dominated the social media sphere and each crisis that has come its way has simply slid off its seemingly Teflon-esque profile".

However, he adds this latest crisis is the firm's biggest and potentially most damaging and the way the company reacts over the coming weeks will, in his view, determine its ability to recover and regain the trust lost.

Kerim Derhalli, CEO and founder of investment app Invstr, told Express.co.uk although Facebook has faced crises before, this is the internet giant's biggest yet.

He said: "There has been a tide of distrust and distaste in the huge tech platforms, predominantly since Donald Trump's election, and the ongoing Cambridge Analytica furore hits many tech cynics to their core.

"This could be a watershed moment, as it comes at a time when Facebook sign-ups are slowing, active time on their platform is declining and, once you lose public trust, it can be incredibly hard to regain."

Industry analysts are point towards the growing criticism levelled against Facebook's business model as the single largest cause for investor concern.

There remains a real fear, if Facebook's business model invites increased legal scrutiny, then Mr Zuckerberg's firm's ability to both generate revenue and defend itself from costly legal battles will lead to a massive withdrawal of investor confidence.

Mr Kerim Derhalli said: "Fundamentally, Facebook's model is unsustainable. Selling peoples' data when they were making a few billion dollars was acceptable. Making tens of billions of dollars implies that there is something fundamentally wrong with the social contract between Facebook and their users.

"I doubt Facebook will ever recover both from the loss of trust and the upcoming competitive challenge."

Evgeny Chereshnev, CEO at Biolink.Tech told Express.co.uk yesterday that he worst-case scenario for the tech giant is bankruptcy.

He said: "If there is rock-hard proof and evidence that Facebook data has been used to influence Trump's election, the Brexit decision and many other political voting processes, Facebook could go bankrupt.

"Trust in Facebook has been broken, and investors are dumping stock primarily because of that. There is too much at stake as it's now a potentially toxic asset due the information revealed by whistleblowers and the potential investigation results.

"The amount of legal cases and the dollar amounts of those, especially when GDPR law comes into effect, are potentially too high even for Facebook to handle."

The Guardian(London)


March 29, 2018 Thursday 6:00 PM GMT 


Apple launches iOS 11.3 with raft of privacy features;
Sensing opportunity - and GDPR - the Silicon Valley company launches major data protection push across devices


BYLINE: Alex Hern


SECTION: TECHNOLOGY; Version:1


LENGTH: 431 words


Apple is launching a major privacy push, with software updates across all its devices to introduce new data privacy information immediately, with an updated website offering new privacy management tools to follow in May. 

Thursday's updates (macOS 10.13.4, iOS11.3 and tvOS 11.3) are prompted by the enormous new European data protection regulation GDPR, and have been in the works since at least January. But they come at a good time for the company, whose head Tim Cook has been merrily capitalising on the Facebook/Cambridge Analytica scandal, publicly rebuking Mark Zuckerberg over the social network's business model.

For users of the company's devices, the biggest change will be the introduction of a unified data privacy iconography, which now shows up alongside detailed information about how Apple uses personal data for its various first-party services. "Apple believes privacy is a fundamental human right," the company will tell every user the first time they turn on their devices after the update, "so every Apple product is designed to minimise the collection and use of your data, use on-device processing whenever possible, and provide transparency and control over your information".

Although the new features are prompted by GDPR, they are rolling out to users worldwide, and the company proudly notes that it has not had to change any of its software to comply with the new regulations. Unlike competitors such as Google, who operate on the principle that large scale data collection bestows an advantage in areas such as machine learning and transport planning, Apple has repeatedly argued that it has a responsibility to minimise data collection.

Speaking on Wednesday, Cook said "We could make a ton of money if we monetised our customers, if our customers were our product ... We've elected not to do that. We're not going to traffic in your personal life. Privacy to us is a human right, a civil liberty."

Related: Facebook logged SMS texts and phone calls without explicitly notifying users

In May, shortly before GDPR takes effect, Apple will also update its website to make it easier for users to exercise four key rights granted by the regulation: getting a copy of their data; requesting a correction to their data; deactivating their accounts; and deleting their accounts.

The company sees an opportunity to distinguish from competitors there too: deactivation, in particular, is a much stronger implementation than in other platforms. It removes the user's information from all aggregated data stores, isolating their accounts but stopping short of deleting them.


LOAD-DATE: March 29, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBGNS



Copyright 2018 The Guardian, a division of Transcontinental Media Group Inc.
All Rights Reserved


210 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Guardian(London)


March 29, 2018 Thursday 12:06 PM GMT 


GDPR: how can I email data securely to comply with the new regulations?;
Robert is often required to email sensitive data. Is there a secure way of doing so in view of the new data protection laws?


BYLINE: Jack Schofield


SECTION: TECHNOLOGY; Version:1


LENGTH: 1255 words


As a freelance media professional, I am often asked by my various employers to send copies of my passport, completed visa forms and other sensitive data in the form of email attachments. I have recently questioned this and have not really got a satisfactory response. I have tried uploading these documents to my Google Drive account and giving them a link, though I don't really know whether this method is any safer. However, I am at a loss to see how companies should acquire such sensitive data in light of the new GDPR rules coming into force in May. Robert

The European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which comes into force on May 25, will govern the storage and processing of data rather than its collection. It also includes some very important consumer rights. The most important are the right to be informed, the right of access, the right to correct errors, the right to erase data, the right to restrict processing, and the right take it elsewhere (data portability). How useful these will be in practice remains to be seen.  

"Personal data" includes names, addresses, phone numbers and IP addresses, as well as what GDPR calls "factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity of that natural person". That includes biometrics such as face, fingerprint and iris recognition, and genetic information. In other words, you may have personal data that identifies someone even if you don't know their name.

GDPR applies to companies and organisations, particularly those with more than 250 employees. Home and household users are exempt. However, as a freelancer, you store and process data, even if the "processing" just means entering a name in an address book and looking it up. You should therefore do an audit of the devices and software you use to make sure that other people's personal data is protected. This may require the use of data backups, passwords, encryption, malware protection, and a VPN when using public hotspots. The GDPR also obliges you to tell people if there are any security breaches.

You should also audit your data to make sure that you are only holding data that is necessary for your jobs, or that you are legally required to hold, eg for tax purposes.

The UK's Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) has a useful 12-step plan ( PDF ), though like most things GDPR-related, it's aimed at companies. IBM's Liz Henderson provides a good summary in two posts on LinkedIn, GDPR Plan - Do you have yours? and GDPR Initial Steps, What's Next...?

Note: the GDPR is being modified and implemented in the UK by the data protection bill, which is still going through parliament. It should include some exceptions for journalism similar to the ones in the previous DPA, so check whether these apply to you.

Email problems

You are right to be concerned about sending things by email. Emails are more like plain text postcards because they can, in theory, be read at any of the many servers through which they pass, or by someone tapping a line. Of course, "read by" is unlikely to mean "read by a human being." However, software can look for things like passwords and credit card numbers.

A more likely problem is sending emails to the wrong address, either because users have got their own email addresses wrong (this happens surprisingly often), or through human error. Pick the wrong address from a list of auto-complete suggestions and you could send personal data to the wrong recipient. This would be a data breach that might have to be reported.

It would obviously be good thing if all emails were encrypted by default so that only the intended recipient could read them. Three decades of history says this isn't going to happen soon, if at all. Public key encryption is too hard for people who just want to send normal emails.

Some large organisations do have encrypted email services, such as the NHS, but that doesn't help the rest of us.

Some people do choose secure email services, such as ProtonMail in Switzerland and Tutanota in Germany. However, you also have to send external recipients a password - for example, in an SMS text message - to decrypt the email.

Tutanota users get an email that says "you have an encrypted email" and you click a link to read it, and reply to it, in a browser. You have to export the email if you want to keep a copy.

There are also plug-ins for Gmail and the Microsoft Outlook email program that provide secure email services. If one of your employers is using a secure system, they might let you join in.

If there's no other alternative, you should encrypt and password-protect your images and documents before sending them as email attachments. Again, you must send the password separately, either via a different messaging service or in the post.

Online storage locations

It's a good idea to upload attachments and then send people a link. However, bear in mind that you are uploading documents to the company that probably runs the biggest surveillance operation on the planet. Encrypt your documents before you upload them.

Encryption protects data if an online storage service is compromised - it has happened - or if your email is hacked.

Unfortunately, using Google Drive brings up an extra complication. If you are using Gmail, then you can assume that your data is being held in, or passing through, or accessible from the USA.

GDPR does not oblige users to store data on servers inside the EU. However, there are extra requirements if servers are outside the EU. First, you need to have a legitimate reason for transferring personal data outside the EU. Second, you must have the consent of the person whose data is being exported. Third, you must give that person the option to opt out.

In another post, the aforementioned Liz Henderson explains how to create a GDPR Privacy Notice, and you could adapt her sample to cover Gmail storage outside the EU.

You could switch to using an email service that operates wholly within the EU (see above), if only for any people who opt out, or you could upgrade to Google's paid-for service.

Google claims that its G Suite and Google Cloud Platform (GCP) services are fully compliant with GDPR, because it offers to sign EU Model Contract Clauses and a Data Processing Amendment. The fine print notes that "the parties acknowledge and agree that Non-European Data Protection Legislation may also apply to the processing of Customer Personal Data" and that "Google will not process Customer Personal Data for Advertising purposes or serve Advertising in the Services".

I don't think GDPR will actually stop advertising-driven personal data processing. Just look forward to clicking "I agree" to lots of terms and conditions you won't even bother to read.

IANAL!

Bear in mind that GDPR is a legal matter and I am not a lawyer. I am also not an expert on GDPR. Companies who can be fined up to (EURO)20 million or 4% of their annual turnover should take this stuff seriously and follow the ICO's advice. Lots of consultancies are offering guides, training, software toolkits and other services, too.

Freelancers like us are not the target, but we should work to comply as best we can. In particular, don't keep any personal data you don't need, and store and use it securely. Indeed, you should do those things even if the GDPR didn't exist.

Have you got a question? Email it to Ask.Jack@theguardian.com


LOAD-DATE: March 29, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBGNS

The Guardian(London)


March 29, 2018 Thursday 10:50 AM GMT 


Facebook to stop allowing data brokers such as Experian to target users;
Company to shut down Partner Categories feature to 'improve people's privacy' but analysts question potential impact of change


BYLINE: Alex Hern


SECTION: TECHNOLOGY; Version:2


LENGTH: 458 words


Facebook is shutting down a feature that allowed "data brokers" such as Experian and Oracle to use their own reams of consumer information to target social network users, the company has announced. 

The feature, known as "Partner Categories", will be "winding down over the next six months", Facebook announced in a terse blogpost. The company says the move "will help improve people's privacy on Facebook."

Previously, data brokers were able to target specific sets of Facebook users, letting them bring their wider ad-targeting metrics on to Facebook. Now, they will either have to use Facebook's own targeting tools, or a much more specific form of targeting known as "custom audiences", which broadly requires companies to have a prior relationship with the users they're targeting.

Facebook is also closing down a data flow in the opposite direction, preventing the same data brokers from receiving anonymised information about how their ad campaigns have been received.

The moves come after weeks of bad press for Facebook, sparked by reporting in the Observer and the Guardian that revealed Facebook's lax oversight of data received by third parties. Brian Wieser, senior research analyst at Pivotal Research Group, described the move as "an attempt to generate positive press on the privacy front without directly causing a meaningful negative revenue impact.

"On the margins," he said, Facebook's claim that the change would improve people's privacy "is probably true, but if privacy in the use of data on the platform were the goal, the change has relatively limited impact".

Instead, the move could be an attempt to outflank competitors like Google, Wieser speculated. "We can imagine that Facebook may want to try to make Google and others look worse by comparison to the extent that the use of third party data for targeting is a widespread and highly conventional activity in digital advertising."

The Information Commissioner, Elizabeth Denham, welcomed the news that the feature was shutting down. "I have been examining this service in the context of my wider investigation into the use of personal data for political purposes and had raised it with Facebook as a significant area of concern," she said. "The use of third party sources of data will be covered in more detail in the report my office will publish soon."

On Wednesday, Facebook announced a raft of changes to its platform that were aimed at making it easier for users to alter their privacy settings, and ensure compliance with the forthcoming European data protection regulation, GDPR. "We've heard loud and clear that privacy settings and other important tools are too hard to find, and that we must do more to keep people informed," two Facebook executives wrote in a blogpost.

212 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Independent (United Kingdom)


March 29, 2018 Thursday 5:58 PM GMT 


iOS 11.3: New iPhone update adds messages to tell people when Apple is gathering data;
The move comes amid growing worry about how other major tech companies such as Facebook process people's information


BYLINE: Andrew Griffin


SECTION: NEWS; Version:1


LENGTH: 579 words


Apple has released its latest iPhone update. And perhaps its biggest change isn't really a change at all.

The update brings with it a whole range of features, including the power management tools that Apple has long promised to fix after its battery controversy. But probably the most noticeable change is new boxes that will pop up to everyone, giving information about privacy and data use - not highlighting new features but instead pointing out old ones.

Those pop-ups will first appear when people update the phone, as part of the usual setup process, and will give people general information about the way their phone collects and uses data. They will continue to appear as people navigate through using the phone: every Apple app that gathers information about its user will show one of the boxes, which will describe how that data is being processed. 

Apple has long been far more privacy conscious than other major tech companies - a point that has been made as increasing pressure is turned on Facebook over alleged abuse of user data. The new features are being added partly in response to the new GDPR regulations on data that will come into force in May, but are in keeping with the companies historical commitment to openness and responsible use of data.

The new pop-ups allow Apple to emphasise that fact, while ensuring that people know how their data is being used. Despite their relatively conservative approach to data collection, the company does still gather information on its users, such as what music they listen to and what news stories they read.

Read more

Apple to reveal future of iPhone and other software

The first time users boot up their phone, they will see a message that explains that there is new branding in iOS and that there will be more information available about how data is being used. Then, when they open an app that uses that data - such as the App Store - they'll see a message explaining how it is being done, which they can tap for a full rundown of all the ways data is being collected and analysed.

Similar pages will be available in macOS and tvOS, all of which have been newly updated. They will all use the same branding.

Apple's new privacy push will see further releases in May. Then, Apple will roll out a special page to allow people to take control of their data - and delete it, if they wish.

The page will be part of the Apple ID account settings. By navigating to it, people will be able to get a copy of their data, correct it, deactivate their account so that Apple can't use its data or delete the account entirely and permanently.

At the same time the new update rolls out, Apple will update its privacy page. That will include information about the ways that people can protect their personal data, and information on how that data is being collected and used by Apple.

That page makes clear that Apple for the most part avoids collecting data as much as it can - an approach that has occasionally led it to be criticised for not having some of the same data-powered features that are present in products made by competitors such as Google. Apple uses techniques like differential privacy, for instance, which allows it to see trends in how people are using products without them actually being able to see anything about how individual people are doing so.

While many of the new updates are being rolled out as part of Apple's commitment to introducing GDPR, they are being made available everywhere, not just in Europe.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication

The Independent - Daily Edition


March 29, 2018 Thursday  
First Edition


Facebook introduces new tools that allow users to view and delete their data


BYLINE: ANDREW GRIFFIN


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 11


LENGTH: 449 words


Facebook will give people new ways of seeing and deleting the data it collects on its users, it has said.

The latest development comes as the social network continues to try and stop the damage from the Cambridge Analytica scandal, through which it became clear that the site was collecting many of its users' most sensitive and personal information. Now it says it will add new features in the next few weeks that will change the site's terms of service and its data policy so that people can see how their data is being collected. It will also give people new ways of deleting what has been collected and stopping further information being harvested, it claimed. 

Those tools will allow people to delete data selectively, as well as removing their account entirely, Facebook's announcement appeared to suggest. "Some people want to delete things they've shared in the past, while others are just curious about the information Facebook has," it wrote. "So we're introducing Access Your Information - a secure way for people to access and manage their information, such as posts, reactions, comments, and things you've searched for. You can go here to delete anything from your timeline or profile that you no longer want on Facebook."

Some of those new features are required by GDPR, the new data regulation being introduced by the EU in May that could hit companies such as Facebook. More changes will be announced in the coming weeks, Facebook said in the blog post, which was titled It's Time to Make Our Privacy Tools Easier to Find. The company has faced a global outcry after a whistleblower said that data from millions of users was improperly harvested by consultancy Cambridge Analytica to target US and British voters in close-run elections.

Facebook shares are down nearly 18 per cent since 16 March, when it first acknowledged that user data had been improperly channelled to Cambridge Analytica, eating away nearly $100bn (£71bn) of the company's market value. "We've heard loud and clear that privacy settings and other important tools are too hard to find, and that we must do more to keep people informed," Erin Egan, Facebook's chief privacy officer, and Ashlie Beringer, its deputy general counsel, said in a statement.

In addition to redesigning its settings menu on mobile devices, Facebook said it is creating a new privacy shortcut menu where users would be able to better secure their accounts and control personal information. It would also allow users to review and delete data they have shared, including posts and search queries. Users would be able to download the data shared with Facebook, including uploaded photos, contacts added to their account and posts on timelines.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: IA

mirror.co.uk


March 29, 2018 Thursday 3:00 PM GMT 


How to keep your data safe online - the easy steps you can take to protect your information;
How much do you know about what you share and who you share it with? Take a little time to ensure you aren't giving away more than you want to


BYLINE: By mirror


SECTION: TECHNOLOGY; Version:1


LENGTH: 1213 words


After the revelations aboutCambridge AnalyticaandFacebookin recent weeks, an increasing number of people have chosen to download their Facebook data and investigate exactly what information has been collected on them.

Android phone users who downloaded the app in particular have been distressed to find logs of phone activity not relevant to their account, times calls were made and to who.

While many people have shown concern, and some have acted to improve their privacy and security online, the majority have said it either doesn't bother them, or that having to be alert to the problems - to change their settings and to consider a different way of online engagement- is simply too much hassle.

But how much do you know about what you share and who you share it with? Check your phone settings - do you have your location services switched on? If yes that means every app, every service you use on your phone knows where you are. 

Cambridge Analytica chief Alexander Nix sets date for another grilling from MPs to explain 'inconsistencies' in his evidence

This weekend, rather than idly browsing the internet, take half an hour to familiarise yourself with your data and follow these simple steps to safeguard your data.

You can do this on an Android phone by going to your settings app on your device:

Take the time to see if you have given permission to your contacts, your photo album, your diary, your location, your microphone. Some apps won't need to know this information about you, you have the power to control who sees what.

GooglePlay settings can be foundhere

How you're giving away your private information online without even realising it - 5 reasons to fear your permanent record

Many apps want to know your location but it is rarely necessary for them to know where you are. Where possible turn access to your location off completely.

For apps that need to know where you are such as maps or car sharing apps like Uber, iPhone allow you to only share your location when using the app.

To do this:

9 explosive claims from Cambridge Analytica whistleblower's evidence to MPs

The latest version ofiOS 11on the iPhone also lets you stop your data being tracked. To do this:

You can also clear history and website data at the bottom of that screen - this may mean you have to input logins again but it is worth doing on a regular basis.

Facebook

When it comes to Facebook, first consider deleting the app and making the choice to log into only when you want to look at it. Having the app running on your device all the time enables the app to access contacts, diary, location, photos, microphone. Think about if this is necessary.

If not delete the app and login via the website.

Second, familiarise yourself with the settings.

Cambridge Analytica whistleblower tells MPs about his predecessor's mysterious death

Security

Make sure you use a completely unique password one you do not use anywhere else. Make it a phrase rather than a word, lyrics from a song or a poem. Or a handful of words joined together squirrelseatbrownnuts for example, long passwords with random words are much harder to break.

Using two factor authentication is good, but it means providing your mobile telephone number.

Timeline and tagging helps you decide which of your friends can see what. Choosing 'Review what other people see on your timeline' is well worth clicking.

It can be surprising, even with strong privacy settings, what info can leak out. Your profile photo and cover photo will always be public, but you do not need to permit access to anything else - all your photos, personal info, friends etc can be hidden away so no one other than the friends you have can see it.

Notifications are your chance to stop facebook messaging you all the time. Being notified may seem helpful but it keeps you addicted to facebook. It is good to be able to switch off and think about other things.

MPs urged to probe if Brexit campaign handed insurance company's customer data to Cambridge Analytica

Apps: here you will see all the apps you have given permission to access your facebook data. If this makes you uncomfortable, turn it off.

Apps, websites and plugins - click edit and choose disabled

Apps others use - click and untick every option,

Old versions of Facebook - choose 'only me'

Ads. This page shows all the things Facebook has categorised you under based on your activity on and off Facebook. This includes:

Click on the different headings

You can choose whether you want Facebook to keep these interests, advertisers and information. If not, tap on the box and say no, or delete.

Location data again is really important. The more you tell facebook the more they will follow you.

In the mobile app (on iOS and Android) go to settings, account settings, location, turn off location tracking and disable location history too.

If you want to see what Facebook hold about you on the settings page you will see Manage Account, click edit and scroll down.

At the very bottom outside of the grey box you will see Download a copy of your Facebook data, click and follow the instructions.

If you want to delete facebook gohere.

Google

Whenever you go to Google there is a box on the page saying A privacy reminder from Google. Most of the time you probably ignore it. Don't. Take a moment to review your privacy settings.

Tap Review Now and read the brief information they give you.

Then log into your Google account and make some choices about what you want them to know.

Click at the bottom - sign into your account

If you are already signed in, think about whether always being signed into Google is a good idea. It is the equivalent of leaving your front door open to your home and letting Google just wander around and watch what you do all the time you are online. Whenever possible log in and log out.

When you are signed in click the circle in the right hand corner of the screen which indicates your account.

Cambridge Analytica offices searched by Commissioner's Office

What you will see here is likely to freak you out - as the amount of data Google collect about you can be enormous. But you now have the power to stop it if you want.

You can Pause what data Google collect about you and Manage Activity.

You can stop Google storing searches you have made, stop them gathering your location and delete your location history, stop data being shared between devices, stop them recording your voice

And stop them logging everything you do and watch onYouTube.

This is just the start, but if you can begin the process of educating yourself about these settings and think what choices will protect you rather than expose you.

In May the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) comes into force, it is worth familiarising yourself with the eight data protection rights which we can all use to protect ourselves, including restricting access to data and challenging automated decision making and profiling.

In the offline world we take responsibility over our physical wellbeing, in the online world we must do the same for our digital selves. We are our data, we must take control of it and look after it, because once it's gone, like our physical health, it's gone.


LOAD-DATE: March 29, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDMI
