All Rights Reserved


215 of 413 DOCUMENTS




mirror.co.uk


March 29, 2018 Thursday 2:58 PM GMT 


It's time to take control of our own data, says digital awareness campaigner Renate Samson;
We are digital citizens, says the former chief executive of Big Brother Watch, and it's time to start taking responsibility for our own data


BYLINE: By Renate Samson


SECTION: TECHNOLOGY; Version:1


LENGTH: 889 words


Two weeks have passed since the revelations aboutFacebookandCambridge Analyticawere published. In that time story after story has shown the extent to which our data has been misused, shared, sold and treated with disrespect.

Articles are being shared by panicked users on how to delete their account. Facebook themselves have announced improvedprivacysettings and companies such as Mozilla have launched tools to keep the social media giant's data hungry eyes off your internet activity.

Increasing numbers of people have chosen to download their Facebook data and investigate exactly what information has been collected on them. 

Many have laid bare their shock, anger and fear by what they have found. Android phone users who had downloaded the app in particular have been truly distressed to find logs of phone activity not relevant to their account, times calls were made and to whom.

"Why do Facebook need to know this" they have asked, "I had no choice to download the app if I wanted to message my friends. "I can't believe they have a list of calls and messages it's none of their business".

How to keep your data safe online - the easy steps you can take to protect your information

How to guides are now appearing all over the internet. The extent to which Google track us is becoming the next big conversation point. And all I can say is, finally.

I, along with many others, have been campaigning for years to raise awareness about the extent to which social media companies, advertisers and online services track, monitor and harvest our data. While people have shown concern, and some have acted to improve their privacy andsecurity online, the majority have said it either doesn't bother them, or having to be alert to the problems, to change their settings, to consider a different way of online engagement is simply too much hassle.

Shocking video reveals how easily police can download your phone data WITHOUT a warrant

Now you could argue that it's not for the individual to have to take responsibility for themselves. That this is the problem of the companies, that their approach has been disgusting and that they need to change their business model. And I would agree wholeheartedly.

But, it is not as simple as just pointing the finger at them. We live in a connected world. Never in history have products and people been so intertwined. For the first time we are as much the product as we are the consumer.

Because internet connected devices, services and platforms rely on data to function, every time we engage, every time we share a piece of information, we keep the blood running through their veins. Without our data the body of social media, of smart products, of online shops and advertisers would simply stop breathing.

We are digital citizens. We are digital by default. The internet is now an essential service not a choice. Anyone who connects daily or has a smart device which is always on, always listening and monitoring, is part of the internet eco-system, willingly handing over data to gain instant information, instant communication, the ability to buy with one click, track and monitor health, and demand information from a device in the corner of the room.

Brits could get up to £12,500 EACH from Facebook as expert warns of £625 billion lawsuit against social network

We may have evolved to accept connectivity as a benefit of living in the modern world, but we have not evolved to develop the much needed sixth sense which makes us see the journey our personal data takes. We imagine every engagement with a device or service as we do a human interaction. One on one, not one to many.

If our online engagement were to be made visible, we would be followed around by hundreds of people noting down everything we do and say and watching everyone we know. Whatever piece of information we actively shared, or they surreptitiously gleaned from us they would write down and analyse. It would terrify us.

Until we realise our data is a tangible thing, that we are sharing it willy nilly with companies we barely know, to people we cannot see, who are using and abusing it for their gain not for ours, we will remain insecure and at sea when revelations about data misuse come to light.

Bestiality website hacked and private details of over 3,000 users are leaked

This weekend, rather than idly browsing the internet, take half an hour to familiarise yourself with your data. Think about what you share and with whom.

Look at the apps on your phone, the settings on your smart products and the privacy settings on your social media accounts. Educate yourself about these settings and think what choices will protect you rather than expose you. In May the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) comes into force, it is worth familiarising yourself with the eight data protection rights which we can all use to protect ourselves, including restricting access to data and challenging automated decision making and profiling.

In the offline world we take responsibility over our physical wellbeing, in the online world we must do the same for our digital selves. We are our data, we must take control of it and look after it, because once it's gone, it's gone.


LOAD-DATE: March 29, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDMI



Copyright 2018 Trinity Mirror, Plc.
All Rights Reserved


216 of 413 DOCUMENTS




telegraph.co.uk


March 29, 2018 Thursday 5:00 PM GMT 


Apple software update adds new privacy tools to protect users' data


BYLINE: By James Titcomb


SECTION: TECHNOLOGY INTELLIGENCE; Version:1


LENGTH: 391 words


Apple has launched a new privacy push that will mean the company notifying users when they send any personal data to the tech company, an apparent attempt to draw a line between the iPhone maker and companies such as Google and Facebook. 

A software update released on Thursday will mean users are shown extra information about how personal information is shared with Apple, such as the App Store and iTunes.

The company will also let users delete their accounts entirely, or "deactivate" them so that no personal data is processed by Apple. A new section of Apple's website in May will let users download all the data held by the company, such as photos and contacts.

The changes, which will come in a software update to iOS as well as the Mac and Apple TV operating systems on Thursday evening, are designed to comply with strict new European data protection laws known as the GDPR.

However, they also provide an opportunity for Apple to press its privacy credentials, following two weeks of damaging headlines about Facebook and the company's Cambridge Analytica scandal.

Apple says it takes a "comprehensive approach to privacy" and differs from other technology companies in selling hardware rather than online advertising. Its chief executive Tim Cook said earlier this week : "We could make a ton of money if we monetised our customer - if our customer was our product. We've elected not to do that."

The software update, iOS 11.3, will see a mean iPhone users presented with a new icon and notice when they start up the phone and when using apps such as the App Store or Apple Music in which data is sent to the company.

The company says its services such as Siri do not collect as much personal data as rival assistants because it anonymises much of the information, and that information such as users' fingerprints are kept on a device and never sent to the company.

Technology intelligence - newsletter promo - EOA

Apple will introduce privacy tools on its website in May, ahead of the May 25 GDPR deadline, which allow users to delete all their user data. The process will take seven days, in order to stop malicious attempts to delete the information.

Deactivating accounts will mean users can pick up where they left off if they decide to come back to Apple, but that no data will be used in the meantime.


LOAD-DATE: March 29, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDTNS



Copyright 2018 Telegraph Media Group Limited
All Rights Reserved


217 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Times (London)


March 29, 2018 Thursday  
Edition 1;
National Edition


Harsh fines 'will plug data leaks';
After Facebook's failure, EU data protection rules could not come into force at a better time,


BYLINE: Edward Fennell


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 67


LENGTH: 874 words


"Data is the new oil" gurgles the catchphrase of the moment. And, like any oil spillage, the cost of clearing up and compensation after Facebook leaked the personal details of 50 million of its users is likely to be costly.

Last week a Houston businessman filed a class action lawsuit in a US federal court targeting Facebook and Cambridge Analytica seeking $50 billion in damages. Similar suits have been launched in other US states, and in the UK Hayes Connor Solicitors, the Liverpool law firm, said that it was preparing a group claim. 

Europe has already seen this. Three years ago the Austrian law graduate Max Schrems filed a class action suit against Facebook in Vienna for breaches of privacy rights under EU law. The case ended up in the Court of Justice of the European Union, which decided in January that Schrems could litigate in Vienna against the company. How that case will conclude remains to be seen, but it is clear that the European courts are primed for such challenges.

"The tort of misuse of personal information has emerged as a means by which individuals may claim compensation from organisations that use their personal data in a manner that causes them distress," says James Castro-Edwards of Wedlake Bell. "This right to compensation is likely to be pursued by lawyers bringing class actions against abusive organisations. They will not be subject to the same constraints on resources as government-funded data protection authorities, and are likely to be both effective and prolific."

Ben Robson of Oury Clark Solicitors says that although civil damages have long been available it is only since 2015 that the courts have held that a person can be compensated for distress in situations where no financial loss has been suffered. "The level of damages that could be payable will largely depend upon the nature of the breach and the personal situation of the affected individuals," he says. "However, there is some judicial guidance from a 2016 case involving the Home Office to suggest that a base level of £2,500 may be applicable to distress-only claims."

Against this background it is clear that the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) - which entered into force in May 2016, but becomes fully enforceable on May 25 this year - arrives with perfect timing. That's because underpinning GDPR is the key principle of "use limitation", ie that "personal data should not be used for purposes outside of the original intended and specified purpose, except with the consent of the data subject or the authority of the law".

"The GDPR reaffirms that any person who has suffered material or non-material damage as a result of an infringement of this regulation shall have the right to receive compensation for the damage suffered, ie uncapped damages," Robson says.

"So there is certainly the potential for large-scale class actions of affected data subjects to become a growing phenomenon - albeit much will depend upon the attitude and interpreta-tion of the courts to this area over the coming years."

Jane Finlayson-Brown of Allen & Overy points out that social media and search engine companies were at the forefront of legislators' thoughts when designing GDPR. "Regulators have always been concerned about the use of data in a manner the individual would not expect - whether that is exploitation, disclosure, extended retention or manipulation by third parties for totally unconnected purposes," she says. "GDPR contains mechanisms to allow cross-border co-operation and consistency of regulatory enforcement. It will be interesting to see how easy it is for a co-ordinated approach to be taken."

And that's not the only change arising from GDPR. Emma Gross of SA Law points out: "There will be significant changes for data controllers, like Facebook, who will now be tasked with providing easily accessible and intelligible policies on data protection and subject rights outlining their legal basis for processing data and informing data subjects of their right to have data deleted or rectified."

Added to that are the fines that regulators can impose. "Breaching data protection law carries a maximum fine of only £500,000 in the UK," says Mark Weston of Hill Dickinson. "Would Facebook really care about that level of fine? However, the advent of GDPR provides for fines up to a maximum of the greater of (EURO)20 million or 4 per cent of annual global group turnover. It certainly cares about that."

The final sting for platforms such as Facebook is that their responsibilities extend to the actions of rogue employees. "[As well as] direct liability to those whose personal data they process companies may also have vicarious liability for the accidental, negligent, or even wilfully malicious actions of staff members in the handling of personal data," says Piers Leigh-Pollitt at Doyle Clayton. Companies preparing for GDPR should take note, Leigh-Pollitt says, and ensure that their management and crisis plans can minimise risks to the organisation and pre-empt actions by staff who go against company policy and procedure. Failure to do so could be catastrophically expensive.

Suddenly the dangers of running a social media platform are looking decidedly high.

Time to log off? Times Law will return on April 12


LOAD-DATE: March 29, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Posters at Cambridge Analytica's offices show Alexander Nix, its chief executive

All Rights Reserved


218 of 413 DOCUMENTS




Express Online


March 28, 2018 Wednesday 10:43 AM GMT 


Facebook shares LATEST: Facebook stock PLUMMETS as scrutiny intensifies


BYLINE: David Dawkins


LENGTH: 1357 words


FACEBOOK'S shares are responding to the social media giant's most severe crisis to date after Bank of America Merrill Lynch slashed its price forecast for the second time in five days, while an expert has warned of it becoming a, "potentially toxic asset".

GETTY

Facebook shares LATEST: Mark Zuckerberg is under pressure

Bank of America analyst Justin Post reduced his 12-month price target on the social media giant to $210 from $230, in light of the Cambridge Analytica data privacy revelations in the UK, and a pending government investigation that Mr Post says "raises the risk of civil penalties on data privacy violations". 

Shares in Facebook fell 4.9 percent Tuesday and the stock is down 9.4 percent so far this week and 16.1 percent this month, wiping around $60bn from the tech firm's value.

The Federal Trade Commission confirmed on Monday that a non-public investigation has been opened.

Fiona Cincotta, Senior Market Analyst at City Index, told Express.co.uk that the "Facebook contagion" has infected all tech stocks.

She said: "Facebook continued to fall dropping a further 4.9 percent and taking losses to 20 percent from its February peak as the fallout from the data mismanagement scandal continues.

"The overriding concern is that lawmakers and regulators will start to clamp on the use and management of data by the tech giants. Increased regulation could hit advertisers, Facebook's main income source, who could have reduced access to user data and therefore no longer be able to focus advertising in the way that they can at the moment.

"A hit to this revenue stream could be catastrophic to Facebook."

However, Paul MacKenzie-Cummins from Clearly told Express.co.uk that the fall-out from these revelations goes beyond the $60bn that has been wiped off Facebook's market value, the impact on its reputation could be far greater.

He said: "Each time a new case arises, Facebook's response is the same: delay and hope the story simply goes away - which it never does - followed by denial.

"When that doesn't hold water, remorse sets in coupled with an unswerving pledge to 'fix Facebook' and 'prevent bad actors from accessing people's information'.

"This is topped off by the admission that 'there's more we need to do'.

"For the best part of a decade, Facebook has dominated the social media sphere and each crisis that has come its way has simply slid off its seemingly Teflon-esque profile.

"This latest crisis, however, is its biggest and potentially most damaging and the way it reacts over the coming weeks will, in my view, determine its ability to recover and regain the trust it has lost."

Facebook has fallen foul of users and investors for its handling of personal data following revelations in the UK that political research firm Cambridge Analytica wrongly gained access to personal data of more than 50 million people.

A global campaign to "delete Facebook" has begun and Marie Page one of the UK's leading Facebook marketing authorities told Express.co.uk the social network has lost trust with its end users.

She said: "Despite terms and conditions to the contrary users assumed their data would be kept safe so in return for seeing the results of a gimmicky personality test or online quiz, they happily agreed to the Terms and Conditions not realising that their own data and that of their friends would be mined too.

"The perception is that Facebook should have been more protective of users' data. Zuckerberg's apology has recognised the erosion of trust that resulted and they are scrabbling to regain that and "fix" the various problems Facebook faces as a priority."

Bank of America Bank of America analyst Justin Post said: "The #deletefacebook campaign persists, though Google Trends suggest fervour peaked on March 23, and it remains unclear as to how many users actually are walking away. We see the second quarter of 2018 as the first real test of user trends."

However Mrs Page does not believe that the crisis is terminal, she said: "Facebook's shares have taken a hit but they will bounce back.

"Facebook is the drug we can't do without. Users have short memories and their fear of missing out by deleting Facebook will soon overcome their concerns.

"Those looking to move to other platforms could well face similar issues there. Facebook owns two of the major alternatives: WhatsApp and Instagram - something many users do not realise."

Updates below throughout the day....

GETTY

Facebook HQ: Zuckerberg has apologised in print

2.27pm - UPDATE - 'It's not great for Zuck'

Matt Donegan, CEO of Social Circle told Express.co.uk that Facebook's history has been mired in conflict since its inception.

Mr Donegan says that "Zuck" is the heavyweight champion of Silicon Valley and he knows how to throw some punches - and to deflect heavy blows.

He said: "Facebook's shares have plummeted by 16 percent, wiping $36bn off its market value. It's not great for Zuck, and while he may have "lost" a few $billion - my heart bleeds - the share price is likely to recover."

The CEO says that Facebook should be caring about most is losing users, because the platform is seen to take more than it gives.

He adds: "The lynch mob is in force, and the #DeleteFacebook tag is trending, but time will tell how many people follow through the threats, and actually hit the delete button.

"This news has brought home to people this tough truth and some don't like what they see. If this isn't addressed users will at best view Facebook ads with disdain, and at worst turn away from Facebook.

"An investor cares about one thing: Is my investment going to grow or decline. A drop in engaged users will immediately turn off advertisers - cue unhappy investors."

Mr Donegan believes that Facebook itself isn't dead as an idea but the platform has to focus on putting people and content at its centre, then build privacy conscious ways for contextual advertising to appear around that.

He said: "Cambridge Analytica has shed light on the less savoury practices of this social media goliath. Now will Joe Public be the David that fells Goliath?"

1.35pm - UPDATE - Facebook to go bankrupt?

Evgeny Chereshnev, CEO at Biolink.Tech told Express.co.uk that the worst could be yet to come for Facebook.

Mr Chereshnev said: "If those find more evidence on potential data use for tampering with presidential elections, Brexit and other cases of basically brainwashing people, we would potentially see the new low."

The CEO says that on March 16, Facebook stock was worth $185.02, today, March 28, it's 152.22.

He adds, "they've lost $32.8 in share prices, which is huge. They were $537.69 billion in capitalisation. Today it's $442.2 - which means they've lost $95.48 billion dollars in 2 weeks."

The worst-case scenario for the tech giant Mr Chereshnev warns is bankruptcy.

He said: "Trust in Facebook has been broken, and investors are dumping stock primarily because of that. There is too much at stake as it's now a potentially toxic asset due the information revealed by whistleblowers and the potential investigation results.

"If there is rock-hard proof and evidence that Facebook data has been used to influence Trump's election, the Brexit decision and many other political voting processes, Facebook could go bankrupt.

"The amount of legal cases and the dollar amounts of those, especially when GDPR law comes into effect, are potentially too high even for Facebook to handle. They are potentially unprecedented."

GETTY

Facebook in the spotlight: One CEO has warned that the fines could spell bankruptcy

12.35pm - UPDATE - Playboy deletes Facebook accounts

Playboy issued a press release late Tuesday night to announce its withdrawal from Facebook.

It said: "The recent news about Facebook's alleged mismanagement of users' data has solidified our decision to suspend our activity on the platform at this time.

"There are more than 25 million fans who engage with Playboy via our various Facebook pages, and we do not want to be complicit in exposing them to the reported practices."

Playboy is the latest company to #DeleteFacebook after the Cambridge Analytica scandal.

On Friday by Elon Musk removed Tesla and SpaceX pages from Zuckerberg's social media juggernaut.

219 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Guardian(London)


March 28, 2018 Wednesday 12:48 PM GMT 


Facebook announces privacy tools to 'put people in more control' of data;
Corporation suggests changes are response to Cambridge Analytica scandal, with EU set to toughen data protection rules in May


BYLINE: Alex Hern


SECTION: TECHNOLOGY; Version:1


LENGTH: 434 words


Facebook is launching a range of new tools in an effort to "put people in more control over their privacy" in the buildup to new EU regulations that tighten up data protection. 

The changes come after a troubling two weeks for the company, which is battling with the fallout of the Cambridge Analytica files. At least one of the new features, a unified privacy dashboard, was previously discussed by Facebook's chief operating officer, Sheryl Sandberg, back in January.

Facebook is not committing to making it any easier for users to delete their accounts wholesale

"The last week showed how much more work we need to do to enforce our policies, and to help people understand how Facebook works and the choices they have over their data," two Facebook executives wrote in a blogpost announcing the changes. "We've heard loud and clear that privacy settings and other important tools are too hard to find, and that we must do more to keep people informed."

Erin Egan, Facebook's chief privacy officer, and Ashlie Beringer, its deputy general counsel, continued: "Most of these updates have been in the works for some time, but the events of the past several days underscore their importance." The features will be available to all users, not just those in countries covered by the EU general data protection regulation (GDPR), which comes into effect on 25 May.

On mobile devices, Facebook users will now be able to find all their settings in a single place, rather than spread across "nearly 20 different screens" as they were before. They will also be able to find a separate item, the "privacy shortcuts" menu, which provides a clearing house for options about data protection, ad personalisation and on-platform privacy.

The site is also complying with rules about access to stored personal data with a new "access your information" tool, that allows people to find, download and delete Facebook data.

Related: Jeremy Deller distributes posters instructing how to delete Facebook

But Facebook is not committing to making it any easier for users to delete their accounts wholesale. The option to permanently delete an account is currently buried in a help menu, deprioritised in favour of the non-destructive option to "deactivate" a user account, which leaves all the data on Facebook's servers and accessible to the company's data-mining tools.

Facebook says that further changes will come in response to user feedback, including updates to the terms of service and data policies. "These updates are about transparency," Egan and Beringer write, "not about gaining new rights to collect, use, or share data."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBGNS

The Independent (United Kingdom)


March 28, 2018 Wednesday 1:06 PM GMT 


Facebook introduces new tools to let people delete and see their data as scandal continues


BYLINE: Andrew Griffin


SECTION: NEWS; Version:4


LENGTH: 460 words


Facebook will give people new ways of seeing and deleting the data it collects on its users, it has said.

The latest development comes as the social network continues to try and stop the damage from the Cambridge Analytica scandal, through which it became clear that the site was collecting many of its users' most sensitive and personal information. 

Now it says it will add new features in the next few weeks that will change the site's terms of service and its data policy so that people can see how their data is being collected. It will also give people new ways of deleting what has been collected and stopping further information being harvested, it claimed.

Those tools will allow people to delete data selectively, as well as removing their account entirely, Facebook's announcement appeared to suggest.

"Some people want to delete things they've shared in the past, while others are just curious about the information Facebook has," it wrote. "So we're introducing Access Your Information - a secure way for people to access and manage their information, such as posts, reactions, comments, and things you've searched for. You can go here to delete anything from your timeline or profile that you no longer want on Facebook."

Some of those new features are required by GDPR, the new data regulation being introduced by the EU in May that could hit companies such as Facebook.

More changes will be announcedin the coming weeks, Facebook said in the blog post, which was titled It's Time to Make Our Privacy Tools Easier to Find.

The company has faced a global outcry after a whistleblower said that data from millions of users was improperly harvested by consultancy Cambridge Analytica to target USand British voters in close-run elections.

Read more

Facebook admits collecting data on phone calls, but says people agreed

Facebookshares are down nearly 18 per cent since 16 March, when it first acknowledged that user data had been improperly channelled to Cambridge Analytica, eating away nearly $100bn(£71bn)of the company's market value.

"We've heard loud and clear that privacy settings and other important tools are too hard to find, and that we must do more to keep people informed," Erin Egan,Facebook's chief privacy officer, and Ashlie Beringer, its deputy general counsel, said in a statement.

In addition to redesigning its settings menu on mobile devices,Facebooksaid it is creating a new privacy shortcut menu where users would be able to better secure their accounts and control personal information. It would also allow users to review and delete data they have shared, including posts and search queries.

Users would be able to download the data shared withFacebook, including uploaded photos, contacts added to their accountand posts on timelines.

221 of 413 DOCUMENTS




telegraph.co.uk


March 28, 2018 Wednesday 11:00 AM GMT 


Facebook privacy overhaul lets users permanently delete their old posts and comments


BYLINE: By James Titcomb


SECTION: TECHNOLOGY INTELLIGENCE; Version:1


LENGTH: 476 words


Facebook is making it easier for users to permanently delete data, amid a swirling privacy row over the information it collects.

The social network said it would introduce a new tool that lets members find the information currently held by the website and download their own copy or destroy it. The feature will also allow users to port information to another social media site if they wish to leave Facebook. 

Facebook previously allowed users to delete information, but the process was onerous and required sleuthing through their histories. 

The changes are designed to comply with strict new European privacy laws and were not introduced in response to a user backlash over data following the Cambridge Analytica controversy.

Facebook's chief privacy officer Erin Egan  admitted that it is currently too difficult for users to stay on top of their privacy. "The last week showed how much more work we need to do to enforce our policies, and to help people understand how Facebook works and the choices they have over their data," she said.  "We've heard loud and clear that privacy settings and other important tools are too hard to find, and that we must do more to keep people informed.

On Wednesday, Facebook said it had completely redesigned the settings on its smartphone app to make it easier to control what information is being shared with other users and what adverts users see. The changes are designed to replace 20 different privacy pages with one. However, the changes only apply to the mobile app, not the Facebook website.

It is also introducing a way for users to see in one place all the personal data Facebook holds on them, such as statuses they have liked, posts and comments, and delete them individually or in bulk. The data will be deleted from accounts immediately, and from the social network within 90 days.

Alternatively, users will be able to download all the data and send it to another social network. Under the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), new EU rules that are being mirrored in UK legislation, social networks will have to allow their data to be transferred to a rival, an attempt to encourage competition.

Facebook members are currently allowed to download their data, but the process is onerous and means it is received in a complicated format.

Technology intelligence - newsletter promo - EOA

Ms Egan said the settings would prove that "it's your data, after all", following a week in which Facebook has been accused of failing to protect its users after it emerged that information about 50m users had been harvested and obtained by election consultants Cambridge Analytica.

Facebook said it would introduce the changes in the coming weeks, ahead of a May 25 deadline to comply with GDPR. It will also be changing its terms of service and data policy to comply with the new law.

The Guardian(London)

Corrections and clarifications;
Tate female artists


BYLINE: Corrections and clarifications column editor

· An interview said that with the Tate's purchase of Missionary Position II in 1987, Sonia Boyce became the first black female artist and the fifth female artist to enter the collection. While the first statement is correct, Tate had 212 female artists by the end of 1986 ( 'The anger and vitriol were really unhealthy', 20 March, page 8, G2).

GDPR: the new data-protection law giving watchdogs a mega bite

Experience: I had a date with a serial killer

223 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Times (London)


March 26, 2018 Monday  
Edition 1;
National Edition


Facebook scandal rocks the foundation of tech start-ups;
Businesses that rely on easy access to information from big data holders such as social media face new rules and changed attitudes, reports James Hurley GOING FOR GROWTH


BYLINE: James Hurley


SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 44,45


LENGTH: 1423 words


Anyone working with technology start-ups in recent years would have struggled to avoid hearing founders talk proudly about how the exploitation of data sat at the heart of their business models.

Trying to get them to speak up after revelations that information concerning 50 million Facebook users was wrongfully "harvested" by Cambridge Analytica, a data analysis company, was a trickier proposition.

"Many of them are preferring to duck the issue," one experienced technology industry consultant says.

A paradigm of the technology industry in recent years has been the notion that "data is the new oil". 

Technology giants, including Facebook, have made fortunes from convincing people to give away a precious resource - their personal information - in return for little more than access to their platforms.

The information can be exploited by advertisers and other businesses and, as a result, even after a week from hell, the social networking giant is still worth $463 billion.

Below mammoth data collectors such as Facebook sits a vast ecosystem of businesses that relies on the information they hold to inform, grow and provide a stamp of authenticity for their own services.

Everything from dating apps to fitness tracking services access Facebook data via its "application programming interface" (API), a software tool that allows third parties to access websites' user information.

Then there are the countless technology start-ups operating independently of Facebook that share their view of the value of user data.

There's nothing new in the idea of businesses exploiting data, but technology provides user data at a speed, scale and a level of detail that can make more traditional methods look like a blunt tool.

Vast quantities of venture capital can be used to subsidise a start-up service that operates in the belief that the data it collects on users will make them a fortune when they allow third parties to access it. A start-up mobile banking business, for example, might offer a subsidised service to win users in the belief that once it reaches scale third-party financial services will pay for access to its customers.

Those willing to discuss what the Facebook scandal means for start-ups are divided over the implications. If data is the new oil, is the value of those intimate details of our lives that we put online over the past decade or so dawning on us at last? Signal Media is a venture capitalbacked business that uses technology to monitor the authenticity of media data, allowing customers to filter out "fake news". David Benigson, its founder and chief executive, says people have been waking up to the "value, use and misuse" of their personal data and the attention on the issue in recent weeks has "supercharged" those concerns.

Technology giants have been the conduit for many businesses to convince people to part with their data and Mr Benigson says that game may be up. "People will now be significantly more wary of handing out personal data online and we will probably see more restrictive regulation over the next couple of years. This makes it much harder for new companies in the data/tech space to move forward from both an infrastructure perspective and as a consumer tool. Without a trusted brand, who will willingly give their data to a start-up, where security will probably be less impressive? "Firms will now be much clearer about what they use data for and how they store and manage [it]. I just hope that innovation is not a casualty along the way."

Eileen Burbidge, a partner at Passion Capital, a venture capital investor, and a government adviser, is not convinced the fallout will be so profound. "Data harvesting is pretty common and a valuable tool that businesses use to provide and deliver more relevant products and services. That is here to stay. The vast majority do not overstep the mark."

She says tougher regulations are needed governing how data harvesting is used to influence elections - which is the essence of the Cambridge Analytica controversy - along with greater transparency from businesses over data use but she doesn't believe the genie can be squeezed back into the bottle.

"I think consumers are going to get less sensitive about their data. If data had been shared with Amazon for clothing sizes [instead of Cambridge Analytica] there wouldn't have been the same uproar [even if] the violations of the terms were the same."

The Facebook scandal coincides with the introduction of new rules governing how all companies in the European Union handle data.The general data protection regulation (GDPR), which emanates from Brussels, is designed to hand control of personal data to individuals rather than organisations.

From May 25, everyone from global technology giants to banks to startups will need consent to process consumers' personal data. Consent must be "freely given". People must have signalled their willingness to share their data, not via a prepopulated tick box.

Companies will be required to obtain an unequivocal "positive indication of agreement" to personal data being processed. Silence will no longer count as consent.

Personal data includes names, photos, email addresses, bank details, posts on social networking websites, medical information and computer IP addresses.

Organisations that fail to comply can be fined up to 4 per cent of their annual global turnover, or (EURO)20 million, whichever is larger.

Ms Burbidge thinks the rules are "positive" and will be sufficient in most areas to boost transparency.

Nic Brisbourne, managing partner at Forward Partners, a backer of early-stage businesses, believes the soul-searching over the Facebook data breach points to a more significant moment.

"This issue is bigger than Facebook and my view is we are part way into a long-term trend of increasing regulation of the use of data. We are seeing start-ups' customers and investors starting to ask for evidence of GDPR compliance as a precondition for doing business and I expect to see the frequency and comprehensiveness of those checks to increase."

Call for 'sensible ground rules' to define use and abuse of data Ian Smith is chief executive and founder of Gospel Technology, a London-based start-up that helps businesses to share and monitor data safely using blockchain, the distributed ledger technology that also underpins cryptocurrencies such as bitcoin (James Hurley writes).

He says the debate that has been prompted by the Facebook scandal signals a sea-change in how companies will look after data. "This is huge. Start-ups have been relying on an effectively unregulated space for access to data."

While the intent hasn't always been malicious, he believes there have been "lies, deception and subterfuge" as organisations have raced to mine user data. "It may often be perfectly legal, but the effort with which some companies avoid being transparent about how they use our data reveals an uncomfortable moral landscape."

Last week Andrew Bailey, chief executive of the Financial Conduct Authority, hinted that tougher rules may be needed so that non-financial companies are held to the same standards over data misuse as City firms.

The Information Commissioner's Office is the UK data regulator that can issue fines, warnings and data processing bans for those who breach information rules, but speaking to an audience of financial technology start-ups and investors, Mr Bailey appeared to suggest greater powers may be needed to regulate technology firms.

"We don't regulate on the space in the news [Facebook and Cambridge Analytica] but generically there's a similar issue, which is, from a public interest perspective and a public policy perspective, what are the sensible rules for using data given that one of the things that ... innovation enables is unlocking access to data on a scale that never happened previously?

"We can't stand in the way of the fact that putting data to use is one of the rapidly growing powers within society Consumers want the benefit of it. Sometimes, we are all surprised to find out some of the things that have been going on." He added: "Some people are saying you've got to get regulation in there, others are saying that would be terrible because it would kill innovation. I think the solution is to say you need to come up with sensible ground rules.

"Some of the different [regulatory] regimes have very different approaches to how you regulate things, some are more restrictive than others. That merits examination of what is the sensible and better way."

A "transparent debate" was needed, Mr Bailey said.


LOAD-DATE: March 26, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Issues raised by Cambridge Analytica's actions "signal a sea-change"FRANCESCO GUIDICINI/SUNDAY TIMESEileen Burbidge of Passion Capital saystougher rules are needed on how data harvesting is used to influence elections. Mark Zuckerberg, below, admitted Facebook had made mistakes


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: TIM



Copyright 2018 Times Newspapers Limited
All Rights Reserved


224 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Times (London)


March 26, 2018 Monday  
Edition 2;
National Edition


Facebook scandal rocks the foundation of tech start-ups;
Businesses that rely on easy access to information from big data holders such as social media face new rules and changed attitudes, reports James Hurley GOING FOR GROWTH


BYLINE: James Hurley


SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 44,45


LENGTH: 1424 words


Anyone working with technology start-ups in recent years would have struggled to avoid hearing founders talk proudly about how the exploitation of data sat at the heart of their business models.

Trying to get them to speak up after revelations that information concerning 50 million Facebook users was wrongfully "harvested" by Cambridge Analytica, a data analysis company, was a trickier proposition.

"Many of them are preferring to duck the issue," one experienced technology industry consultant says.

A paradigm of the technology industry in recent years has been the notion that "data is the new oil". 

Technology giants, including Facebook, have made fortunes from convincing people to give away a precious resource - their personal information - in return for little more than access to their platforms.

The information can be exploited by advertisers and other businesses and, as a result, even after a week from hell, the social networking giant is still worth $463 billion.

Below mammoth data collectors such as Facebook sits a vast ecosystem of businesses that relies on the information they hold to inform, grow and provide a stamp of authenticity for their own services.

Everything from dating apps to fitness tracking services access Facebook data via its "application programming interface" (API), a software tool that allows third parties to access websites' user information.

Then there are the countless technology start-ups operating independently of Facebook that share their view of the value of user data.

There's nothing new in the idea of businesses exploiting data, but technology provides user data at a speed, scale and a level of detail that can make more traditional methods look like a blunt tool.

Vast quantities of venture capital can be used to subsidise a start-up service that operates in the belief that the data it collects on users will make them a fortune when they allow third parties to access it. A start-up mobile banking business, for example, might offer a subsidised service to win users in the belief that once it reaches scale third-party financial services will pay for access to its customers.

Those willing to discuss what the Facebook scandal means for start-ups are divided over the implications. If data is the new oil, is the value of those intimate details of our lives that we put online over the past decade or so dawning on us at last? Signal Media is a venture capitalbacked business that uses technology to monitor the authenticity of media data, allowing customers to filter out "fake news". David Benigson, its founder and chief executive, says people have been waking up to the "value, use and misuse" of their personal data and the attention on the issue in recent weeks has "supercharged" those concerns.

Technology giants have been the conduit for many businesses to convince people to part with their data and Mr Benigson says that game may be up. "People will now be significantly more wary of handing out personal data online and we will probably see more restrictive regulation over the next couple of years. This makes it much harder for new companies in the data/tech space to move forward from both an infrastructure perspective and as a consumer tool. Without a trusted brand, who will willingly give their data to a start-up, where security will probably be less impressive? "Firms will now be much clearer about what they use data for and how they store and manage [it]. I just hope that innovation is not a casualty along the way."

Eileen Burbidge, a partner at Passion Capital, a venture capital investor, and a government adviser, is not convinced the fallout will be so profound. "Data harvesting is pretty common and a valuable tool that businesses use to provide and deliver more relevant products and services. That is here to stay. The vast majority do not overstep the mark."

She says tougher regulations are needed governing how data harvesting is used to influence elections - which is the essence of the Cambridge Analytica controversy - along with greater transparency from businesses over data use but she doesn't believe the genie can be squeezed back into the bottle.

"I think consumers are going to get less sensitive about their data. If data had been shared with Amazon for clothing sizes [instead of Cambridge Analytica] there wouldn't have been the same uproar [even if] the violations of the terms were the same."

The Facebook scandal coincides with the introduction of new rules governing how all companies in the European Union handle data.The general data protection regulation (GDPR), which emanates from Brussels, is designed to hand control of personal data to individuals rather than organisations.

From May 25, everyone from global technology giants to banks to startups will need consent to process consumers' personal data. Consent must be "freely given". People must have signalled their willingness to share their data, not via a prepopulated tick box.

Companies will be required to obtain an unequivocal "positive indication of agreement" to personal data being processed. Silence will no longer count as consent.

Personal data includes names, photos, email addresses, bank details, posts on social networking websites, medical information and computer IP addresses.

Organisations that fail to comply can be fined up to 4 per cent of their annual global turnover, or (EURO)20 million, whichever is larger.

Ms Burbidge thinks the rules are "positive" and will be sufficient in most areas to boost transparency.

Nic Brisbourne, managing partner at Forward Partners, a backer of early-stage businesses, believes the soul-searching over the Facebook data breach points to a more significant moment.

"This issue is bigger than Facebook and my view is we are part way into a long-term trend of increasing regulation of the use of data. We are seeing start-ups' customers and investors starting to ask for evidence of GDPR compliance as a precondition for doing business and I expect to see the frequency and comprehensiveness of those checks to increase."

Call for 'sensible ground rules' to define use and abuse of data Ian Smith is chief executive and founder of Gospel Technology, a London-based start-up that helps businesses to share and monitor data safely using blockchain, the distributed ledger technology that also underpins cryptocurrencies such as bitcoin (James Hurley writes).

He says the debate that has been prompted by the Facebook scandal signals a sea-change in how companies will look after data. "This is huge. Start-ups have been relying on an effectively unregulated space for access to data."

While the intent hasn't always been malicious, he believes there have been "lies, deception and subterfuge" as organisations have raced to mine user data. "It may often be perfectly legal, but the effort with which some companies avoid being transparent about how they use our data reveals an uncomfortable moral landscape."

Last week Andrew Bailey, chief executive of the Financial Conduct Authority, hinted that tougher rules may be needed so that non-financial companies are held to the same standards over data misuse as City firms.

The Information Commissioner's Office is the UK data regulator that can issue fines, warnings and data processing bans for those who breach information rules, but speaking to an audience of financial technology start-ups and investors, Mr Bailey appeared to suggest greater powers may be needed to regulate technology firms.

"We don't regulate on the space in the news [Facebook and Cambridge Analytica] but generically there's a similar issue, which is, from a public interest perspective and a public policy perspective, what are the sensible rules for using data given that one of the things that ... innovation enables is unlocking access to data on a scale that never happened previously? "We can't stand in the way of the fact that putting data to use is one of the rapidly growing powers within society. Consumers want the benefit of it. Sometimes, we are all surprised to find out some of the things that have been going on." He added: "Some people are saying you've got to get regulation in there, others are saying that would be terrible because it would kill innovation. I think the solution is to say you need to come up with sensible ground rules.

"Some of the different [regulatory] regimes have very different approaches to how you regulate things, some are more restrictive than others. That merits examination of what is the sensible and better way."

A "transparent debate" was needed, Mr Bailey said.

March 26, 2018 Monday  
Edition 1;
Scotland


Facebook scandal rocks the foundation of tech start-ups;
Businesses that rely on easy access to information from big data holders such as social media face new rules and changed attitudes, reports James Hurley GOING FOR GROWTH


BYLINE: James Hurley


SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 44,45


LENGTH: 1424 words


Anyone working with technology start-ups in recent years would have struggled to avoid hearing founders talk proudly about how the exploitation of data sat at the heart of their business models.

Trying to get them to speak up after revelations that information concerning 50 million Facebook users was wrongfully "harvested" by Cambridge Analytica, a data analysis company, was a trickier proposition.

"Many of them are preferring to duck the issue," one experienced technology industry consultant says.

A paradigm of the technology industry in recent years has been the notion that "data is the new oil". 

Technology giants, including Facebook, have made fortunes from convincing people to give away a precious resource - their personal information - in return for little more than access to their platforms.

The information can be exploited by advertisers and other businesses and, as a result, even after a week from hell, the social networking giant is still worth $463 billion.

Then there are the countless technology start-ups operating independently of Facebook that share their view of the value of user data.

There's nothing new in the idea of businesses exploiting data, but technology provides user data at a speed, scale and a level of detail that can make more traditional methods look like a blunt tool.

Vast quantities of venture capital can be used to subsidise a start-up service that operates in the belief that the data it collects on users will make them a fortune when they allow third parties to access it. A start-up mobile banking business, for example, might offer a subsidised service to win users in the belief that once it reaches scale third-party financial services will pay for access to its customers.

Those willing to discuss what the Facebook scandal means for start-ups are divided over the implications. If data is the new oil, is the value of those intimate details of our lives that we put online over the past decade or so dawning on us at last? Signal Media is a venture capitalbacked business that uses technology to monitor the authenticity of media data, allowing customers to filter out "fake news". David Benigson, its founder and chief executive, says people have been waking up to the "value, use and misuse" of their personal data and the attention on the issue in recent weeks has "supercharged" those concerns.

Technology giants have been the conduit for many businesses to convince people to part with their data and Mr Benigson says that game may be up. "People will now be significantly more wary of handing out personal data online and we will probably see more restrictive regulation over the next couple of years. This makes it much harder for new companies in the data/tech space to move forward from both an infrastructure perspective and as a consumer tool. Without a trusted brand, who will willingly give their data to a start-up, where security will probably be less impressive? "Firms will now be much clearer about what they use data for and how they store and manage [it]. I just hope that innovation is not a casualty along the way."

Eileen Burbidge, a partner at Passion Capital, a venture capital investor, and a government adviser, is not convinced the fallout will be so profound. "Data harvesting is pretty common and a valuable tool that businesses use to provide and deliver more relevant products and services. That is here to stay. The vast majority do not overstep the mark."

She says tougher regulations are needed governing how data harvesting is used to influence elections - which is the essence of the Cambridge Analytica controversy - along with greater transparency from businesses over data use but she doesn't believe the genie can be squeezed back into the bottle.

"I think consumers are going to get less sensitive about their data. If data had been shared with Amazon for clothing sizes [instead of Cambridge Analytica] there wouldn't have been the same uproar [even if] the violations of the terms were the same."

The Facebook scandal coincides with the introduction of new rules governing how all companies in the European Union handle data.The general data protection regulation (GDPR), which emanates from Brussels, is designed to hand control of personal data to individuals rather than organisations.

From May 25, everyone from global technology giants to banks to startups will need consent to process consumers' personal data. Consent must be "freely given". People must have signalled their willingness to share their data, not via a prepopulated tick box.

Companies will be required to obtain an unequivocal "positive indication of agreement" to personal data being processed. Silence will no longer count as consent.

Personal data includes names, photos, email addresses, bank details, posts on social networking websites, medical information and computer IP addresses.

Organisations that fail to comply can be fined up to 4 per cent of their annual global turnover, or (EURO)20 million, whichever is larger.

Ms Burbidge thinks the rules are "positive" and will be sufficient in most areas to boost transparency.

Nic Brisbourne, managing partner at Forward Partners, a backer of early-stage businesses, believes the soul-searching over the Facebook data breach points to a more significant moment.

"This issue is bigger than Facebook and my view is we are part way into a long-term trend of increasing regulation of the use of data. We are seeing start-ups' customers and investors starting to ask for evidence of GDPR compliance as a precondition for doing business and I expect to see the frequency and comprehensiveness of those checks to increase."

Call for 'sensible ground rules' to define use and abuse of data Ian Smith is chief executive and founder of Gospel Technology, a London-based start-up that helps businesses to share and monitor data safely using blockchain, the distributed ledger technology that also underpins cryptocurrencies such as bitcoin (James Hurley writes).

He says the debate that has been prompted by the Facebook scandal signals a sea-change in how companies will look after data. "This is huge. Start-ups have been relying on an effectively unregulated space for access to data."

While the intent hasn't always been malicious, he believes there have been "lies, deception and subterfuge" as organisations have raced to mine user data. "It may often be perfectly legal, but the effort with which some companies avoid being transparent about how they use our data reveals an uncomfortable moral landscape."

Last week Andrew Bailey, chief executive of the Financial Conduct Authority, hinted that tougher rules may be needed so that non-financial companies are held to the same standards over data misuse as City firms.

The Information Commissioner's Office is the UK data regulator that can issue fines, warnings and data processing bans for those who breach information rules, but speaking to an audience of financial technology start-ups and investors, Mr Bailey appeared to suggest greater powers may be needed to regulate technology firms.

"We don't regulate on the space in the news [Facebook and Cambridge Analytica] but generically there's a similar issue, which is, from a public interest perspective and a public policy perspective, what are the sensible rules for using data given that one of the things that ... innovation enables is unlocking access to data on a scale that never happened previously? "We can't stand in the way of the fact that putting data to use is one of the rapidly growing powers within society Consumers want the benefit of it. Sometimes, we are all surprised to find out some of the things that have been going on." He added: "Some people are saying you've got to get regulation in there, others are saying that would be terrible because it would kill innovation. I think the solution is to say you need to come up with sensible ground rules.

"Some of the different [regulatory] regimes have very different approaches to how you regulate things, some are more restrictive than others. That merits examination of what is the sensible and better way."

A "transparent debate" was needed, Mr Bailey said.

GRAPHIC: Issues raised by Cambridge Analytica's actions "signal a sea-change"FRANCESCO GUIDICINI/SUNDAY TIMESEileen Burbidge of Passion Capital saystougher rules are needed on how data harvesting is used to influence elections. Mark Zuckerberg, below, admitted Facebook had made mistakes


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: TIM



Copyright 2018 Times Newspapers Limited
All Rights Reserved


226 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Sunday Telegraph (London)


March 25, 2018  
Edition 1;
National Edition


Will this be Silicon Valley's 'financial crisis' moment?;
Millions were happy to share personal details so they could play apps, but after the Cambridge Analytica scandal it's not a game any more, finds James Titcomb


BYLINE: James Titcomb


SECTION: BUSINESS AND MONEY;BUSINESS; Pg. 6,7


LENGTH: 1698 words


There is a puzzling thing about the tidal wave of criticism that hit Facebook last week. It was not the company's crashing share price, or the spike in people googling "delete Facebook" that came with it. Nor was it the five days that it took Mark Zuckerberg to personally respond to the crisis, strange as the chief executive's silence was.

The curious thing was instead that many of the allegations levelled at the social networking giant were far from new. Facebook first faced accusations that it was failing to protect users' data in 2015, when newspaper reports emerged that a shadowy British data firm called Cambridge Analytica had harvested information from millions of profiles without their knowledge.

Back then few people had heard of the obscure analytics company, which had been tasked with boosting Ted Cruz's ultimately unsuccessful presidential campaign. 

The claims were as serious as many of those made last week. But the story failed to reverberate around the world, nor did it cost the social network almost $60bn (£42bn). The crucial difference is that while the facts have not changed, the world has.

There are two important new factors. The first is that after Cruz's defeat in the Republican primaries, Cambridge Analytica struck up a relationship with Donald Trump, whose victory in the 2016 presidential election has invited near-constant allegations of impropriety.

The second is much more fundamental, and its ripples will be felt long after Trump leaves the White House: the world is becoming more anxious about the way its data is constantly collected, manipulated, and exploited.

The string of cyber attacks that have seen billions of people's personal information stolen in recent years, combined with a growing distrust of Silicon Valley's internet giants and their creeping presence on everyday life, has been stoking tensions about data for months before last week's scandal. All it needed was one moment to trigger an eruption. Years from now, it may be remembered as Silicon Valley's "financial crisis" moment.

The story of Facebook's Cambridge Analytica scandal begins in 2007, when Mark Zuckerberg's social media giant launched what it called the "Facebook Platform". The feature allowed developers to create applications that would be linked to Facebook, such as games, quizzes and online accounts. The iPhone had yet to be released and online privacy was a concept that troubled few people - Facebook users would happily carry out entire conversations on each other's pages, which were often visible to the general public.

As Facebook grew, the number of apps that could connect to users' accounts and read their data grew with it. By 2012, there were 9m, and some of these, such as Farmville and Mafia Wars, had tens of millions of users. Around one in 10 apps were not only able to read the personal data of the people that had installed them, such as names, status updates and what pages they had liked, but also similar data about their Facebook friends. By reading friends' information, an app installed by just one person could harvest the data of hundreds.

"We thought that every app could be social," Andrew Bosworth, a senior Facebook executive who has been with the company since 2006, said last week. "Your calendar should have your events and your friends' birthdays, your maps should know where your friends live, your address book should show their pictures."

The startling thing is that this was not viewed as strange at the time.

Max Schrems, an Austrian privacy campaigner who has spent years challenging Facebook, said: "Any app could pull all this data, there is no control over it whatsoever, and people agreed to it. Now they claim they have been betrayed and lied to. It's absurd."

In 2014, in response to privacy concerns, Facebook announced that it would stop apps getting access. But the damage had been done. Before Facebook blocked apps from accessing friends' data, around 270,000 people downloaded thisisyourdigitallife, a personality-testing app developed by Aleksandr Kogan, a Cambridge University academic.

The power of Facebook's friend network had meant the app was able to gather data on some 50m users. Against Facebook's rules, which prohibited apps from passing on the information they had gathered, these details were then handed to Cambridge Analytica, which allegedly used them to run a sophisticated psychological advert targeting campaign that helped deliver Trump to the White House.

Experts disagree about how true these dark arts are. Researchers have claimed that people's personalities can be determined using minor amounts of Facebook information - users who press "like" on the page of reality TV star Kim Kardashian, for example, are extroverts. Listing "cooking" as an interest is a sign one is conscientious.

These personality traits can then supposedly be used to show people customised online adverts that they will be most receptive to. A study last year found that psychological microtargeting made users 50pc more likely to buy something from an online advert.

Others deride this idea as pseudoscience, and say nobody would believe in Cambridge Analytica's methods were it not for many people looking for a way to dismiss the legitimacy of Donald Trump's election victory.

What was undoubtedly real was Facebook being thrown into crisis last week. Nine days ago it announced that it had suspended Cambridge Analytica, after discovering that the British firm had failed to delete the data when ordered to in 2015. This was followed by allegations from whistleblowers that the company had effectively no control over how data about its users was shared, leading the scandal to widen.

Sandy Parakilas, an operations manager at Facebook between 2011 and 2012, told MPs on the Commons digital, culture, media and sport (DCMS) committee last week that "personal data was basically allowed to leave Facebook" and that the company had never physically audited a developer that took data from it.

Damian Collins, the committee chairman, said the company had "turned a blind eye because it didn't want to find out the truth".

Facebook's shares fell 11pc in four days, wiping $60bn off the company's share price. Mr Zuckerberg's personal wealth fell by $8bn, relegating him to merely the fifth richest person in the world behind clothing tycoon Amancio Ortega.

Facebook has been through no shortage of scandals before. In the last year alone it has been buffeted by fake news allegations, claims that its addictive nature is harming mental health and of failing to combat terrorism on the site. But none of this appeared to affect the company's inexorable rise.

It signed up 269m new users last year, a period during which its shares rose 53pc, and profits almost doubled, from $10.2bn to $18.2bn.

Last week was different. Facebook may not face many direct financial consequences from the Cambridge Analytica crisis. The UK's Information Commissioner, Elizabeth Denham, is investigating Facebook and Cambridge Analytica. She was a thorn in the side of the company when running British Columbia's data regulator, but the maximum fine she can impose is £500,000. America's Federal Trade Commission has greater powers if it judges that the company has broken the terms of a landmark 2011 agreement on data protection.

There may be greater consequences, not just for Facebook but for all data businesses. European laws coming into force in May known as the GDPR will give regulators the ability to fine companies up to 4pc of annual sales for data violations, £1.1bn in Facebook's case. Denham said last week that the regulator will soon have "sharper teeth". MPs have now called for the Information Commissioner to have beefed-up powers that allows it to raid companies. "This has shown the dark underbelly of data capture," says Julian Knight, an MP on the DCMS committee. "The relationship needs to turn from 'you are the producer' [of data] to 'you are the owner'."

"It was the week the world changed," says Jonathan Kewley, a data privacy lawyer at Clifford Chance.

Kewley says the past 20 years has seen a "data free-for-all" in which a generation of consumers have given away their information too freely, partly because the privacy violations of past totalitarian regimes have been forgotten. It may have needed an event such as last week's to remind the world why it was important.

"It's taken us a while to go back to the reality of why privacy is important," Kewley says.

Zuckerberg appeared to admit the world had changed last week when he finally broke his silence, several days after the story emerged.

"I am actually not sure we shouldn't be regulated," he said. He may get his wish.

Combative commissioner Teeth sharpened

Elizabeth Denham's investigation into how data from Facebook and elsewhere may have been misused for political purposes is not the first time the Information Commissioner has tangled with the social media giant.

Until she was appointed as the UK's top data regulator in 2016, the Canadian ran British Columbia's data regulator, as well as serving as Canada's assistant privacy commissioner, where she pursued Facebook over claims it was sharing users' data with third-party apps without consent, and that it held on to data even after people had deleted their accounts.

Since arriving in the UK she has also challenged Facebook after the social media giant began to share data between the social network and WhatsApp, the messaging app it acquired in 2014.

It led Facebook to stop sharing certain data between the two apps and sign an agreement promising to keep the data separate.

Denham has used the full powers of her office in fining companies for data breaches, including a record £400,000 fine for TalkTalk after the telecoms operator's 2015 data breach.

She is now tasked with enforcing strict new data protection laws that give her more powers for fines.

$58bn value lost from Facebook's market cap

$8bn Zuckerberg's personal loss

£1.1bn potential Facebook fine under new law

2015 year it stopped sharing friend data with thirdparty apps

50m users whose data was compromised

5 Zuckerberg's days of silence

'Any app could pull all this data, there is no control over it whatsoever, and people agreed to it'


LOAD-DATE: March 25, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

227 of 413 DOCUMENTS



Sunday Express


March 25, 2018  
Edition 1;
National Edition


COMMENT


BYLINE: GEOFF HO


SECTION: FEATURES; Pg. 64


LENGTH: 238 words


FACEBOOK has enjoyed a meteoric rise since Mark Zuckerberg founded it in his Harvard University dormitory room in 2004, but I suspect that the unfettered growth it has enjoyed will soon end. 

The Cambridge Analytica data harvesting scandal has wiped more than $60 billion off the value of Facebook and could be the catalyst that prompts governments around the world to crack down on technology companies.

They could subject them to the same rules and regulations that traditional media groups are obliged to follow.

Facebook is free to use and makes serious amounts of money from advertising. How it does that is by taking all of your data, your age, date of birth, likes and dislikes, who your friends are, what you do online and so on, analysing it and using the results to help advertisers target specific groups.

Cambridge Analytica harvested the data of 50 million Facebook users, who were unaware that this was going on, and used that data to target them with political advertising. Naturally this has outraged politicians and privacy groups and led to Facebook being condemned for failing to protect its users' data.

Tough new restrictions on how companies store peoples' data, called GDPR, come into force in May in the UK and Europe. Do not be surprised if countries around the world in the weeks ahead go further and impose harsher restrictions on how Facebook and other technology companies use data. ? geoff.ho@express.co.uk


LOAD-DATE: March 25, 2018

mirror.co.uk


March 24, 2018 Saturday 3:02 PM GMT 


Should You Delete Your Facebook account? Privacy Expert Mark Weinstein answers your questions;
As Facebook hits the news again, with concerns over the data breach with Cambridge Analytica, we ask privacy expert Mark Weinstein if we should be worried and what happens next


BYLINE: By Jo-Anne Rowney


SECTION: TECHNOLOGY; Version:1


LENGTH: 874 words


Facebookhas endured a lot of backlash in the past few years due to the manipulation of the app and the role it may have played inBrexit's passing andAmerica's presidential election. With the tech company's involvement withCambridge Analytica, the cat is officially out of the bag.

What do Facebook's privacy infractions mean to you? Has your information been breached? 

Is Facebook safe any longer or was it ever? To answer these questions and others concerning Facebook selling personal information to Cambridge Analytica, I interviewed leading privacy advocate and CEO of MeWe, Mark Weinstein.

There is no way to use FB without giving up all your data. People forget or don't understand that Facebook is a "data" company and that is their true business. So even the facade of "privacy" settings on FB have absolutely nothing to do with their ability to spy on you and track everything you and your friends do. Facebook creates a data packet on you that may include 2,000+ points of information. And Facebook tracks their members across the Web - not just at Facebook but at thousands of sites. If a person wants privacy and data ownership - then Facebook is the wrong company to use.

Facebook is 'designed to exploit the brain and changes relationships', says man who helped create it

In the case of this Cambridge Analytica debacle, this is not a breach, not a hack, and not even an intrusion. This is Facebook being Facebook, selling data to anyone with the dollars to pay - think Russian election influence, etc. And in this case they sold personally identifiable data on 50-million members to supposed "researchers." Yes, this is actually a serious breach by Facebook of their privacy policy - and of course that cat is out of the box - the data has ended up in the most nefarious of hands, and now those members are the perfect manipulation target. This is downright scary.

This is the core of the Facebook data vacuum machine. These leaks of your data without your explicit permission are hard to contain because they have an immense data trove on everyone - and this data gold mine lives forever. It is your "permanent digital record."

Imagine that every single thing you do online is captured by some algorithm and eventually ends up in a huge data packet about you. This is your digital footprint - every search, every person you connect with, all conversations, all purchases, your politics, religion, relationships, everything. A person's digital footprint will soon become the most important personal data they manage.

People have been careless with their digital footprint because they didn't realize how pervasive and long-lasting the steps they've taken would become. People will want to get familiar with the phrase "permanent digital record."

This is what they are adding to with their digital footprint every time they post on Facebook or search on Google, etc., - because those companies watch and categorize everything you do. This will outlive you and likely in the future be discoverable by your employers, your significant others, schools, family members, friends, and more. Scary? Yes!

'Cambridge Analytica HQ evacuated' and surrounding area sent into lockdown amid reports of a suspicious package

The best defense is to immediately take yourself out of the Facebook data ecosystem. If you want true privacy then it's best to ditch Facebook. Facebook deletion is actually a very tricky process because they want your data regardless. Even when you delete your account they still serve your content that you posted previously in everyone's timeline that it was already posted.

And here's something really creepy - if you delete your Facebook account they still track you across the Web and they still maintain a data packet about you, what you do, who you talk to, what sites you visit, what topics you search, and much more.

Regardless, the absolute best strategy is to terminate Facebook's ability to spy on you, delete your account and just move on - and get a fresh start with a privacy centric site like MeWe or another site that blocks all intruding algorithms and doesn't sell data or serve ads.

Facebook

A: Just browsing the Web is now a bizarre experience because your ISP can spy on you and sell the data on everything you are doing - sites you are visiting, conversations you are having, purchases you are making, searches you are initiating. And Facebook is notorious for tracking both members and non-members alike across thousands of sites and aggregating what they learn into your permanent digital record for sale.

So, people are best to install a privacy browser like TOR, use search engines that don't track like DuckDuckGo, and use social media sites that have privacy-by-design built into their platform like we've done with MeWe, with barriers keeping out snooping ISPs, Google, bots, etc.

If history is the judge of how these data vacuums will behave under the auspices of GDPR, then we all should be very worried. Predictably, there will come a day when companies like Facebook and Google will have been discovered to have violated nearly every tenet of GDPR, all the while acting as though they'd complied. Uh oh!
