MailOnline


March 5, 2018 Monday 7:19 PM GMT 


Pornhub's AgeID age verification software to hit the UK soon


BYLINE: BEN RABINOVICH


SECTION: SCIENCE; Version:2


LENGTH: 727 words



  • •

    Pornhub parent company MindGeek has revealed its AgeID age-verification tool 

  • •

    The tool is designed to comply with new legislation that kicks in later this year 

  • •

    It is not yet clear how Pornhub's AgeID will work or how ages will be verified  

Pornhub recently attracted positive attention when it offered Philadelphia lubricant to grease the city's poles, in order to prevent Philadelphia Eagles fans climbing them during Super Bowl LII, and the pornography website is back in the news after it unveiled AgeID, its online age verification tool. 

AgeID was created by Pornhub's parent company Mindgeek, which also owns pornography websites YouPorn and Brazzers and is designed to adhere to the new rules set out in the Digital Economy Act 2017, which requires porn viewers to prove they are over the age of 18.

The British Board of Film Classification (BBFC) has been picked as the regulator and any company that fails to verify the age will be fined £250,000.

Here is all the information on Pornhub's new age verification tool including why and when it is being implemented, and how it works.

What is Pornhub's AgeID?

AgeID is designed to force people who watch porn to prove they over the age of 18 in the UK.   

It is reportedly going to be a one-time verification, meaning that once a person has their age confirmed via AgeID, any subsequent websites using the tool won't require another verification.

During the first time, UK users will be prompted to 'Verify my Age' and create a login profile that will work on all AgeID websites. 

Verifying age is reportedly going to require either a passport or a mobile number, with the information then being relayed to a 'government-appointed' service to confirm that it is accurate.

However, such a collection of data has made many people uneasy. Jim Killock, the Executive Director of the privacy group Open Rights Group said: 'The BBFC will struggle to ensure that Age Verification is safe, secure and anonymous. They are powerless to ensure people's privacy.

'The major publisher, MindGeek, looks like it will dominate the AV market. We are very worried about their product, AgeID, which could track people's porn use,' she added. 

However, MindGeek spokesman said: 'AgeID has been built from the ground up with data protection, data minimisation and the principles of privacy by design at its core, while also complying with the GDPR.'

The spokesman also confirmed that AgeID won't store any personal data entered during the 'age-verification process'.

'Due to the encrypted nature of AgeID's login credentials, such data cannot be exposed in the unlikely event of a hack,' he added.  

MindGeek is also reportedly expected to let third-party websites use its AgeID tool. 

When will Pornhub's AgeID be rolled out?

MindGeek was originally supposed to roll out the age verification tool in April, so as to conform to the new rules that will kick in that month with the implementation of the Digital Economy Act 2017.

However, in a press release about the country's Digital Strategy initiative dated March 10, the UK Government said the following: 'It is anticipated age verification will be enforceable by the end of the year.'

The reasoning was to give more time for the BBFC to draft guidance and for it to be subsequently cleared by Parliament.

'For the public and the industry to prepare for and comply with age verification, the Government will also ensure a period of up to three months after the BBFC guidance has been cleared by Parliament before the law comes into force.' 

What is the Digital Economy Act 2017?

The Digital Economy Act 2017 is wide-ranging legislation that covers everything from how the BBC is regulated to re-transmission fees and a legally-mandated broadband speed minimum.

However, a large part of the act is dedicated to pornography. The act mandates age-checks in order to prevent under-18s accessing pornographic material.

The act allows an 'age-verification regulator' - the BBFC - to require companies to provide it with 'any information which it requires for the purpose of exercising, or deciding whether to exercise' any of its functions, and to impose financial penalties.

The regulator will be allowed to force ISPs to block companies' websites that fail to comply with the legislation.

telegraph.co.uk


March 1, 2018 Thursday 12:01 AM GMT 


Facebook to target people with adverts based on their religion


BYLINE: By Margi Murphy


SECTION: TECHNOLOGY; Version:2


LENGTH: 760 words


Facebook will soon allow advertisers to target British users based on their religious or political views.

The changes will allow businesses to target - or block - groups of individuals based on the faith or sexuality they identify with in their profile, along posts they have liked and groups they are members of.

The move could raise concerns that radical groups may be able to pay to target certain political groups with recruitment propaganda, perpetuating extremism on the website. A Facebook spokesman said it had policies in place to remove any advertising that appeared to be maliciously profiling certain people. 

From today a small number of users will be prompted to check their information and will be advised that it could be used to target them with advertising. Only those who agree will be shown relevant marketing, like Christian-dating apps, for example.

The trial is part of a wider data privacy clean-up ahead of new data protection laws arriving in May that will particularly affect Facebook, along with companies like Google and marketing businesses.

The technology giant faces a maximum fine of $1.1bn (£777m) if found in breach of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which will look at how and why companies collect and retain data."For many years, people had ability to put political religious views and as a part of GDPR we will be asking people if they are happy for that information to be shared," said Rob Sherman, Facebook's privacy chief.

"For many years, people had ability to put political religious views and as a part of GDPR we will be asking people if they are happy for that information to be shared," said Rob Sherman, Facebook's privacy chief.

The company has previously made presumptions about someone's interested based on posts they like, but under EU regulations was not permitted to use information uploaded to their profile to target them with relevant services or adverts. 

The company has been able to target its American audience like this thanks to more lenient data protection rules in the US. But it garnered controversy when it emerged that Russians had been able to pay for anti-Democratic propaganda during the run up to the 2016 presidential election.

The practice has also been criticised by human rights activities. Undercover reporters at investigative website ProPublica last year revealed that Facebook could easily be gamed to racially discriminate. In one example journalists pretending to be a rental company were able to block certain ethnicities from seeing their adverts. Facebook later apologised. 

"Our existing ad policies prevent people from targeting ads which  discriminate against others," a Facebook spokesperson said.  "If we find an ad in violation our policies we will disapprove the ad and send messaging to the advertiser warning them of the violation. If we see egregious, malicious, or repeated violations of our policies, we will typically move to permanently ban the advertiser from running ads."

The social network said it will also bring  facial recognition technology to its European users as part of the trial. Around one per cent of its two billion audience will be given the option to start using the photo detection tool, which helps suggests tagging photos and can spot identity theft.

To do this, algorithms analyse the pixels in photos that a person is already tagged in and generate a string of numbers called a template. When photos and videos are uploaded to Facebook's systems, it compares those images to the template.  Although impressive, the technology  was not used in the EU because of a ban on processing of an individual's sensitive personal data without their explicit permission. By asking for explicit permission, Facebook can lawfully collect this information.

Mr Sherman is working to make sure the company, which controls the data of billions of its users, can prove that it has gathered explicit permission from everyone it makes money from their data on.

"We have taken very seriously the privacy concerns we have heard around facial recognition, but we think it is important to use technology that is valuable to people. We want to help enable beneficial uses [of facial recognition technology] while safeguarding against others," he said.

"We think that putting people in control this and being clear with people about technology, and people's choices, is an important part of this."

Last month chief operating officer Sheryl Sandberg announced a new privacy control portal that would help people better understand how their information is being used.

February 27, 2018 Tuesday

Hiscox profits fall 91pc after run of natural disasters bites;
Insurer left with $225m bill after last year's storms, hurricanes and wildfires 'battered balance sheets'


BYLINE: Lucy Burton


SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 4


LENGTH: 564 words


ANNUAL profits at Hiscox have plunged 91pc after the insurer had to pay out millions of pounds worth of claims following a record year of natural disasters.

The FTSE 250 insurer said the earthquakes, hurricanes and wildfires in the US, Caribbean and Mexico last year left it with a $225m (£160m) bill for claims and "battered insurers' balance sheets" around the world.

While its pre-tax profits nosedived from £354.5m in 2016 to £30.8m for the year to December, the specialist insurer said prices had finally risen on "catastrophe-exposed lines" such as property and casualty as a result of the losses. 

"The $140bn of catastrophe losses across the sector led to capital destruction and reserve deficits, and as a result the market is turning," said chairman Robert Childs. "This is not an immediate process; it comes about through each difficult conversation, each new quotation and each renewal."

However, chief executive Bronek Masojada said he had hoped prices would have risen more on big ticket policies following years of reductions, months after his counterpart at rival Beazley said the industry was preparing to up rates for the areas hit by the disasters. Further claims from catastrophes this year would mean that prices would likely rise even more.

Shares in Hiscox, which is one of just three Lloyd's of London insurers left listed in London, fell 2.1pc to £13.67 as investors digested news of the profit fall. Mr Masojada brushed off the drop, however.

"When people say, 'oh gosh you had lots of claims', we say, 'yep, that's why people buy them [our policies]'," he said. "When you make an insurance claim, you're expecting a cheque back."

Hiscox's London market business was most hit by the natural disasters, swinging from a profit of £44m in 2016 to a loss of £36.2m last year.

It said the division would return to growth due to the increase in rates but "not as much as originally expected" given the rate rises were not as strong as initially hoped.

Meanwhile, its US business stood as "the standout performer" of the year having "withstood the impact of the hurricanes well", the business said. Profit in its retail division - which covers homes, businesses, fine art and wealthy clients - dipped on last year but still exceeded £100m.

Looking ahead, Hiscox claimed that there was plenty of opportunity for growth and it would focus on building non-catastrophe lines such as cyber security, having hired former GCHQ chief Robert Hannigan late last year.

The insurance industry is under pressure to do more to help combat climate change as scientists warn that extreme weather could become the norm.

Last year was one of the worst ever for natural disasters, leaving insurers facing millions of pounds in claims and costing the industry as a whole more than £100bn. The storms were unusual for their extreme power, with US hurricane scientist Eric Blake tweeting that Hurricane Irma will go down as one of the most infamous in Atlantic hurricane history.

Natural disasters have not been the only area weighing on insurers in recent months, however.

"It's hard not to feel tormented by regulation," Mr Childs added. "We are working hard to navigate geopolitical issues such as Brexit, US tax reform, GDPR and New York's cyber security regulation.

"I'm sure I am not alone in appealing for some reprieve from the regulatory leapfrog while we deal with so many sizeable global issues."


LOAD-DATE: February 27, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Bronek Masojada, the chief executive of Hiscox, brushed off the news of the drop in profits at the insurer


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

Ireland


Watchdog warns Tusla after McCabe data error


BYLINE: Ed Carty


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 8


LENGTH: 464 words


The data watchdog has warned Tusla, the child and family agency, about its poor record-keeping after a false sex abuse allegation about Sergeant Maurice McCabe, the whistleblower. The Data Protection Commission (DPC) said the organisation did not properly plan for the processing of personal and sensitive data when it was set up almost four years ago. 

It began an inquiry into Tusla's personal data controls after it emerged in February last year that an unfounded rape allegation had been put on a file relating to Sergeant McCabe and circulated to gardaí three years earlier. Tusla apologised and the scandal was examined at the Disclosures Tribunal. The DPC did not specifically refer to the McCabe affair in its annual report. It said its inquiry started in March last year into the governance of personal data concerning child protection cases.

It said: "The processing of personal and sensitive data, in the context of file management and record keeping overall, was not sufficiently planned for in the form of a robust data governance strategy when Tusla was established in 2014, bringing together a considerable volume of casework and over 4,000 staff from three distinct agencies.

"It is critical that the casework management system deployed across all areas of Tusla generates a full and complete record of all casework material concerning each case to mitigate the risk that the system might give an inaccurate, incomplete or distorted view of each case. Evidence was identified in multiple and overlapping volumes of individual case files where no complete 'master file' could be identified, and with no audit trail in relation to the handling of the file."

The DPC carried out unannounced inspections in Tusla offices in Limerick, Tralee, Kilkenny, Drogheda, Navan, Churchtown, Portlaoise, and the Dublin headquarters. Tusla was issued with 59 findings by the commission in January and given two months to set out a plan of action.

In its annual report, the commission said that it received a record number of complaints - 2,642 - last year, compared with 1,479 in 2016. It dealt with a record 2,973 data breach notifications and 2,795 were classed as valid.

The watchdog said it expected to issue its first findings on its inquiries into the public services card before June. Helen Dixon, the data protection commissioner, said: "Cybersecurity must be a priority for all organisations to maintain integrity and confidentiality, particularly as this is one of the two new general principles of data protection introduced under the GDPR, Europe's general data protection regulation, and against which the higher level of fines will apply."

The DPC investigated 21 complaints on the "right to be forgotten". Six were upheld, 12 rejected and another three are still being examined.

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

telegraph.co.uk


February 26, 2018 Monday 1:53 PM GMT 


Hiscox profits crash 91pc after 'most costly year ever' for natural disasters


BYLINE: By Lucy Burton, Financial services editor


SECTION: BUSINESS; Version:3


LENGTH: 579 words


Profits at Hiscox have plunged 91pc after the insurer had to cough up millions of pounds worth of claims following a record year of natural disasters. 

The FTSE 250 insurer said the earthquakes, hurricanes and wildfires in the US, Caribbean and Mexico last year left it with a $225m (£160m) bill for claims and "battered insurers' balance sheets" around the world. 

While its pre-tax profits nosedived from £354.5m in 2016 to £30.8m for the year to December, the specialist insurer said prices on "catastrophe-exposed lines" such as property and casualty had risen as a result of the losses. 

"The $140bn (£100bn) of catastrophe losses across the sector led to capital destruction and reserve deficits, and as a result the market is turning," said chairman Robert Childs. "This is not an immediate process; it comes about through each difficult conversation, each new quotation and each renewal."  

However chief executive Bronek Masojada said he had hoped prices would rise even faster on big-ticket policies following years of reductions. His comment comes months after his counterpart at rival Beazley said the industry was preparing to hike rates for the areas hit by disasters. Further claims from catastrophes this year could mean that prices will rise even more. 

Shares in Hiscox, which is one of just three UK-listed Lloyd's of London insurers left, dipped on the announcement as investors digested news of the profit fall. Mr Masojada brushed off the drop, however. 

Hiscox

"When people say, 'oh gosh you had lots of claims', we say, 'yep, that's why people buy them [our policies]'," he said. "When you make an insurance claim, you're expecting a cheque back."  

Hiscox's London market business was most hit by the natural disasters, swinging from a profit of £44m in 2016 to a loss of £36.2m last year. It said the division would return to growth due to the increase in rates but "not as much as originally expected" given the rate rises were not as strong as initially hoped. 

Meanwhile its US business was "the standout performer" of the year having "withstood the impact of the hurricanes well", the company said. Profit in its retail division - which covers homes, businesses, fine art and wealthy clients - dipped on last year but still exceeded £100m.  

The insurer, which underwrites risks from terrorism to kidnappings, increased its dividend by 5.5pc to 29p a share. Looking ahead it said that there was plenty of opportunity for growth and it would focus on building non-catastrophe lines such as cyber security, having hired former GCHQ chief Robert Hannigan late last year. 

The insurance industry is under pressure to do more to help combat climate change . Last year was one of the worst ever for natural disasters, leaving insurers facing millions of pounds in claims and costing the industry as a whole more than £100bn. The storms were unusual for their extreme power, with US hurricane scientist Eric Blake noting that hurricane Irma would go down as one of the most infamous in Atlantic history. 

Natural disasters have not been the only area weighing on insurers in recent months, however. 

"It's hard not to feel tormented by regulation," Mr Childs said.

"We are working hard to navigate geopolitical issues such as Brexit, US tax reform, GDPR and New York's Cybersecurity regulation. I'm sure I am not alone in appealing for some reprieve from the regulatory leapfrog while we deal with so many sizable global issues."

The Sunday Times (London)


February 25, 2018 Sunday  
Edition 1;
Ireland


Safely crossing the boardroom divide;
Critical thinking, independence and networking skills are key to making the switch to non-executive positions, says Grainne Rothery


BYLINE: Grainne Rothery


SECTION: BUSINESS AND MONEY;BUSINESS; Pg. 11


LENGTH: 1079 words


Crossing over to the nonexecutive side of the boardroom table may seem like a natural progression for senior executives approaching the end of their careers, but for most it's a move that will require plenty of preplanning and preparation. Anyone considering working as a non-executive director should educate themselves - formally and informally - around corporate governance. "It's very onerous being a nonexecutive director, so you need to know exactly what you're taking on and you need to be fully knowledgeable of the legal requirements," said Thora Mackey, chief operating officer at the Institute of Directors in Ireland.

A good starting point is to get an understanding of the Companies Act 2014 and its implications for directors. For certain sectors - such as charities and financial services - it will be necessary to be aware of the specific regulatory environments. 

Having a background in the particular sector will not necessarily suffice. "You may be an executive in the financial services industry but not be looking at the board piece," said Mackey. "You do need to do that to familiarise yourself with the specifics around what board members need to know."

And, particularly topical is the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which will replace the existing data protection laws in the EU when it comes into effect on May 25. "Ultimately, the responsibility rests with the board for ensuring it's implemented and monitored," Mackey said.

An increasing number of directors and prospective directors - both executive and non-executive - are undertaking some kind of formal training, such as the Institute of Directors' chartered director programme, UCD's diploma in corporate governance, or the Irish Management Institute's diploma in governance and compliance.

A broad range of business knowledge outside an individual's particular speciality helps. Prospective board members should also look at developing soft skills such as good communications skills, critical thinking and the ability to challenge constructively. "Boards really need someone who's independent," said one seasoned director. "It can often be human nature to try to fit in. Your function is not to agree with the management all the time. You've got to challenge."

Some people have an advantage when it comes to catching the interest of prospective boards. "In the listed company sector, having been a senior manager in a big company is attractive," said Professor Niamh Brennan, academic director of the UCD Centre for Corporate Governance. "Having been a chief executive or chief financial officer definitely helps to land non-executive directorships."

According to Tony McPoland, who has a portfolio of 12 directorships, particular experience - such as finance, marketing and IT - can also be an advantage. "And I think anyone who has a background in compliance and regulatory affairs around GDPR would be snapped up at the moment," he said.

McPoland said his appointments have taken between three and 22 months to secure from having first conversations to receiving formal confirmation.

After being made redundant from his senior executive position in regulatory financial services, McPoland decided he wanted to have a series of part-time roles and consciously built up his portfolio of directorships. He started out with two non-executive roles on special purpose vehicles from his previous employer and did the Institute of Directors chartered director programme.

"I then spent the next two years drinking a lot of coffee and buying a lot of lunches telling people what I was doing," he said. "All my early roles came from my personal network."

His advice for anyone planning a nonexecutive career is to be prepared to get out and explain what you're doing.

"People are not going to ring you out of the blue," he said.

Another director noted that the informal approach is still quite prevalent among board appointments in private companies in Ireland.

"That probably smacks of the old boys' club," he said. "It is and it isn't. If I had a choice of three candidates and knew one of them and thought they might do the job well, it might short-circuit an interview process."

He stressed the importance of starting to develop networks early. "If you're starting to network at the end of your executive career, you're probably about 20 years too late," he said.

There is a view that starting out on a charity board is a good way of gaining experience. Brennan urges caution. "In that sector, money is always a problem so the risk of insolvency is greater," she said. "You do not want to be a director of an insolvent organisation. I would advise people to do their due diligence very, very carefully."

Mackey, meanwhile, said charities are very complex and the boards have to function very well.

Vacancies also come up quite regularly on state boards, but again Brennan urges caution. "Some of them are established by statute in a very dysfunctional manner," she said. "A state board is an opportunity to get governance experience, but be careful that you know what you're getting into."

All state board positions are advertised on www.Stateboards.ie. On the not-for-profit side, Boardmatch Ireland (www.boardmatchireland.ie) provides a free matching service for boards and prospective candidates. And members of the Institute of Directors in Ireland can register with the Boardroom Centre to potentially be matched to client companies. Typical pay for a non-executive in the funds industry is about (EURO)15,000 to (EURO)20,000 to prepare for, attend and do any necessary follow-up for four to six meetings per year.

Among listed companies, the rewards are significantly higher. In Glanbia, for example, non-executive directors earned (EURO)70,000 in 2017. In 2015, AIB paid its non-executive directors a minimum of (EURO)80,000 each.

www.Stateboards.ie lists vacancies for two new members of the Central Bank Commission who will earn just under (EURO)15,000 each. Two slots on the Nama board are also advertised; each pays (EURO)50,000 per year. Not-for-profit roles are generally unpaid.

Most non-executive directors don't do it for financial gain.

"It's important that there's absolute synergy between the two of you and that your value systems are aligned," said Mackey. "It's very enjoyable and challenging and can be extremely rewarding to be on a board, but you need to go into it with your eyes wide open."

Your function is not to agree with the management all the time. You've got to challenge


LOAD-DATE: February 25, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Prospective board members do not have to agree with the management all the time. They need to challenge constructively, said one experienced director


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: STS



Copyright 2018 Times Newspapers Limited
All Rights Reserved


260 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Times (London)


February 23, 2018 Friday  
Edition 1;
Ireland


Political fudge is behind lower age of digital consent;
Ministers have failed to properly debate change to law about how firms store children's data


BYLINE: Cormac Lucey


SECTION: EDITORIAL; OPINION, COLUMNS; Pg. 20


LENGTH: 980 words


Iam due to give a talk shortly to a public body. As a courtesy, the organisers of the event emailed me a list of their members who have registered to attend. The excel document was passwordprotected due to new GDPR regulations. GDPR stands for General Data Protection Regulation and it refers to a 2016 EU regulation to harmonise data protection laws across the member states.

The regulation introduces several obligations for organisations that handle personal data, such as stricter mechanisms for obtaining consents, timely notification of breaches and keeping the need for data to a minimum in the first place. Individuals also have several rights such as access to and rectification of their personal information and the right to have it erased. 

Another consequence is that Ireland must set a digital age of consent. The original text of the GDPR tabled by the European Commission in 2012 proposed a threshold of 13 years. During final negotiations with the European Parliament this was increased to 16 but with an option for individual member states to reduce it to as low as 13 - the route the Irish government is proposing to take.

Contrary to what the term might suggest, it doesn't refer to the age at which children can decide for themselves to access the internet or engage in online activities. Instead, it refers to the age from which it is legal for data controllers to gather and hold data from minors without parental consent.

Charlie Flanagan, the justice minister, has explained the government's preference for 13 by saying that organisations involved in child welfare have recommended it. A government advisory group has also recommended 13.

Other experts hold a contrary viewpoint. Two leading cyber security figures recently told the Oireachtas committee on children and youth affairs that there are significant risks in opting for 13. Professor Barry O'Sullivan, director of the Insight Centre for Data Analytics at UCC, said that it would allow social media companies to gather information about a child, including where they live, where they go to school, or their family photographs.

Dr Mary Aiken, adjunct associate professor at UCD's Geary Institute for Public Policy, believes the internet is "not fit for children as it stands". She has said that Irish children under 16 are deemed too young to attend a GP on their own for health advice, so the same age should apply for digital consent.

Several aspects of the government's stance on the issue are worrying. Rather than explain and defend its own position, it seems to be hiding behind various organisations. That's a wholly inadequate position. Any minister can readily find advice that he or she likes and then act on it. It's an old and well-established political game, but it doesn't in any way dilute the government's responsibility for deciding its own policy in this area. That should follow a consideration of the pros and cons of different stances rather than just outsourcing policy-making to unaccountable experts. There was public consultation on the age of consent, but it was more likely to have been responded to by corporate interests with a lot at stake rather than parents too busy with today's real concerns to spend a lot of time on possible concerns that may arise tomorrow.

The outcome certainly seems to reflect the interests of the former ahead of the latter, many of whom would be shocked to learn that the government wants to give 13-yearold children the right to decide which organisations may hold their personal data.

The woolly thinking permeating the official stance on the question was illustrated at Oireachtas hearings on Wednesday when Ronan Lupton, a barrister and member of the government's internet advisory group, was asked why he believes the digital age of consent should be lowered to 13. He said that if a parent puts a picture of a naked child on the internet, the child would not have the right to have that picture taken down without the intervention of the parent until they reached 16. I find that scenario unlikely, if occasionally possible. Martin Conway, a Fine Gael senator, asked him about the reverse scenario, where a young person put a provocative picture of themselves on the internet. Would it be the case that a parent could not require it to be taken down if the child were over 13? "I think that would be the case, yes," Lupton replied, only to be told by Conway that the vast majority of parents would be horrified by such a prospect.

At the same hearings, four ministers turned out to bat for the government position. Katherine Zappone, the children's minister, said that the presence of technology giants in Ireland should be used to push for safeguards. "We must link responsibility for child welfare and protection with the provision of services," she said. "We must embed responsibility for child welfare and protection in all services to children."

That sounds wonderful, but it presumes the technology giants are public-spirited bodies that will drop everything to listen rather than profit-orientated corporations focused on maximising their commercial opportunities and minimising their costs. I don't criticise their stance. What I do criticise is our government relying on trust and good faith endeavours to prevail over it. Flanagan said that legislation could be introduced to make it illegal for social media companies to use data from children under 16. If so, why not set the digital age of consent at 16 in the first place and save everyone additional bother? Looking at the way the issue has been handled so far there is a grave danger that the government has followed the groupthink of corporate interests and experts rather than the example of Germany and the Netherlands which have opted for 16.

One expert believes the internet is not fit for children as it stands

Ministers are wrong to think that trust and good faith will prevail


LOAD-DATE: February 23, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Children aged 13 will be able to give consent for their personal data to be storedEMMA KIM/GETTY IMAGES


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: TIM



Copyright 2018 Times Newspapers Limited
All Rights Reserved


261 of 413 DOCUMENTS




mirror.co.uk


February 22, 2018 Thursday 1:56 PM GMT 


How you're giving away your private information online without even realising it - 5 reasons to fear your permanent record;
We all know we're leaving a record behind, but do you know exactly what that means? Here's why you should be worried


BYLINE: By Jo-Anne Rowney


SECTION: TECHNOLOGY; Version:1


LENGTH: 587 words


Permanent records in the real world contain information that has some sort of administrative, historical, or legal worth.

There's a reason they need to be preserved such as your medical history, a criminal record, a birth certificate, or perhaps a will.

But what about permanent records online? Information doesn't fade away like it used to. What was once lost in files, is now there ready and searchable, for who knows how long. 

Is it something to be worried about, even to fear? What even is a permanent record?

Here are five things you should know - and fear:

It equally gathers important and meaningless information about you and keeps it forever. Your birth certificate gets filed with your tweets. It's just a big melting pot of everything you do online. That means pictures, web browser histories, sites you join, emails, attachments, posts and so on, forming a profile of yourself that may be nothing like who you really are.

Every time you go online, you're adding another entry to this in-erasable entity. There is no privacy with an online permanent record. Permanent in most instances, just means public.

How to stay safe online - top safety tips for kids using the Internet or social media

Sometimes you hear a permanent record referred to as a 'digital footprint.' But that's not quite accurate. Some footprints can be covered or removed. But a permanent record can't be deleted from the Internet. When you pull down a Twitter post or empty your inbox, that information doesn't just disappear. Once information goes public, it gets collected and retained by apps, people, companies, data collectors and the government. Even if you close an account like Instagram or Snapchat, traces of your history remain. The only difference being you can't get into the app anymore.

Facebook

Google

With Facebook, it doesn't even matter if you belong to Facebook. The company can track you on any site that connects to Facebook with a "like" box. The company can also track non-member friends of Facebook users.

13 ways your online privacy was violated in 2016 - and what you can do about it

Permanent records online in most cases have no historical or legal value, not to us anyway. They are a goldmine however to the companies collecting and maintaining them.

Here's what that could mean to you:

Mark Weinstein: Did Facebook elect Trump President? The role it played with 'fake news'

This win by European users against Google has the potential to let users regain some control of their permanent record.

People should have the right to clean their records. They should be able to maintain their truth online. The problem however is you still must go through a process, leap through some hoops, to get that information removed from Google's search engine.

It's better than nothing though, which is how life is in the United States.

We need online privacy to protect ourselves, our families, and our friends. With a permanent record, we also need online privacy to protect our reputation and ability to earn a living. Our digital self should mirror that of ourselves. That requires better control of our private information. We should have means to ensure its accuracy.

Laws such as the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) are a step in the right direction. But be careful regardless about what you do and post online. It's no longer a question of if someone is watching, but rather the numbers of entities doing it.


LOAD-DATE: February 22, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDMI



Copyright 2018 Trinity Mirror, Plc.
All Rights Reserved


262 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Daily Telegraph (London)


February 21, 2018 Wednesday  
Edition 1;
National Edition


Plan now for data reforms or face the consequences


BYLINE: stephen bailey


SECTION: BUSINESS;NEWS; Pg. 2


LENGTH: 895 words


Most businesses are reliant on a complex supply chain to maintain efficiency. From outsourced payroll or marketing services to medical insurance providers, the supply chain is often larger than first anticipated. It should come as no surprise that this will be highly scrutinised under the EU's new General Data Protection Regulation, which will come into effect in May, due to the sheer volume of data processed as part of it.

In preparation, companies need to know exactly what their supply chain looks like by undertaking a risk-based audit, with efforts focused where it matters most from a privacy perspective. This is something that is much easier said than done. However, there are some simple steps that businesses can take in order to comply. 

First and foremost, it is important to map precisely where data you are responsible for lies throughout the supply chain. Once this is established, you will need to control what your new, existing and previous suppliers are doing with the personal data shared with them.

New suppliers should be brought on board with a contract outlining precisely what data will be shared, what it can be used for and what will happen to it at the termination of the contract. It will also be crucial to define a meaningful retention period for holding on to the data following the end of the contract and how the data will be destroyed and/or returned at the end of this period.

Existing supplier contracts need updating to reflect these precautions, while carrying out a full review of their current distributed data will ensure they only have access to the information they need.

Previous suppliers can be trickier to handle and will most likely need to be reviewed to identify areas of high risk that need to be addressed.

Carrying out these measures will protect customers from unlawful uses of their personal information. For example, a marketing company co-ordinating email campaigns would only have access to information relevant for that purpose - that means no date of birth or bank details - and would not lawfully be able to add customers to other distribution lists.

Any actual or suspected data breaches, whether large or small, must be recorded or tracked in a breach log.

As a minimum, reporting on exactly when a breach took place, how it happened, the decision that was made in response, and who signed off this decision will prove a business is at least attempting to comply. Since the general consensus of GDPR is "the more, the better", those wishing to demonstrate intent beyond mere compliance should link the recorded breach to any steps taken to prevent further breaches.

To ensure full transparency over any potential breaches to data you are responsible for, it's highly advised that contracts developed with suppliers should agree access to their own breach logs. This also provides an opportunity to monitor for vulnerabilities and flag when a supplier's cyber security might not be up to scratch - any alarming activity will provide a warning sign to change suppliers and can help avoid falling victim to a severe cyber attack.

When collecting data, businesses will be required to disclose what it is being used for, as well as how it will be processed, shared and stored. Due to the extent of most supply chains, it's also highly likely that somewhere along the line, data may be shared or stored outside the EU.

Even if a supplier is not UK-based, they will need to comply with the same regulations if they hold any personal data relating to people in the EU. But the onus is on the business responsible for the data to ensure that any contracted suppliers meet these standards, especially as the fines handed out by the Information Commissioner's Office are likely to skyrocket under GDPR.

More significant contraventions of the regulation could result in fines of up to (EURO)20m (£17.7m) or 4pc of an organisation's global turnover, whichever is the greater figure. One example of the increased financial risk to companies is the TalkTalk breach that allowed cyber attackers to access customer data.

The company was fined £400,000 in 2016, but under GDPR this would rise significantly to around (EURO)59m.

It is also crucial to raise awareness with key stakeholders. Not just so that everyone is aware of the changes required and the amount of work to be planned for and carried out, but also so they understand that responsibility for preparing for GDPR does not sit solely with the IT department and the legal team.

In this way, every department within the business must work in tandem to "know their data", the extent of the supply chain and, crucially, secure board buy-in for this shift.

As the months are drawing ever closer to GDPR's implementation, businesses need to ensure they are making significant steps towards securing the supply chain.

The main objectives for any business should be to improve their security defences, ensure all sensitive data is safeguarded, and to use GDPR as an opportunity to review their entire security strategy.

Understanding that attacks will happen and ensuring appropriate reactions is crucial.

Although the initial task can be overwhelming, approaching GDPR with a structured, risk-based approach is the best way forward.

Stephen Bailey is an associate director at NCC Group

'Companies need to know exactly what their supply chain looks like by undertaking a risk-based audit'


LOAD-DATE: February 21, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: DTL



Copyright 2018 Telegraph Media Group Limited
All Rights Reserved


263 of 413 DOCUMENTS




telegraph.co.uk


February 21, 2018 Wednesday 6:00 AM GMT 


Plan now for data reforms or face the consequences


BYLINE: By Stephen Bailey


SECTION: BUSINESS; Version:1


LENGTH: 979 words


Most businesses are reliant on a complex supply chain to maintain efficiency. From outsourced payroll or marketing services to medical insurance providers, the supply chain is often larger than first anticipated. It should come as no surprise that this will be highly scrutinised under the EU's new General Data Protection Regulation, which will come into effect in May, due to the sheer volume of data processed as part of it.

In preparation, companies need to know exactly what their supply chain looks like by undertaking a risk-based audit, with efforts focused where it matters most from a privacy perspective. This is something that is much easier said than done. However, there are some simple steps that businesses can take in order to comply. 

First and foremost, it is important to map precisely where data you are responsible for lies throughout the supply chain. Once this is established, you will need to control what your new, existing and previous suppliers are doing with the personal data shared with them.

New suppliers should be brought on board with a contract outlining precisely what data will be shared, what it can be used for and what will happen to it at the termination of the contract. It will also be crucial to define a meaningful retention period for holding on to the data following the end of the contract and how the data will be destroyed and/or returned at the end of this period.

Existing supplier contracts need updating to reflect these precautions, while carrying out a full review of their current distributed data will ensure they only have access to the information they need.

Previous suppliers can be trickier to handle and will most likely need to be reviewed to identify areas of high risk that need to be addressed.

Carrying out these measures will protect customers from unlawful uses of their personal information. For example, a marketing company co-ordinating email campaigns would only have access to information relevant for that purpose - that means no date of birth or bank details - and would not lawfully be able to add customers to other distribution lists.

Any actual or suspected data breaches, whether large or small, must be recorded or tracked in a breach log.

As a minimum, reporting on exactly when a breach took place, how it happened, the decision that was made in response, and who signed off this decision will prove a business is at least attempting to comply. Since the general consensus of GDPR is "the more, the better", those wishing to demonstrate intent beyond mere compliance should link the recorded breach to any steps taken to prevent further breaches.

To ensure full transparency over any potential breaches to data you are responsible for, it's highly advised that contracts developed with suppliers should agree access to their own breach logs. This also provides an opportunity to monitor for vulnerabilities and flag when a supplier's cyber security might not be up to scratch - any alarming activity will provide a warning sign to change suppliers and can help avoid falling victim to a severe cyber attack.

.html-embed.component .quote.component{margin-left:0}.html-embed.component .quote.component .component-content{margin-right:16px}.quote__source, .quote__author {white-space: normal;}@media only screen and (min-width:730px){.html-embed.component .quote.component{margin-left:-60.83px}.html-embed.component .quote.component .quote__content:before{margin-left:-12px;padding-right:1px}}@media only screen and (min-width:1008px){.html-embed.component .quote.component{margin-left:-82.33px}}Companies need to know exactly what their supply chain looks like by undertaking a risk-based audit

When collecting data, businesses will be required to disclose what it is being used for, as well as how it will be processed, shared and stored. Due to the extent of most supply chains, it's also highly likely that somewhere along the line, data may be shared or stored outside the EU.

Even if a supplier is not UK-based, they will need to comply with the same regulations if they hold any personal data relating to people in the EU. But the onus is on the business responsible for the data to ensure that any contracted suppliers meet these standards, especially as the fines handed out by the Information Commissioner's Office are likely to skyrocket under GDPR.

More significant contraventions of the regulation could result in fines of up to (EURO)20m (£17.7m) or 4pc of an organisation's global turnover, whichever is the greater figure. One example of the increased financial risk to companies is the TalkTalk breach that allowed cyber attackers to access customer data.

The company was fined £400,000 in 2016, but under GDPR this would rise significantly to around (EURO)59m.

High-profile hacks

It is also crucial to raise awareness with key stakeholders. Not just so that everyone is aware of the changes required and the amount of work to be planned for and carried out, but also so they understand that responsibility for preparing for GDPR does not sit solely with the IT department and the legal team.

In this way, every department within the business must work in tandem to "know their data", the extent of the supply chain and, crucially, secure board buy-in for this shift.

As the months are drawing ever closer to GDPR's implementation, businesses need to ensure they are making significant steps towards securing the supply chain.

The main objectives for any business should be to improve their security defences, ensure all sensitive data is safeguarded, and to use GDPR as an opportunity to review their entire security strategy.

Understanding that attacks will happen and ensuring appropriate reactions is crucial.

Although the initial task can be overwhelming, approaching GDPR with a structured, risk-based approach is the best way forward.

Stephen Bailey is an associate director at NCC Group

JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDTNS

All Rights Reserved


264 of 413 DOCUMENTS




telegraph.co.uk


February 20, 2018 Tuesday 2:29 PM GMT 


Can your employer check your emails and spy on you at work? 


BYLINE: By Sophie Christie


SECTION: BUSINESS; Version:2


LENGTH: 1008 words


Many of us suspect that our employers are closely watching our day-to-day activities to ensure we're not browsing social media websites or making personal phone calls rather than working.

But it's rare for a company to publicly call on its staff members to spy on their colleagues and report lax behaviour - unless of course you are the Australian Taxation Office, which sent out an internal memo in December encouraging employees to snitch on time wasters in the office. 

The note, which was released under a freedom of information request, was titled "Seen something suspicious?" and urged staff to report when a colleague "makes a habit of taking long lunches", "regularly leaves early" or "spends the first hour at work eating breakfast and reading the paper". 

"There could be explanations - perhaps they travel to work with their partner who has to start early, and they don't 'sign on' until after breakfast. Or maybe they have an agreed working arrangement that enables them to leave early, or partly work from home," the note said.

"Or perhaps your suspicions are correct and they're simply not recording their working hours appropriately." 

The government agency's 20,000 public servants were advised to make an anonymous report if they suspected colleagues of failing to accurately record working hours.

The note said: "We all have an obligation to assist in reporting fraud by referring any suspicion to either a manager or to fraud prevention and internal investigations."

A failure to accurately record working hours "can be fraud", the note said.

Is it legal for employers to spy on their staff?

It is common for employers to monitor their staff via phone and IT systems, CCTV and even, in more extreme cases, location tracking through employee access passes. It is also completely legal in the UK.

And while this Big Brother-style surveillance is often slammed as harmful for workplace culture, as it is an intrusion of privacy, the motivation behind it isn't always negative. Employers say monitoring is often a health and safety measure, to prevent crime, such as theft or misconduct, or misappropriation of intellectual property, and to comply with legal and regulatory obligations.

While monitoring is legal, there are several guidelines companies must adhere to, such as providing an unrecorded telephone line for employees to use in emergencies if all other telephones are routinely monitored, and explaining how the information will be stored and processed in accordance with the Data Protection Act, and who has access to this information.

The 1998 Human Rights Act also plays an important role here as it gives individuals' a right to privacy, therefore employers need to find a balance between an employee's legitimate expectation of privacy and the employers interests when they monitor their staff, says Nicola Goodridge, an employment law and HR consultant.

Suzanne Horne of law firm Paul Hastings, says that when it comes to monitoring the amount of time spent on lunch, employers have active obligations under the Working Time Regulations and Health and Safety at Work Act to ensure that employees do take a break.

"Monitoring can be justified if it means employees return from their breaks to ensure that their colleagues are also allowed to take their allotted time out. The legal issues arise in terms of how employers conduct this monitoring as, again, this can be in direct conflict with the Data Protection Act and the employees' Article 8 right to a private life under the European Convention of Human Rights," she says. 

Can an employer read your emails?

According to a  European Court of Human Rights (ECHR) ruling in 2016, bosses have the right to spy on staff's work emails and electronic messages . 

The decision was taken after a Romanian engineer was fired for sending messages to his fianceé on his private Yahoo chats, and challenged his employer in the High Court.

The ECHR later defined the scope of corporate snooping by ruling that companies must tell employees in advance, either in the staff handbook or employment contract, if their work email accounts are being monitored.

"An employer does have the right to monitor emails, but it must carry out an impact assessment to demonstrate that it is a balancing act between protecting its employees' privacy, and the legitimate interests of the business," Ms Horne says.

Dr Mark Batey, a senior lecturer in organisational psychology at Alliance Manchester Business School, says that just because employees can monitor their staff, doesn't mean they should. 

"If monitoring is a way to protect staff, then that's fine, but if it's because you don't trust them then this can be hugely demotivating for employees and your company will be less appealing to prospective staff," he says.

"So what could appear to be savings on the surface by making staff more productive could actually prove more costly if you struggle to retain and attract employees."

Ranked: the top 10 UK companies to work for in 2018

Hannah Reed of Trades Union Congress (TUC) agrees: "British workers put in billions of unpaid overtime every year. They shouldn't be punished for occasionally checking private emails and going on social media."

She says: "Bosses who snoop on their staff undermine trust and damage morale. It is essential that employers have clear policies on Internet use so that people know where they stand. Acting in a draconian way is not the answer."

From the end of May, the Data Protection Act (DPA) will be replaced by the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), a framework with greater scope and much tougher punishments for those who fail to comply with new rules around the storage and handling of personal data.

The regulation will favour employees, Ms Horne says, "so businesses must ensure they update privacy notices and policies to reflect these changes and ensure that they continue to have the right to monitor their employees in appropriate circumstances".


LOAD-DATE: February 20, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDTNS



Copyright 2018 Telegraph Media Group Limited
All Rights Reserved


265 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Times (London)


February 20, 2018 Tuesday  
Edition 1;
Ireland


EU rules create surge in jobs for data protection experts


BYLINE: Peter O'Dwyer


SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 36


LENGTH: 183 words


The number of vacancies for data protection experts rose by more than a third last year as businesses stepped up their preparations for the introduction of new EU regulations later this year. 

Orla Moran, general manager at www.IrishJobs.ie, said: "General data protection regulation (GDPR) is a far-reaching regulation that has implications for every Irish SME and multinational that processes personal data. Fines for noncompliance are significant. In 2017 www.IrishJobs.ie recorded a sustained yearlong increase in jobs requiring GDPRrelated skills, and early indications for this quarter suggest that the trend is continuing.

The deadline for GDPR adherence to the rules is May 25. After this date, companies will be liable for fines of up to (EURO)20 million, or 4 per cent of turnover.

A survey by the Irish Small and Medium Enterprises Association suggested that 76 per cent of its members were concerned about GDPR.

More than 40 per cent of businesses have a member of staff dedicated to data protection and GDPR compliance, while only 7 per cent have completed their GDPR plan, its survey suggested.


LOAD-DATE: February 20, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: TIM



Copyright 2018 Times Newspapers Limited
All Rights Reserved


266 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Daily Telegraph (London)


February 19, 2018 Monday  
Edition 1;
National Edition


Tech industry warns ministers not to drop EU data security laws


BYLINE: Peter Foster


SECTION: BUSINESS;NEWS; Pg. 3


LENGTH: 759 words


THE British tech industry has issued a stark warning to leading Brexiteer ministers that diverging from EU data protection standards after Brexit will "undermine" the UK's status as Europe's leading tech hub.

In an open letter to Liam Fox, the International Trade Secretary, Julian David, the chief executive of the industry's leading lobby group, said that remaining closely aligned with the EU would not stop the UK seeking trade deals after Brexit.

"Diverging from EU data protection rules in domestic law post-Brexit would undermine this opportunity," wrote Mr David, of TechUK, which represents nearly 1,000 UK tech firms, including several FTSE 100 companies. 

The letter warned of a growing "misunderstanding" among Brexiteers that Britain could chase a Brexit dividend by diverging from the EU's tough data protection rules in order to seek comparative advantage with Europe in a fast-growing sector.

"We would caution against the misunderstanding that adherence to the EU data protection regime is incompatible with securing high-quality trade agreements," added Mr David in the letter co-signed by Dean Garfield, the chief executive of the ITI, TechUK's international affiliate.

The plea from the tech sector's chief lobby group to remain converged with the EU echoes those already made by the pharmaceutical and chemical industries. Thanks to a strong regulatory environment, a central timezone and its geographical location between the US and continental Europe, the UK handles 11.5pc of worldwide data flows - nearly four times its share of global GDP (3.2pc).

The UK is also Europe's leader in digital start-ups, with 43pc of all large EU digital companies being started in the UK. It also boasts a burgeoning £7bn "fintech" industry, which employs 60,000 people as part of a financial services industry worth a total of £124bn a year.

TechUK's decision to publish an open letter represents a shot across the bows to Mr Fox and other Brexiteer ministers who have been lobbying across Whitehall for a more divergent approach to Brexit - often citing the tech industry as an area with exciting possibilities for divergence. TechUK praised the work of the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport, which is implementing the EU's new general data protection regulation (GDPR), which will be fully taken into UK law ahead of Brexit.

TechUK said its members had made very clear that they had no wish to diverge from the GDPR post-Brexit, having already invested significantly in order to achieve compliance with the new EU regulations.

More importantly, Mr David told The Daily Telegraph, remaining compliant will be essential to both retaining and expanding the UK's position as a global tech and data hub.

"This is the base of international trade deals, if we end up different, then that's a problem," he said, citing the work that the US had done to reach its own "Privacy Shield" agree ment with the EU in order to keep transatlantic data flows moving. His message contradicts that of leading Brexiteer ministers who have argued internally that the UK needs to be able to have divergent regulations in future economic growth areas such as artificial intelligence.

They argue that such an approach would enable the UK to outflank the EU, which has historically taken a highly conservative approach to digital and data issues.

However, TechUK believes that when it comes to tech, the Brexiteer divergence narrative is misguided, arguing that in practice the UK is unlikely to want to diverge radically from the EU, particularly when public approaches to data, robotics, artificial intelligence and social media are trending in a more conservative direction.

Instead, the UK should use its position as an industry leader and global data hub to exert "soft power" influence on shaping the EU approach to data regulation.

In August last year, the Government released a 13-page Brexit position paper in which it pledged to keep the UK "fully involved" in shaping EU data policy, starting from a point of "unprecedented" alignment at the point of exit.

The paper proposed that the UK's data authority, the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO), be "fully involved in future EU regulatory dialogue", with an "ongoing role" for the ICO with the existing network of EU data protection authorities.

Mr David concluded that there was now a growing risk that ideology might take precedence over expertise when setting policy.

"It is time to listen to the experts," he said. "The idea that we should have divergence on data protection rules is incorrect and unhelpful."


LOAD-DATE: February 19, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Julian David, the chief executive of TECHUK


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: DTL

267 of 413 DOCUMENTS




telegraph.co.uk


February 19, 2018 Monday 12:01 AM GMT 


Tech industry warns ministers not to drop EU data security laws


BYLINE: By Peter Foster , Europe Editor


SECTION: BUSINESS; Version:3


LENGTH: 971 words


The British tech industry has issued a stark warning to leading Brexiteer ministers that diverging from EU data protection standards after Brexit will "undermine" the UK's status as Europe's leading tech hub.

In an open letter to Liam Fox, the International Trade Secretary, Julian David, the chief executive of the industry's leading lobby group, said that remaining closely aligned with the EU would not stop the UK seeking trade deals after Brexit.

"Diverging from EU data protection rules in domestic law post-Brexit would undermine this opportunity," wrote Mr David, of TechUK, which represents nearly 1,000 UK tech firms, including several FTSE 100 companies. 

The letter warned of a growing "misunderstanding" among Brexiteers that Britain could chase a Brexit dividend by diverging from the EU's tough data protection rules in order to seek comparative advantage with Europe in a fast-growing sector.

"We would caution against the misunderstanding that adherence to the EU data protection regime is incompatible with securing high-quality trade agreements," added Mr David in the letter co-signed by Dean Garfield, the chief executive of the ITI, TechUK's international affiliate.

The plea from the tech sector's chief lobby group to remain converged with the EU echoes those already made by the pharmaceutical and chemical industries. Thanks to a strong regulatory environment, a central timezone and its geographical location between the US and continental Europe, the UK handles 11.5pc of worldwide data flows - nearly four times its share of global GDP (3.2pc).

How long until Britain leaves the EU?

The UK is also Europe's leader in digital start-ups, with 43pc of all large EU digital companies being started in the UK. It also boasts a burgeoning £7bn "fintech" industry, which employs 60,000 people as part of a financial services industry worth a total of £124bn a year.

TechUK's decision to publish an open letter represents a shot across the bows to Mr Fox and other Brexiteer ministers who have been lobbying across Whitehall for a more divergent approach to Brexit - often citing the tech industry as an area with exciting possibilities for divergence.

TechUK praised the work of the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport, which is implementing the EU's new general data protection regulation (GDPR), which will be fully taken into UK law ahead of Brexit.  

TechUK said its members had made very clear that they had no wish to diverge from the GDPR post-Brexit, having already invested significantly in order to achieve compliance with the new EU regulations.

More importantly, Mr David told The Daily Telegraph, remaining compliant will be essential to both retaining and expanding the UK's position as a global tech and data hub.

"This is the base of international trade deals, if we end up different, then that's a problem," he said, citing the work that the US had done to reach its own "Privacy Shield" agreement with the EU in order to keep transatlantic data flows moving. His message contradicts that of leading Brexiteer ministers who have argued internally that the UK needs to be able to have divergent regulations in future economic growth areas such as artificial intelligence.

They argue such an approach would enable the UK to outflank the EU which has historically taken a highly conservative approach to digital and data issues, thanks to activist-voices in the European Parliament combining with French protectionism and innate German cautiousness on data issues.

However TechUK believes that when it comes to tech, the Brexiteer divergence narrative is misguided, arguing that in practice the UK is unlikely to want to diverge radically from the EU, particularly when public approaches to data, robotics, artificial intelligence and social media are trending in a more conservative direction.

Instead the UK should use its position as an industry-leader and global data hub to exert 'soft power' influence on shaping EU approach to data regulation.

Making the UK the 'wild west' of the data world - or even signalling that that was the UK's future intention - would be "a disaster" according to Mr David.

Last August, the UK government released a 13-page Brexit position paper in which it pledged to keep the UK "fully involved" in shaping EU data policy, starting from a point of "unprecedented" alignment at the point of exit.

Trading partners | How other nations deal with EU law

The paper proposed that the UK's data authority, the Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) to be "fully involved in future EU regulatory dialogue", with an "ongoing role" for the ICO with the existing network of EU data protection authorities.

It remains to be seen whether the EU will allow the UK any role in shaping regulations after Brexit - currently the European Commission is taking a very hard line - but tech bosses are now concerned this level of ambition may is fading under pressure from leading Brexiteers.

Mr David concluded that there was now a growing risk that ideology might take precedence over expertise when setting policy.

 "It is time to listen to the experts," he added, "The idea that we should have divergence on data protection rules is incorrect and unhelpful."

In a statement, the Department for International trade referred to remarks from Mr Fox last August in which he welcomed the UK position paper on data flows.

"With the UK at the forefront of the increasingly digitised global economy, the government is keen to prioritise key areas such as digital trade and investment as we leave the EU," he said at the time.

"Secure data flows between the UK and EU are crucial for our economic prosperity and these proposals give certainty to businesses and consumers that high protection standards will continue."


LOAD-DATE: February 19, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDTNS



Copyright 2018 Telegraph Media Group Limited
All Rights Reserved


268 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Sunday Times (London)


February 18, 2018 Sunday  
Edition 1;
Ireland


State must not dodge the Data Protection Act;
The plan to exempt public agencies from potential fines is indefensible


BYLINE: Conor Brady


SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. 14


LENGTH: 854 words


Charlie Flanagan, the justice minister, is not thought of as naive or unrealistic. Yet here is what he had to say recently, when asked to justify the government's intention to exempt public bodies from fines if they are found to have breached the terms of the forthcoming EU General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

"I believe it's important in the context of public and state involvement that we lead by example here and that the state, all the public bodies and agencies attached thereto, would be fully compliant," he said. Is Flanagan seriously expecting good behaviour from public bodies if they can never face sanction? GDPR is an EU mega-regulation aimed at giving citizens back control of their personal data, while laying down rules for those hosting and processing that data. It is recognition by Europe - many would say belatedly and minimally - that the harvesting, storage and processing of personal information now takes place on a scale once unimaginable and that this is still growing exponentially. 

GDPR is to be given legal expression here in the Data Protection Act 2018, with effect from May 25. It will entitle citizens who believe their personal data has been misused by, say, a bank, a sports club or an online retail company, to seek compensation through the courts. But the proposed exemption means that if a government department or, say, the HSE or Irish Water breaches an individual's data protection rights, it will effectively be beyond the reach of the courts. The implications here are enormous, since the information held by the state on individuals is likely to be vastly greater and more sensitive than data held by private businesses.

It is unconscionable that the most powerful state agencies, funded by the taxpayer, should have control of individuals' most private information effectively without sanction in the event of misuse. Flanagan and most of his colleagues in government are long enough in public life to know that when the bureaucracy decides it wants to do something, talk of "leading by example" can go by the wayside. They know that moral suasion, on its own, will never ensure compliance with regulations by everyone who holds power. They know that what best moderates the actions of public bodies and institutions, just like private individuals, is fear of getting hit in the pocket.

The government's stance contradicts the wishes of Helen Dixon, the data protection commissioner, who has warned against any exemption for public bodies or authorities. She could see no basis for it, she told the Joint Oireachtas committee on justice last June, because "arguably, higher standards in the protection of fundamental rights are demanded of those entities". Failure to provide for fines on public bodies would "cancel out the deterrent effect" of the legislation, she added.

The committee supported her argument, having heard and rejected submissions from civil servants worried about the legal complexity of possible cases taken against public bodies and the potential drain on resources in the data commissioner's office. It recommended unambiguously that "fines be administered to public bodies in breach of the new data-protection legislation where appropriate, to encourage compliance".

Dixon said that because of Ireland's role as host to many of the world's leading information technology firms, her office will assume "lead supervisory authority" for EU operations. "The message that the government has been sending out globally is that Ireland will be 'best in class', leading the way in European best practice in data protection regulation," she said. "There will inevitably be a huge amount of scrutiny as to the domestic measures taken by the state to give effect to the GDPR."

She is correct. How can a government in Dublin credibly tell people in Silicon Valley, "Do not as we do, when we are conducting our business, but do as we say, when you are conducting yours"? No less sceptical will be citizens whom the state is urging to sign up to the Public Services Card (PSC) scheme. Simon McGarr, a leading privacy lawyer, has argued that the PSC already contravenes the GDPR and that law suits against the state could leave the taxpayer with a bill that could run "into an unknowable number of zeros". If the present draft bill becomes law, there will probably be no such suits, of course. But many people will be wary of committing their information to the PSC scheme if there will be no sanction against any agency or employee of the state that misuses it.

If the government adheres to its proposed exemption for public bodies, it will also undermine Ireland's international credibility and ultimately hit the economy. It should follow the advice of the data protection commissioner, whose role includes providing guidance in navigating a way through this rapidly changing landscape.

Flanagan has said the exemption for state bodies will "be a matter of debate in the Oireachtas starting in the coming weeks". The legislation is still only in draft form. It can and should be amended.

conor.brady@sunday-times.ie

We can't tell people, 'Do not as we do, but do as we say'


LOAD-DATE: February 18, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: STS



Copyright 2018 Times Newspapers Limited
All Rights Reserved


269 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Daily Telegraph (London)


February 17, 2018 Saturday  
Edition 1;
National Edition


Have the tech giants taken a wrong turning?;
They have driven Wall Street's growth in recent years but such strong returns may be over. Laura Suter investigates


BYLINE: Laura Suter


SECTION: MONEY;FEATURES; Pg. 4


LENGTH: 819 words


The technology giants Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Netflix and Google have dominated the American stock market's growth for the past five years. But can their pre-eminence continue?

Facebook's share price has risen by 364pc since the company floated in 2012, while holding Netflix shares for the past 10 years would have given you a 6,520pc return on your investment. Over the same period Alphabet, Google's parent company, has returned almost 300pc, Apple 814pc and Amazon 1,800pc.

However, investors are now questioning whether this rate of growth is sustainable. The most recent earnings announcements from the tech giants, collectively known as the "Fangs", contained some worrying signs. 

While the Fangs are still growing, there are concerns about individual companies: Facebook's ability to grow its user base, for example, or whether the smartphone market has become too mature for Apple's exponential growth to continue.

Professional investors are selling.Walter Price, manager of the £326m Allianz Technology Trust, is one.

"It is almost inevitable that their growth is going to slow as they have got so big," he said. "When it comes to the Fangs we are more enthusiastic about Amazon and Netflix and a bit less enthusiastic about Facebook and Google." Mr Price has recently sold some of his Apple holding on the basis that the smartphone market is now too well developed. Last year Apple was among his top 10 holdings but it no longer features there.

The Allianz manager is not the only one to have concerns about Apple's future growth. Sales of the most recent iPhone X model missed market expectations when volumes of new iPhone sales fell by 1pc at the end of last year. Some put this down to the hefty $999 (£710) price of the device.

Facebook has come under the spotlight because of reports that users are spending less time on its platform. It has also come under fire for the damaging mental health effects of using the website, leading it to overhaul its newsfeed. Mr Price said he expected this overhaul to take up Facebook's resources in the coming months, but his main reason for reducing his stake was Europe's new wide-reaching data protection legislation. The EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) will force companies to be more transparent and get more approval for how they track customers.

"I think Facebook and Google do a lot of tracking of people without their explicit permission, and under GDPR they are going to have to ask permission and customers will have the ability to be untracked," Mr Price said. "That will impose a bit of a slowdown and an additional cost for those companies in the next six months."

Nick Evans, a technology portfolio manager at Polar Capital, the fund group, is more upbeat about the tech giants' prospects.

"We expect the pace of growth to gradually slow for all companies as they become larger, but what makes many of the best technology companies sustain such high levels of growth is that great products drive strong customer usage trends and the resulting pricing power drives strong revenue growth," he said.

However, he is also investing in smaller, higher-growth companies.

"We have many small and mediumsized companies which are growing faster and are much less well known than the Fang stocks," Mr Evans said. In particular he is looking at machine learning and artificial intelligence.

"If we are correct, the influence of artificial intelligence over the next three to five years is likely to accelerate technology disruption, stimulate growth and act as a continued tailwind," he said.

Mr Price is investing in "cloud computing" firms - those that exploit the trend towards services delivered online. "It's hitting its sweet spot in growth and corporate acceptance," he said. "Companies such as Microsoft have been big in this sector, as has ServiceNow, and Workday is seeing easier and faster growth in this environment."

One way to benefit from the growth of the tech giants without having direct exposure is to back companies that work with their products. For example, Chris Ford, who manages the Smith & Williamson Artificial Intelligence fund, said he had invested in Roku, a platform through which you can access Netflix. Its software, which is built into some televisions and comes as an add-on with others, recommends content from different including Netflix, the user.

recommend platforms, i tailored to t He is also regions suc investing in growing such as Latin America.

MercadoLibre, a website that features of eBay and operates in the region.

"It is the leader in La larger than Mr For eco in oa ecommerce market Latin America - it is much anyone else," he said. Ford pointed out that the ecommerce market was tiny the region, at around 1pc of sales, compared with around 15pc in the West, providing huge potential for growth. MercadoLibre has also been tipped by our Questor column.

'It is almost inevitable that their growth is going to slow'


LOAD-DATE: February 17, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Driverless cars depend on Google's mapping data; Facebook, led by Mark Zuckerberg, is overhauling its website rless nd ping book, erhauling ite
