JOURNAL-CODE: DTL



Copyright 2018 Telegraph Media Group Limited
All Rights Reserved


270 of 413 DOCUMENTS




telegraph.co.uk


February 17, 2018 Saturday 7:30 AM GMT 


Amazon, Google, Netflix and other FANGS: where next for super-profits?


BYLINE: By Laura Suter


SECTION: INVESTING; Version:1


LENGTH: 829 words


The technology giants Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Netflix and Google have dominated the American stock market's growth for the past five years. But can their  pre-eminence continue?

Facebook's share price has risen by 364pc since the company floated in 2012, while holding Netflix shares for the past 10 years would have given you a 6,520pc return on your investment. Over the same period Alphabet, Google's parent company, has returned almost 300pc, Apple 814pc and Amazon 1,800pc.

However, investors are now questioning whether this rate of growth is sustainable. The most recent earnings announcements from the tech giants, collectively known as the "Fangs", contained some worrying signs.  

While the Fangs are still growing, there are concerns about individual companies: Facebook's ability to grow its user base, for example, or whether the smartphone market has become too mature for Apple's exponential growth to continue.

Professional investors are selling. Walter Price, manager of the £326m Allianz Technology Trust, is one. 

"It is almost inevitable that their growth is going to slow as they have got so big," he said. "When it comes to the Fangs we are more enthusiastic about Amazon and Netflix and a bit less enthusiastic about Facebook and Google."

Buy these seven shares to profit from driverless cars and artificial intelligence

Mr Price has recently sold some of his Apple holding on the basis that the smartphone market is now too well developed. Last year Apple was among his top 10 holdings but it no longer features there. 

The Allianz manager is not the only one to have concerns about Apple's future growth. Sales of the most recent iPhone X model missed market expectations when volumes of new iPhone sales fell by 1pc at the end of last year . Some put this down to the hefty $999 (£710) price of the device.

Facebook has come under the spotlight because of reports that users are spending less time on its platform . It has also come under fire for the damaging mental health effects of using the website, leading it to overhaul its newsfeed.

Mr Price said he expected this overhaul to take up Facebook's resources in the coming months, but his main reason for reducing his stake was Europe's new wide-reaching data protection legislation. The EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) will force companies to be more transparent and get more approval for how they track customers.

"I think Facebook and Google do a lot of tracking of people without their explicit permission, and under GDPR they are going to have to ask permission and customers will have the ability to be untracked," Mr Price said. "That will impose a bit of a slowdown and an additional cost for those companies in the next six months."

Nick Evans, a technology portfolio manager at Polar Capital, the fund group, is more upbeat about the tech giants' prospects. 

"We expect the pace of growth to gradually slow for all companies as they become larger, but what makes many of the best technology companies sustain such high levels of growth is that great products drive strong customer usage trends and the resulting pricing power drives strong revenue growth," he said. However, he is also investing in smaller, higher-growth companies. 

"We have many small and medium-sized companies which are growing faster and are much less well known than the Fang stocks," Mr Evans said. In particular he is looking at machine learning and artificial intelligence.

"If we are correct, the influence of artificial intelligence over the next three to five years is likely to accelerate technology disruption, stimulate growth and act as a continued tailwind," he said.

Mr Price is investing in "cloud computing" firms - those that exploit the trend towards services delivered online. "It's hitting its sweet spot in growth and corporate acceptance," he said. "Companies such as Microsoft have been big in this sector, as has ServiceNow, and Workday is seeing easier and faster growth in this environment."

One way to benefit from the growth of the tech giants without having direct exposure is to back companies that work with their products.

For example, Chris Ford, who manages the Smith & Williamson Artificial Intelligence fund, said he had invested in Roku, a platform through which you can access Netflix. Its software, which is built into some televisions and comes as an add-on with others, recommends content from different platforms, including Netflix, tailored to the user. 

He is also investing in growing regions such as Latin America. MercadoLibre, a website that combines features of eBay and Amazon, operates in the region.

"It is the ecommerce market leader in Latin America - it is much larger than anyone else," he said. Mr Ford pointed out that the ecommerce market was tiny in the region, at around 1pc of sales, compared with around 15pc in the West, providing huge potential for growth. MercadoLibre has also been tipped by our Questor column.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDTNS



Copyright 2018 Telegraph Media Group Limited
All Rights Reserved


271 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Times (London)


February 17, 2018 Saturday  
Edition 1;
National Edition


Advert guru has little time for tech giants' excuses on extremist content;
Johnny Hornby has targets from online platforms to politicians in his sights


BYLINE: Alexandra Frean


SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 53


LENGTH: 1301 words


Johnny Hornby saw nothing remotely satisfying when Unilever threatened this week to withdraw ads from Google and Facebook unless they properly policed extremist content on their platforms. The ad industry chief had been warning of just such a boycott for years, but didn't see this as a "told you so" moment. There's too much at stake.

It has been, the founder of The&Partnership argues, something akin to "the wild west with YouTube [owned by Google] and Facebook. If they are going to take people's advertising money, it's their duty to ensure that their media inventory is safe."

In the old media world, if somebody had sprayed swastikas on one of his posters, he would have had it down within the hour. So why can't digital platforms do the same and make sure that adverts do not appear alongside unpalatable or illegal content? He has little time for the excuse that with 400 hours of content uploaded to YouTube every minute, it's hard to police it all. 

"They don't need to enable the entire inventory to accept advertising. They could say, 'We will check the inventory and only when we know it's 100 per cent clear will we enable it to receive your advertising.' If behaving well means the tech platforms making less money, it's a price they should be willing to pay."

His warning against the two technology giants, which together account for more than half of Britain's digital advertising market, had focused on advertising fraud, where criminals create fake traffic of absolutely no value to advertisers. The scams are estimated to cost the industry $16.4billion a year. Yet Mr Hornby believes that, finally, the penny has dropped with Facebook and Google. "They've had a very good scare. They have genuinely recognised that if they want to take advertising, they have probably not got many more goes at this." Now representatives from the two companies visit him and his rivals virtually every week.

Already, however, the industry's attention is being diverted to new threats from different directions, not least the arrival on its doorstep of the big professional services and accountancy firms. Accenture, Deloitte, KPMG, McKinsey and PWC have been buying up ad agencies to take advantage of a seismic shift in the business landscape - "They have bought two or three times the number of digital advertising agencies in the US than the traditional holding companies have". And they also have an early advantage: the first people to get their foot in the door when corporations begin digital transformations are the Deloittes and Accentures of this world, who now like to roll in advertising as an additional service.

Then there is the advent of Europe's new GDPR data protection rules, which come into force in May. These herald another disruption to the advertising industry, tightening the rules on buying and selling customer data.

These extra competitive pressures could not have come at a worst time for adland's big holding companies, which had a terrible 2017. WPP, Publicis, Omnicom and Interpublic all suffered significant drops in their share prices as big consumer goods companies cut back on advertising.

Against this backdrop The&Partnership, which is 49 per cent-owned by WPP, doubled its revenue last year to £457 million and added brands such as Netflix to its client list, which also includes Toyota and News UK, publisher of The Times. It did this by adopting an unconventional "full service" approach, which brings together a package of services (media buying, data analytics, PR, creative and more) into one team with a single bottom line for each client. The teams then work in the client's offices, acting like rapid response units.

Mr Hornby cites his company's work for Toyota in Paris, where petrol and diesel cars are banned on days when the temperature tops 32C: "My team inside Toyota can see the weather forecast and if it's going to be really hot they can move all of the media money to early drivetime radio and tell every Parisian that if they drive a Toyota hybrid vehicle they are not affected by the ban."

Charming and chatty, Mr Hornby, 50, has been described as the smoothest act in adland. He displays an engaging mix of self-satisfaction and self-deprecating humour, neatly reflected in his anecdote of what a typical Hornby family Christmas might look like. "Nick [his halfbrother Nick Hornby, the novelist] might say, 'Oh, I've written this book about my obsession with Arsenal and it's going to be made into a movie and I'm going to be played by Colin Firth.' Gill [his sister Gill Hornby, the novelist] might say, 'I've written a novel about women at the school gates called The Hive.' Robert [Robert Harris, the novelist, married to Gill] might say, 'I've written a story about Hitler having won the war and a bungling detective in the Sixties uncovering the fact that there was a holocaust.' And I would say, 'We've propelled a man into a load of fruit with the line, "You know when you've been Tangoed." Everyone would laugh at me, apart from my mother, who would say, 'Well done, darling, aren't you clever.' " His mother is Sonia Beesley, the BBC journalist who got Margaret Thatcher to reveal that, as prime minister, she found time in the middle of the night to darn her husband Denis's socks. His late father was the industrialist Sir Derek Hornby, chairman of Rank-Xerox and the British Overseas Trade Board.

The Christmas anecdote speaks volumes about the frustrations of a man with a gilded life who harbours demons deep down. He seems profoundly disturbed about the dysfunctional state of British and American politics. He hates Brexit, President Trump and the Tories and is in despair about the Labour party's takeover by the hard Left.

"I think John McDonnell is the baddy, probably more than Corbyn, who is the mad old uncle. They will try to get out anybody who has a sniff of David Milliband about them," he says. This is, after all, the ad man who helped Tony Blair's new Labour to hold on to office in 2001 and 2005 and who remains a close associate of Lord (Peter) Mandelson.

So why not run for office himself? Any temptation is fleeting: "What I would love to do is to support through what I do well - marketing and branding - whoever the next Tony Blair is. If somebody emerged, a centrist, preferably for me centre left, with the next third way, I would love to lend my hand to help to make that happen."

Q&A

Who is your mentor?

My late father, Sir Derek Hornby. In any difficult situation I ask myself what he would do ...

Does money motivate you?

Whenever people think about money too much, things will go sour, whereas people who pursue innovative ideas with passion find they will be the better off in the end.

What was the most important event in your working life?

Waking up the morning after the 2001 election, having finished our second campaign and starting out on our own.

Which person do you most admire?

I will forever admire my two founding partners, Simon Clemmow and Charles Inge.

What is your favourite television programme?

I don't watch much television other than Newsnight and Match of the Day, but I've become a binge consumer of box-sets. Big Little Lies, This Is Us, The Crown. The best ever is Friday Night Lights.

What does leadership mean to you?

Making and taking the big decisions and in our business leading the innovation and taking calculated risks, because managing the status quo isn't attractive to me.

How do you relax?

With five horses and five children, and if you ask my family they might say in that order.

CV

Born: 1967, Gloucestershire

Education: University of Edinburgh

Career: 1991-94: Ogilvy & Mather; 1994-98: CDP; 1998-2001: managing director, TBWA; 2001: founding partner, CHI&Partners; 2013: chairman and chief executive, The&Partnership

Family: Married to Clare Hornby, founder of fashion label Me+Em, five children


LOAD-DATE: February 17, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: BEN GURR FOR THE TIMESIn a family full of successful authors, Johnny Hornby's story is one of advertising industry success, which has seen him admired for the campaign for Tango, below


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: TIM



Copyright 2018 Times Newspapers Limited
All Rights Reserved


272 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Times (London)


February 17, 2018 Saturday  
Edition 2;
National Edition


Advert guru has little time for tech giants' excuses on extremist content;
Johnny Hornby has targets from online platforms to politicians in his sights, reports Alexandra Frean


BYLINE: Alexandra Frean


SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 53


LENGTH: 1303 words


Johnny Hornby saw nothing remotely satisfying when Unilever threatened this week to withdraw ads from Google and Facebook unless they properly policed extremist content on their platforms. The ad industry chief had been warning of just such a boycott for years, but didn't see this as a "told you so" moment. There's too much at stake.

It has been, the founder of The&Partnership argues, something akin to "the wild west with YouTube [owned by Google] and Facebook. If they are going to take people's advertising money, it's their duty to ensure that their media inventory is safe."

In the old media world, if somebody had sprayed swastikas on one of his posters, he would have had it down within the hour. So why can't digital platforms do the same and make sure that adverts do not appear alongside unpalatable or illegal content? He has little time for the excuse that with 400 hours of content uploaded to YouTube every minute, it's hard to police it all. 

"They don't need to enable the entire inventory to accept advertising. They could say, 'We will check the inventory and only when we know it's 100 per cent clear will we enable it to receive your advertising.' If behaving well means the tech platforms making less money, it's a price they should be willing to pay."

His warning against the two technology giants, which together account for more than half of Britain's digital advertising market, had focused on advertising fraud, where criminals create fake traffic of absolutely no value to advertisers. The scams are estimated to cost the industry $16.4billion a year. Yet Mr Hornby believes that, finally, the penny has dropped with Facebook and Google. "They've had a very good scare. They have genuinely recognised that if they want to take advertising, they have probably not got many more goes at this." Now representatives from the two companies visit him and his rivals virtually every week.

Already, however, the industry's attention is being diverted to new threats from different directions, not least the arrival on its doorstep of the big professional services and accountancy firms. Accenture, Deloitte, KPMG, McKinsey and PWC have been buying up ad agencies to take advantage of a seismic shift in the business landscape - "They have bought two or three times the number of digital advertising agencies in the US than the traditional holding companies have". And they also have an early advantage: the first people to get their foot in the door when corporations begin digital transformations are the Deloittes and Accentures of this world, who now like to roll in advertising as an additional service.

Then there is the advent of Europe's new GDPR data protection rules, which come into force in May. These herald another disruption to the advertising industry, tightening the rules on buying and selling customer data.

These extra competitive pressures could not have come at a worst time for adland's big holding companies, which had a terrible 2017. WPP, Publicis, Omnicom and Interpublic all suffered significant drops in their share prices as big consumer goods companies cut back on advertising.

Against this backdrop The&Partnership, which is 49 per cent-owned by WPP, doubled its revenue last year to £457 million and added brands such as Netflix to its client list, which also includes Toyota and News UK, publisher of The Times. It did this by adopting an unconventional "full service" approach, which brings together a package of services (media buying, data analytics, PR, creative and more) into one team with a single bottom line for each client. The teams then work in the client's offices, acting like rapid response units.

Mr Hornby cites his company's work for Toyota in Paris, where petrol and diesel cars are banned on days when the temperature tops 32C: "My team inside Toyota can see the weather forecast and if it's going to be really hot they can move all of the media money to early drivetime radio and tell every Parisian that if they drive a Toyota hybrid vehicle they are not affected by the ban."

Charming and chatty, Mr Hornby, 50, has been described as the smoothest act in adland. He displays an engaging mix of self-satisfaction and self-deprecating humour, neatly reflected in his anecdote of what a typical Hornby family Christmas might look like. "Nick [his halfbrother Nick Hornby, the novelist] might say, 'Oh, I've written this book about my obsession with Arsenal and it's going to be made into a movie and I'm going to be played by Colin Firth.' Gill [his sister Gill Hornby, the novelist] might say, 'I've written a novel about women at the school gates called The Hive.' Robert [Robert Harris, the novelist, married to Gill] might say, 'I've written a story about Hitler having won the war and a bungling detective in the Sixties uncovering the fact that there was a holocaust.' And I would say, 'We've propelled a man into a load of fruit with the line, "You know when you've been Tango'd." Everyone would laugh at me, apart from my mother, who would say, 'Well done, darling, aren't you clever.' " His mother is Sonia Beesley, the BBC journalist who got Margaret Thatcher to reveal that, as prime minister, she found time in the middle of the night to darn her husband Denis's socks. His late father was the industrialist Sir Derek Hornby, chairman of Rank-Xerox and the British Overseas Trade Board.

The Christmas anecdote speaks volumes about the frustrations of a man with a gilded life who harbours demons deep down. He seems profoundly disturbed about the dysfunctional state of British and American politics. He hates Brexit, President Trump and the Tories and is in despair about the Labour party's takeover by the hard Left.

"I think John McDonnell is the baddy, probably more than Corbyn, who is the mad old uncle. They will try to get out anybody who has a sniff of David Miliband about them," he says. This is, after all, the ad man who helped Tony Blair's new Labour to hold on to office in 2001 and 2005 and who remains a close associate of Lord (Peter) Mandelson.

So why not run for office himself? Any temptation is fleeting: "What I would love to do is to support through what I do well - marketing and branding - whoever the next Tony Blair is. If somebody emerged, a centrist, preferably for me centre left, with the next third way, I would love to lend my hand to help to make that happen."

Q&A Who is your mentor? My late father, Sir Derek Hornby. In any difficult situation I ask myself what he would do ... Does money motivate you? Whenever people think about money too much, things will go sour, whereas people who pursue innovative ideas with passion find they will be the better off in the end.

What was the most important event in your working life? Waking up the morning after the 2001 election, having finished our second campaign and starting out on our own.

Which person do you most admire? I will forever admire my two founding partners, Simon Clemmow and Charles Inge.

What is your favourite television programme? I don't watch much television other than Newsnight and Match of the Day, but I've become a binge consumer of box-sets. Big Little Lies, This Is Us, The Crown. The best ever is Friday Night Lights.

What does leadership mean to you? Making and taking the big decisions and in our business leading the innovation and taking calculated risks, because managing the status quo isn't attractive to me.

How do you relax? With five horses and five children, and if you ask my family they might say in that order.

CV Born: 1967, Gloucestershire Education: University of Edinburgh Career: 1991-94: Ogilvy & Mather; 1994-98: CDP; 1998-2001: managing director, TBWA; 2001: founding partner, CHI&Partners; 2013: chairman and chief executive, The&Partnership Family: Married to Clare Hornby, founder of fashion label Me+Em, five children


LOAD-DATE: February 17, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: BEN GURR FOR THE TIMESIn a family full of successful authors, Johnny Hornby's story is one of advertising industry success, which has seen him admired for the campaign for Tango, below


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: TIM

273 of 413 DOCUMENTS




telegraph.co.uk


February 12, 2018 Monday 3:01 PM GMT 


German court finds Facebook's data collection was illegal


BYLINE: By Margi Murphy


SECTION: TECHNOLOGY; Version:2


LENGTH: 680 words


Facebook's failure to make people aware that it was collecting their data for advertising purposes was illegal, a German court has found.

The Berlin Regional Court ruled that Facebook did not obtain consent from its users to use their information for its advertising goals, in accordance with German data protection law.

The ruling was seen as a win for the Federation of German Consumer Organisation, who have been locked in battle with the social network since 2015, claiming it breached consumer protection law because data sharing settings were turned on by default.  

"Facebook hides default settings that are not privacy-friendly in its privacy centre and does not provide sufficient information about this when users register," said the federation's litigation policy officer Heiko Dünkel.  "This does not meet the requirement for informed consent."

The tech giant stores information that a person has shared on their profile, through their activity on the website but also their web history while browsing other websites.

Facebook claims that users are made aware of what information it collects under its terms and conditions and that it allows people an easy way to manage their privacy settings. 

But judges ruled that all five of default privacy settings, which were investigated after the consumer watchdog raised concerns, were not lawful, as they did not constitute consent. One example included default location services, which are  already activated in the Facebook app with "ticks" already placed in boxes that allowed search engines to link to the user's timeline.

The court found that a further eight clauses in Facebook's terms of use were invalid. These included pre-formulated declarations of consent for Facebook to use the name and profile picture of users "for commercial, sponsored or related content" and to transfer their data to the US. 

However, it did not find any fault with Facebook's marketing as a "free" app. The watchdog objected to the use of the word because, according to Dünkel, "Consumers do pay to use Facebook. Maybe not in euros, but with their data. And this data is extremely valuable to the company."

Google, Facebook digital ad spend

Facebook said it would appeal the judgement, but it has implications for incoming General Data Protection Regulations which will come into force in May. 

"We are reviewing this recent decision carefully and are pleased that the court agreed with us on a number of issues. Our products and policies have changed a lot since this case was brought, and further changes to our terms and Data Policy are anticipated later this year in light of upcoming changes to the law," a spokesman said. 

"We work hard to ensure that our policies are clear and easy to understand, and that all aspects of the Facebook Service are in compliance with applicable law."

Companies found to be in breach of GDPR face a maximum penalty of 4pc of global annual turnover or (EURO)20m (£17.77m), dependant on which is greater. The new laws will replace the EU's Data Protection Act, granting more power to punish companies that fail to comply with new rules, which will allow individuals to withdraw consent over the information being used. Companies will need a paper trail that proves it collected personal information lawfully. 

Facebook announced more "transparent" privacy tools in anticipation of the European crackdown at the beginning of 2018. Although it did not make it entirely clear how it would show people how it tracks them around other websites. 

The latest transparency drive is one of several sweeping changes to how it communicates with users about its data collection, including a "privacy checkup" and privacy portal, all in response to incoming European data privacy laws.

In light of the new regulation, all eyes will be on Google, Twitter, Snapchat and Instagram, companies that have amassed huge sets of consumer data over the past years and will be expected to show exactly how they retrieved information, and whether each person agreed to their doing so. 


LOAD-DATE: February 12, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDTNS



Copyright 2018 Telegraph Media Group Limited
All Rights Reserved


274 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Sunday Times (London)


February 11, 2018 Sunday  
Edition 1;
Ireland


Keep up to data on protection;
Companies must comply with new EU rules by May if they want to be eligible to tender for state contracts, writes Sandra O'Connor


BYLINE: Sandra O'Connor


SECTION: BUSINESS AND MONEY;BUSINESS; Pg. 8


LENGTH: 1021 words


Siobhan Mockler first came across General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) in a Sunday newspaper last May. She had never heard of it. Her bosses at Copymoore, a 25-year-old office equipment business, had never heard of it either.

Already busy as the company's marketing executive, Mockler was put in charge of GDPR compliance. "I really shot myself in the foot with that one," she said. 

Yet it worked out tremendously. Copymoore is now fully GDPR compliant, and Mockler provides consultancy services to her SME clients on the same subject.

"The vast majority don't think it will have an impact on them," she said. An engineering firm told her the new rules did not apply, as it did not keep client data. "If it stores data on employees, then they do," she said.

GDPR comes into force on May 25. That is not much time to prepare for "a very complex piece of legislation", said Geraldine Keehan, a lawyer with Augustus Cullen Law, who felt businesses were taking a "head in the sand" approach.

The EU regulations create new data responsibilities for companies, give the public with new data rights - and, unlike in the previous regime, breaches can result in penalties of up to 4% of turnover.

Part of the reason small businesses have been slow to prepare for GDPR is because of the word "data", said Brian Honan, a cyber-security consultant.

"It would have been better called the General Human Protection Regulation, because it's not about protecting data," he said, "it's about protecting humans by protecting the data that is out there about them."

If, for example, a staff member loses a mobile phone with client data on it, you need to know how to respond.

But if SMEs are sluggish about GDPR, consumers are not. According to a survey from software company SAS, more than three-quarters (77%) of Irish adults plan to activate new rights over their personal data, including (66%) looking at the right to erase personal data held about them. More than one in four (26%) plan to do this in May.

While social media companies and financial services organisations topped the poll (62%) of businesses that people said they would request to remove personal data, 41% of respondents said they would also request personal data to be removed from small businesses such as retailers. Some 38% said they would request access to their personal data from cyrrent and previous employers.

"GDPR is the bane of my life," said Michael FitzGerald, founder of OnePage CRM, a sales application for small businesses. At almost every internal meeting he attends these days "it comes up - someone will say, 'What about the implications for GDPR?'" The Galway business has clients around the world, many in the US. As a result of GDPR, FitzGerald is splitting its database and building a new server so the company can have one database in Europe, under GDPR, and one in the US, which has different data protection rules.

He can foresee other issues. Cloudbased systems are increasingly designed to work together, with customer relationship management systems working alongside help desk software, or connecting to tools such as Mail Chimp. "You could end up synchronised between your own system and a system in the US, which is going to open up a whole new can of worms," said FitzGerald.

The implication for lead generation is another area of concern. "A load of AI [artificial intelligence] systems are being created with the express purpose of building up profiles on people, and that's going to go head to head with GDPR," he said. "That's just client-facing stuff. There are all your internal documentation processes to consider too, and people to be trained up to respond to instances where customers say, 'I want to retrieve all my data.'" This last could give "powers to trolls" to put businesses through hoops. "What's to stop them from asking to retrieve data multiple times a year?"

Such concerns are now coming to the fore at the Small Firms Association (SFA), which is running a series of GDPR information events, the next on March 9. "For our first one in January, we were afraid very few people would turn up. In the end, 150 people did," said SFA director Sven Spollen-Behrens, who sees interest growing as the deadline approaches.

Members want to know the practical steps they need to take to be compliant. The SFA has created a tool to help on its website. "It is just a bunch of spreadsheets but it allows people to put a structure on the task ahead of them," he said. GDPR compliance also requires businesses to use language in websites and in documents that is easily understood. VisibleThread was set up in 2008 and to date has worked mostly with US state agencies. According to the software company's chief executive, Fergal McGovern, the advent of GDPR is driving demand from European SMEs too.

Clear terms and conditions will also protect businesses in the event of litigation. "If a customer isn't going to read a simple set of terms and conditions, then that will by and large be seen by a judge as their fault," said McGovern.

"But if the terms and conditions are opaque, the fault will be seen to reside with the business."

Privacy policies must clearly explain what data you are collecting and for what purpose. If you do not have permission for the data you are holding, this must be sought. Noncompliance could prevent your business winning public contracts. "Increasingly, we are seeing that GDPR or formal policies around data protection are part of the standard terms and conditions of a tender," said Tony Corrigan of TenderScout. "Many tenders will place the buyers in a position where they have to deal with personal data, they can be expected to put the onus for compliance onto the supplier as part of the tender qualification criteria."

On a recent Bus Eireann contract, a client contracted a GDPR consultant to audit its systems and put in place a GDPRreadiness strategy to ensure that the company was eligible to compete for the contract, said Corrigan.

"Today, being GDPR-ready is a differentiator for most businesses, but after May I expect it to be a mandatory requirement for many tenders for government contracts," he said.


LOAD-DATE: February 11, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: McGovern says clear terms and conditions on GDPR-compliant websites will help to protect businesses in the event of litigation


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: STS



Copyright 2018 Times Newspapers Limited

275 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Sunday Times (London)


February 11, 2018 Sunday  
Edition 1;
National Edition


TEACH YOURSELF TO ... UNDERSTAND GDPR


SECTION: BUSINESS AND MONEY;BUSINESS; Pg. 11


LENGTH: 241 words


Most businesses collect digital data about their customers. Whether a hi-tech start-up or an online florist, they store sensitive information such as addresses and credit card or bank details. 

A new European Union regulation on this wealth of information has the potential to cause trouble for entrepreneurs. The general data protection regulation (GDPR), which was adopted in 2016 and comes into force on May 25, will give people the right to access any information about themselves held by companies. The maximum penalty for breaching the rules will be (EURO)20m (£17.5m) or 4% of global turnover, whichever is higher.

Though it is a Brussels regulation, the provisions are included in the Data Protection Bill, currently going through the Houses of Parliament, so it will be unaffected by Brexit.

GDPR will apply to all businesses that store personal details. Despite this, nearly a third of directors are unaware of the shake-up, according to a survey by the Institute of Directors. Stephen Bailey of the cyber-security consultancy NCC said: "We're surprised at how little notice business owners have taken of GDPR."

Companies may not be aware of how much data they hold, not only on customers, but also on job applicants and suppliers, for example. Bailey said it was essential to make data easily searchable. "The Information Commissioner's Office will accept no excuse for those that fail to do so as there's been two years to prepare."

Liam Kelly


LOAD-DATE: February 11, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: STS



Copyright 2018 Times Newspapers Limited
All Rights Reserved


276 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Sunday Times (London)


February 11, 2018 Sunday  
Edition 1;
National Edition


How businesses of all sizes can bolster their defences;
BT COMMENT


BYLINE: Alexander Moses


SECTION: BUSINESS AND MONEY;BUSINESS; Pg. 9


LENGTH: 224 words


Although large businesses, BT included, collectively succeed in blocking billions of cyberattacks every year, no business can ever claim to be 100 per cent secure. The sheer scale of the global cybercrime industry and the rapid rate of evolving threats mean that developing a robust cybersecurity strategy should be a priority for businesses of all types and sizes. 

As our use of technology is constantly changing and creating new challenges, so too are the tools and methods being employed by cybercriminals. To stay ahead, and to comply with the new GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation) that comes into force in May, organisations need to adopt an informationcentric approach to security, gaining a full understanding of where their sensitive data resides, how it's stored, how it's transmitted through the network and who has access to it.

While there is no one-size-fits-all approach for addressing the challenges and opportunities posed by cybercrime, businesses must get the basics right: strong passwords, firewalls, antivirus software, regular patching and training for sta. Outsourcing some aspects of your IT security estate to a trusted partner can also help businesses bolster their defences. Our report, "The Cyber Security Journey - From Denial to Opportunity", gives advice to help businesses prepare for the future of cybercrime.


LOAD-DATE: February 11, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: STS



Copyright 2018 Times Newspapers Limited
All Rights Reserved


277 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Sunday Times (London)


February 11, 2018 Sunday  
Edition 2;
National Edition


How businesses of all sizes can bolster their defences;
BT COMMENT


BYLINE: Alexander Moses


SECTION: BUSINESS AND MONEY;BUSINESS; Pg. 9


LENGTH: 225 words


'Although large businesses, BT included, collectively succeed in blocking billions of cyberattacks every year, no business can ever claim to be 100 per cent secure. The sheer scale of the global cybercrime industry and the rapid rate of evolving threats mean that developing a robust cybersecurity strategy should be a priority for businesses of all types and sizes. 

As our use of technology is constantly changing and creating new challenges, so too are the tools and methods being employed by cybercriminals. To stay ahead, and to comply with the new GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation) that comes into force in May, organisations need to adopt an informationcentric approach to security, gaining a full understanding of where their sensitive data resides, how it's stored, how it's transmitted through the network and who has access to it.

While there is no one-size-fits-all approach for addressing the challenges and opportunities posed by cybercrime, businesses must get the basics right: strong passwords, firewalls, antivirus software, regular patching and training for sta. Outsourcing some aspects of your IT security estate to a trusted partner can also help businesses bolster their defences. Our report, "The Cyber Security Journey - From Denial to Opportunity", gives advice to help businesses prepare for the future of cybercrime.'

The Sunday Times (London)


February 11, 2018 Sunday  
Edition 1;
Scotland


TEACH YOURSELF TO ... UNDERSTAND GDPR


BYLINE: Michael Glackin


SECTION: BUSINESS AND MONEY;BUSINESS; Pg. 11


LENGTH: 241 words


Most businesses collect digital data about their customers. Whether a hi-tech start-up or an online florist, they store sensitive information such as addresses and credit card or bank details. 

A new European Union regulation on this wealth of information has the potential to cause trouble for entrepreneurs. The general data protection regulation (GDPR), which was adopted in 2016 and comes into force on May 25, will give people the right to access any information about themselves held by companies. The maximum penalty for breaching the rules will be (EURO)20m (£17.5m) or 4% of global turnover, whichever is higher.

Though it is a Brussels regulation, the provisions are included in the Data Protection Bill, currently going through the Houses of Parliament, so it will be unaffected by Brexit.

GDPR will apply to all businesses that store personal details. Despite this, nearly a third of directors are unaware of the shake-up, according to a survey by the Institute of Directors. Stephen Bailey of the cyber-security consultancy NCC said: "We're surprised at how little notice business owners have taken of GDPR."

Companies may not be aware of how much data they hold, not only on customers, but also on job applicants and suppliers, for example. Bailey said it was essential to make data easily searchable. "The Information Commissioner's Office will accept no excuse for those that fail to do so as there's been two years to prepare."

The Sunday Times (London)

Edition 1;
Scotland


How businesses of all sizes can bolster their defences;
BT COMMENT


BYLINE: Alexander Moses


SECTION: BUSINESS AND MONEY;BUSINESS; Pg. 9


LENGTH: 232 words


'Although large businesses, BT included, collectively succeed in blocking billions of cyberattacks every year, no business can ever claim to be 100 per cent secure. The sheer scale of the global cybercrime industry and the rapid rate of evolving threats mean that developing a robust cybersecurity strategy should be a priority for businesses of all types and sizes. 

As our use of technology is constantly changing and creating new challenges, so too are the tools and methods being employed by cybercriminals. To stay ahead, and to comply with the new GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation) that comes into force in May, organisations need to adopt an informationcentric approach to security, gaining a full understanding of where their sensitive data resides, how it's stored, how it's transmitted through the network and who has access to it.

While there is no one-size-fits-all approach for addressing the challenges and opportunities posed by cybercrime, businesses must get the basics right: strong passwords, firewalls, antivirus software, regular patching and training for sta. Outsourcing some aspects of your IT security estate to a trusted partner can also help businesses bolster their defences. Our report, "The Cyber Security Journey - From Denial to Opportunity", gives advice to help businesses prepare for the future of cybercrime.'

Find out more at www.bt.com/securitysolutions

280 of 413 DOCUMENTS




telegraph.co.uk


February 11, 2018 Sunday 5:37 PM GMT 


Facebook tool can judge whether you are middle class


BYLINE: By Margi Murphy


SECTION: TECHNOLOGY; Version:1


LENGTH: 348 words


Facebook has found a way to determine a users' social class, using a method which proves to be far more sophisticated than a perusal of the members signed up to its Avocado Appreciation Society page.  

The social network has plans to train its artificially intelligent algorithms to predict whether someone is "working class", "middle class" or "upper class" dependent on a variety of factors, according to patent filing published in February.

These factors include the amount of devices a person has signed into the social network on - with more devices suggesting greater wealth. Others include a person's location, their level of education and their travel history.

It is unclear whether Facebook is actively using the class prediction tool currently but it is transparent about how it groups its two billion users into demographics for targeted advertising.

For example, its computer algorithms judge whether a person is more likely to be susceptible to travel advertising if they have tagged themselves in different locations and liked pages about travel. 

It is also able to track a person's digital footprint and could detect, for example, if someone has been viewing external travel websites while they are logging into Facebook.

Travel companies will pay Facebook to send targeted adverts to that group of people.  While users can remove themselves from these categories under its privacy controls, the feature is turned on by default. 

If the patent design ever makes an appearance, Facebook may have to tweak its data collection methods to make sure it is compliant with the new General Data Protection Regulation, coming in next year. Companies found to be in breach of GDPR face a maximum penalty of 4pc of global annual turnover or (EURO)20m (£17.77m), dependant on which is greater.

The new laws will replace the EU's Data Protection Act, granting more power to punish companies that fail to comply with new rules, which will allow individuals to withdraw consent over the information being used. Companies will need a paper trail that proves it collected personal information lawfully. 


LOAD-DATE: February 11, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDTNS



Copyright 2018 Telegraph Media Group Limited
All Rights Reserved


281 of 413 DOCUMENTS




Daily Mirror


February 9, 2018 Friday  
Edition 1;
Ireland


Billion euro compo bill on the cards for the State;
3 million may sue over privacy law


BYLINE: FERGHAL BLANEY


SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2


LENGTH: 321 words


THREE million people may be able to sue the State as the controversial PSC identity cards allegedly breach new European privacy laws.

Legal actions could start within weeks and it has been claimed the authorities might have to pay out billions of euro. 

The cost of the cards scheme has topped (EURO)60million and been criticised as an invasion of individuals' privacy.

Solicitor Simon McGarr yesterday told an Oireachtas Committee the PSCs fall foul of the EU's General Data Protection Regulation.

He added: "The GDPR is ticking down to coming into force in May, what that allows for is that States will be liable for non-financial loss breaches of data protection rights.

"If it is the case that it [the PSC scheme] is not compliant - and we're told it contains approximately three million people's details - that would indicate each one of those three million people have a claim on the State.

REMEDY

"And the remedy has not been set out in the terms of the GDPR, it's a remedy in terms of financial compensation, that's available through the courts.

"Any number, the court might consider appropriate for that type of breach multiplied by three million is a very large number."

The Irish Council for Civil Liberties has called for at least the suspension of the PSC project as it has serious concerns that it exceeds its remit and is not necessary.

It said: "The Government has failed to respond to the clear privacy concerns regarding the PSC and has instead invested further funds for promoting a project already over budget."

A Department of Social Protection statement said it does not accept Mr McGarr's claims.

It added: "The Department is satisfied that there is a comprehensive legal basis in place for registering people's identity and for the sharing of that identity data with specified public bodies."

news@irishmirror.ie

IRISH MIRROR COMMENT: PAGE 10

(EURO)60m Cost of the controversial PSC scheme that has been met by taxpayers


LOAD-DATE: February 9, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

The Guardian(London)


February 6, 2018 Tuesday 12:50 PM GMT 


EU data protection law may end up protecting scammers, experts warn


BYLINE: Alex Hern


SECTION: TECHNOLOGY; Version:1


LENGTH: 21 words


WHOIS, one of oldest tools on internet for verifying real identities, at risk of being killed due to tough new GDPR regulations  


LOAD-DATE: February 6, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBGNS



Copyright 2018 The Guardian, a division of Transcontinental Media Group Inc.

283 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Daily Telegraph (London)


February 5, 2018 Monday  
Edition 1;
National Edition


Goliaths battle it out to be the first $1 trillion global giant;
This could be the year that Amazon, Google or Apple could make corporate history, says Margi Murphy


BYLINE: Margi Murphy


SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 5


LENGTH: 1348 words


Amazon, Google and Apple are all in the running to become the first ever company to be valued at one trillion dollars, with analysts believing we could see history being made as early as this year.

Becoming a "trillion dollar company" has implications beyond than the business world. It could cement customer loyalty to these brands, enhancing a perception of quality. It will also throw up myriad questions about competition, regulation, and privacy. Greater scale could mean these companies are able to create more creative products and services. We could see technology giants like Apple ramping up their aims to tackle major healthcare issues like diabetes, or Google stepping up its secretive artificial intelligence division. On the other hand, greater ability to buy out rivals could grant a single company more power than ever before, and is a potential concern for governments struggling to regulate new technologies. "We tend to forget what a $1 trillion market cap means: that's 1,000 unicorns," says Thomas Husson, research analyst at Gartner.

The Daily Telegraph has delved into the economics behind three big names in technology: Google, Amazon and Apple for clues as to which one will hit the historic milestone first. 

Amazon: Strengths Amazon reported the largest profit in its history on Thursday evening. The retailer drew millions of new customers to its Prime subscription, which offers next-day delivery and other benefits including its Netflixstyle streaming. Shares rose more than 6pc and chief executive, Jeff Bezos, now the richest man in the world, added billions to his fortune. Amazon could be on course to take the trillion mark thanks to its mammoth presence and a series of smart, future-proof investments, which have set a foundation upon which the company is certain to soar. Amazon is widely recognised as transforming retail through its marketplace, but it also has a consumer electronics division and a booming cloud storage company - all ripe for future growth.

Weaknesses Amazon has failed to fully crack the entertainment market and its streaming service, Amazon Prime Video, has yet to overtake Netflix despite big investments in exclusive series like Mr Robot. It makes famously paltry profits given its size and has yet to pay a dividend. Amazon is the largest cloud provider - providing computing power needed for businesses around the world. But just as large enterprises were considering paying Amazon a fee to host all its systems and data rather instead of using servers on their premise, the Spectre bug hit the headlines. Prospective AWS customers may be thinking twice about placing their sensitive information into a shared cloud if they believe there is even the smallest chance it might be visible to others.

Opportunities Amazon has correctly singled out the demand for near instant shipping as consumers turn to online shopping. Huge investments in its super-fast delivery service, including using drones to deliver packages within 30 minutes, will keep customers visiting www.Amazon.co.uk even if competitors step up e-commerce. Amazon is also growing its advertising offering, which grew 60pc in the last quarter.

Threats A failure to tackle music and entertainment issues might sink its voice assistant smart speakers. Amazon Echo devices could be challenged by Apple's HomePod, due to launch next week. Plus, an ongoing feud with Google may throw a spanner in the works. The row saw Google remove YouTube from Amazon's Echo and Fire streaming devices. Without popular streaming apps, the smart speakers could fall out of favour.

Google: Strengths Google, now a subsidiary of parent company Alphabet, is one of the most recognised brands in the world. Its primary business as the information sorter of choice and miner of the world's data to be converted into ad revenue is likely to continue for the foreseeable future, and it has the cash to absorb rival technologies that threaten it.

Weaknesses Google has seen its traffic acquisition costs rising over the past 12 months, which could spell trouble for 2018. These costs are payments sent to other companies to direct consumer and business traffic to its website. Consumers are increasingly searching across a mix of mobile, desktop and tablets, bumping up costs, so much so that rising advertising revenues toward the end of 2017 were not enough to offset them.

In light of this Google announced surprisingly disappointing earnings on Thursday evening, sparking a share price drop. "Alphabet is heavily, heavily reliant on Google advertising revenue and there is creeping competition in the advertising business (Facebook for some time, and Amazon also creeping in)," says Forrester analyst Colin Colburn. "So that will be an interesting story to see how it plays out over the coming quarters."

Opportunities Google has expanded into cloud storage and consumer electronics to rival Apple. Its flagship smartphone, the Google Pixel 2, was widely regarded as one of the best phones on the market upon its launch in October last year, and a worthy opponent to the iPhone X. Its purchase of smartphone manufacturer HTC suggests big plans for its hardware division. In its latest earnings report, Google said hardware sales doubled on the same period last year. Though we have been here before: it bought Motorola for $12.5bn in 2012 and sold it for $2.9bn two years later, having extracted the patents it wanted.

Threats Extremism, hate speech and cyber bullying have put Google in the spotlight. These have transformed its perception from a Californian start-up done good to a negligent platform that puts users in harm's way. Despite promising sales of its smart speaker after its launch in the end of 2017, which was boosted by heavy discounts, it might struggle to contend with Amazon's Echo and the new HomePod.

Data, once widely regarded as "the new oil" might cause Google to come unstuck. Incoming General Data Protection Regulations (GDPR) may see a clamping down on how information Google retrieves through its search engine, Android operating system and smart speaker can be used.

If Google falls foul of GDPR it faces a maximum penalty of 4pc of global annual turnover or (EURO)20m (£17.6m), depending on which is greater. Meanwhile increasing pressure from regulators and the European Union could suck up more cash, with Google forced to pay up billions of dollars in antitrust fines.

Apple: Strengths Apple is the world's biggest company, overtaking South Korean electronics giant Samsung to become the largest seller of smartphones. On Thursday evening, it posted the largest quarterly profit of all time, despite a fall in iPhone sales. A company that sells less, but earns more, signals greater things to come. Sales for Apple Watch and Apple TV have also improved.

Weaknesses Depending on how you interpret the results, selling fewer of the expensive iPhone X is either genius or a red flag. Generally, appetite for smartphones appears to be falling slightly, which means Apple may no longer be able to count on huge sales every year it brings out a new version. Sales of Apple Mac computers have also fallen.

Opportunities Apple's hotly anticipated HomePod will launch next week, with the company taking a big step into the market for smart speakers. The £319 smart speaker will take on Amazon's Echo and Google Home, costing significantly more than both. But it is likely to appeal to its core customer base, who are looking for high quality design and sound.

Threats Apple has also suffered a bad press. It apologised after it emerged that it was slowing down iPhones with older batteries, a suspicion long held by customers who were convinced they were being nudged to buy newer models. Apple said that it slowed older batteries to stop phones from shutting down by throttling them in a software update last year. It is now offering discounts on its battery replacement service. "Extraordinary growth and bigger profit than we've seen before means Apple is definitely on track to be a trillion," says Sucharita Kodali, analyst at Forrester. "First or not remains to be seen."

The Guardian(London)


February 5, 2018 Monday 10:00 AM GMT 


New UK data protection rules are a cynical attack on immigrants;
Non-nationals subject to an immigration procedure are to lose the right to access data held about them, in a discriminatory move that worries the European parliament


BYLINE: Claude Moraes


SECTION: OPINION; Version:1


LENGTH: 736 words


In September, I warned in a Guardian opinion article that the Brexit process could have the effect of allowing the UK government to bring in more draconian and discriminatory immigration laws, harking back to the 70s and 80s.

Many people wondered how this would happen and the answer was that Brexit would allow the sweeping away of advances like the abolition of the hated primary purpose immigration rule made illegal by the European court of justice. 

But now a far more profound and deliberate line of attack is being adopted by the British government in its national immigration policy, under cover of implementing the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), one of the biggest modernisations of data protection law anywhere in the world. Simply put, a new clause in the government's data protection bill, which implements the GDPR, would remove the rights of people who are subject to an immigration procedure to know what public authorities hold about them and to rectify or delete erroneous or unlawfully collected personal data.

The UK government is acting under the cover of the complexity of data protection law and the chaotic Brexit negotiations

It would affect individuals who are not UK nationals, including nationals of EU member states resident in the UK.

This is an alarming development and anyone who understands immigration law or data protection will realise that this makes it impossible for individuals involved in immigration disputes to obtain their personal information from the Home Office, something which is essential to any administrative dispute. In addition, these measures would also potentially affect the 3 million EU citizens who will soon face new processes to register their residence after Brexit.

We know the deliberate intent of the government here, because similar blanket exemptions have been attempted before but rejected by the House of Commons as far back as 1983. The then home secretary Leon Brittan wanted to make immigration control " a legitimate category for exemption ".

It was roundly condemned in parliament at a time when discriminatory immigration rules were otherwise accepted.

The discriminatory situation being created is being seen with great concern in the European parliament. The UK data protection authority and digital rights organisations are sounding the alarm because of how this measure would disproportionately interfere with the fundamental rights of non-nationals resident in the UK. This would mean that the UK would not uphold the adequate levels of protection required for the exchange of personal data between the UK and other EU states.

Related: Home Office pays out £15,500 to asylum seeker over data breach

Not only do these proposals stand to flout the important fundamental rights protections of millions of individuals, in the process undermining the already low level of trust of EU citizens in the UK with regard to their rights, they would also lower the UK's chances of obtaining an adequacy arrangement with the EU. This would also make it harder for the UK to continue to obtain information from several EU information systems, in particular those related to immigration, because of the lack of adequate protection.

If the UK fails to obtain an adequacy arrangement from the EU, it would lose free access to data from nations such as the US, which has negotiated an agreement with the EU called the EU-US Privacy Shield. This would have major real-world economic and commercial impact on the UK.

So, in essence, what is happening here is that the UK government, under the cover of the complexity of data protection law in particular, and its chaotic Brexit negotiations in general, is seeking to create damaging new discriminatory national immigration restrictions. In addition, the government is undermining the implementation of the most important piece of EU data protection law ever drafted, which will have the knock-on effect of undermining the ability of the UK to ensure the free flow of data post-Brexit. This, as people will have seen this week, could have major economic and security implications for the UK.

This issue should alarm all those who care about human rights, a fair immigration system, and a professional and transparent implementation of data protection rules in the UK.

· Claude Moraes is a Labour MEP, representing London. He chairs the European parliament's civil liberties, justice and home affairs committee


LOAD-DATE: February 5, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBGNS



Copyright 2018 The Guardian, a division of Transcontinental Media Group Inc.
All Rights Reserved


285 of 413 DOCUMENTS




telegraph.co.uk


February 4, 2018 Sunday 9:00 PM GMT 


Bedroom hackers bigger threat than Russia, regulator says


BYLINE: By Hayley Dixon


SECTION: NEWS; Version:1


LENGTH: 654 words


Government departments should be more worried about teenage bedroom hackers than state-sponsored cyber terrorists, the Information Commissioner has warned. 

In a speech to the heads of the civil service and other public bodies, Elizabeth Denham said that most breaches are preventable and bosses should consider the reputational damage as well as financial losses.

 But rather than panicking about rogue states such as Russia hacking into their systems, civil servants should plan to protect themselves against teenage boys who attack simply to show that they are able to, the regulator warned.  

"We make a mistake if we throw up our hands and worry about state sponsored attacks - we know those are rare," Ms Denham said.

"You should be worrying about the malicious kid in his bedroom who hacks in to your system because he can. Or the opportunistic thief who understands the value of the data you hold and knows how to get his hands on it. Because you left the door wide open."

Her comments come amid rising concern about the impact of a state-sponsored attack on Britain's public services, particularly from Russia. Boris Johnson, the Foreign Secretary, recently warned the Kremlin that Britain would react in kind to any cyber attack. 

In reality many of the most high profile attacks have proven to come from much less powerful sources. 

Kane Gamble, who is currently awaiting sentence, was just 15 when he gained access to the computers of America's top spy chiefs, including the head of CIA, from his Leicestershire bedroom.  

Ms Denham told the Association of Chief Executives and the Public Chairs' Forum that despite complaints about resources in the public sector, cyber breaches such as the Wannacry attack on the NHS cost more in the long run .

The international ransomware attack disrupted  more than a third of trusts in England and saw 6,900 NHS appointments cancelled. 

Ms Denham said: "I ask you to consider the risks. Think of the true cost of a cyber breach, for example.

"It will cost you money but it will also cost you your reputation, trust, social licence. This is collateral damage.

"Yet most cyber breaches and attacks are preventable. The high profile attacks on TalkTalk and Carphone Warehouse would not have happened if they had put rudimentary protections in place. And if NHS systems had been patched and up to date, they would have been protected from Wannacry."

The EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), a framework with greater scope and much tougher punishments for those who fail to comply with new rules around the storage and handling of personal data, will replace the Data Protection Act in May.

Ms Denham said that the new regulations brings the legislation "in line with our 21st century world". 

"It gives greater control to people about how their data is used and it compels organisations to be transparent and account for their actions," she said during the speech on Friday. 

She added: "This is about restoring trust and confidence. Only one in five people in the UK trust organisations to look after their data. That's not good enough."

The Information Commissioner's Office (ICO), which is responsible for punishing any breaches of the rules, will receive more reports of cyber security breaches and more complaints as people are more aware of their rights, she said. 

"Sometimes when I speak to the private sector, I can sense the panic, but also the incentive to get it right. So many businesses feel like they are starting from scratch - it's one of the reasons why we've set up helplines and targeted resources to help them prepare," Ms Denham said.

 "Sometimes when I speak to the public sector, I can sense complacency. Because you know data protection. It's been part of the furniture for years. Now it's time to redecorate."

She encouraged bosses to take the opportunity to retrain their staff and to open up transparency and accountability on how personal information is used. 


LOAD-DATE: February 4, 2018


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDTNS



Copyright 2018 Telegraph Media Group Limited
All Rights Reserved


286 of 413 DOCUMENTS




telegraph.co.uk


February 2, 2018 Friday 12:56 PM GMT 


Google, Apple or Amazon: which will be the first to hit a record $1 trillion valuation? 


BYLINE: By Margi Murphy


SECTION: TECHNOLOGY; Version:6


LENGTH: 1428 words


Amazon, Google and Apple are all in the running to become the first ever company to be valued at one trillion dollars, with analysts believing we could see history being made as early as this year.

Becoming a "trillion dollar company" will have implications beyond than the business world. It could cement customer loyalty to these brands, enhancing a perception of quality. It will also throw up myriad questions about competition, regulation, and privacy. 

Greater scale could mean these companies are able to create more creative products and services. We could see technology giants like Apple ramping up their aims to tackle major healthcare issues like diabetes, or Google stepping up its secretive  artificial intelligence division .

On the other hand, greater ability to buy out rivals could grant a single company more power than ever before, and is a potential concern for governments struggling to regulate new technologies. "We tend to forget what a $1 trillion market cap means: that's 1,000 unicorns," says Thomas Husson, research analyst at Gartner.  

The race to one trillion dollars - Apple Google and Amazon

The Daily Telegraph has delved into the economics behind three big names in technology: Google, Amazon and Apple for clues as to which one will hit the historic milestone first. 

Amazon

Strengths

Amazon reported the largest profit in its history on Thursday evening. The retailer drew millions of new customers to its Prime subscription, which offers next-day delivery and other benefits including its Netflix-style streaming. Shares rose more than 6pc and chief executive, Jeff Bezos, now the richest man in the world, added billions to his fortune.

Amazon could be on course to take the trillion mark thanks to its mammoth presence and a series of smart, future-proof investments, which have set a foundation upon which the company is certain to soar. Amazon is widely recognised as transforming retail through its marketplace, but it also has a consumer electronics division and a booming cloud storage company - all ripe for future growth. 

Alexa products compared

Weaknesses

Amazon has failed to fully crack the entertainment market and its streaming service, Amazon Prime Video, has yet to overtake Netflix despite big investments in exclusive series like Mr Robot. It makes famously paltry profits given its size and has yet to pay a dividend. Amazon is the largest cloud provider - providing computing power needed for businesses around the world. But just as large enterprises were considering paying Amazon a fee to host all its systems and data rather instead of using servers on their premise, the Spectre bug hit the headlines. Prospective AWS customers may be thinking twice about placing their sensitive information into a shared cloud if they believe there is even the smallest chance it might be visible to others.

Opportunities 

Amazon has correctly singled out the demand for near instant shipping as consumers turn to online shopping. Huge investments in its super-fast delivery service, including using drones to deliver packages within 30 minutes, will keep customers visiting Amazon.co.uk even if competitors step up e-commerce. Amazon is also growing its advertising offering, which grew 60 per cent in the last quarter.

Threats

A failure to tackle music and entertainment issues might sink its voice assistant smart speakers. Amazon Echo devices could be challenged by Apple's HomePod, due to launch next week. Plus, an ongoing feud with Google may throw a spanner in the works. The rowsaw  Google remove YouTube from Amazon's Echo and Fire streaming devices . Without popular streaming apps, the smart speakers could fall out of favour .

Google

Strengths

Google, now a subsidiary of parent company Alphabet, is one of the most recognised brands in the world. Its primary business as the information sorter of choice and miner of the world's data to be converted into ad revenue is likely to continue for the foreseeable future, and it has the cash to absorb rival technologies that threaten it.

Weaknesses

Google has seen its traffic acquisition costs rising over the past 12 months, which could spell trouble for 2018.

These costs are payments sent to other companies to direct consumer and business traffic to its website. Consumers are increasingly searching across a mix of mobile, desktop and tablets, bumping up costs, so much so that rising advertising revenues toward the end of 2017 were not enough to offset them. In light of this Google announced surprisingly disappointing earnings on Thursday evening, sparking a share price drop.

"Alphabet is heavily, heavily reliant on Google advertising revenue and there is creeping competition in the advertising business (Facebook for some time, and Amazon also creeping in)," says Forrester analyst Colin Colburn.

"So that will be an interesting story to see how it plays out over the coming quarters."

The best smartspeakers, from Amazon Echo to Google Home

Opportunities

Google has expanded into cloud storage and consumer electronics to rival Apple. Its flagship smartphone, the Google Pixel 2, was widely regarded as one of the best phones on the market upon its launch in October last year, and a worthy opponent to the iPhone X.

Its purchase of smartphone manufacturer HTC suggests big plans for its hardware division. In its latest earnings report, Google said hardware sales doubled on the same period last year. Though we have been here before: it bought Motorola for $12.5bn in 2012 and sold it for $2.9bn two years later, having extracted the patents it wanted.

Threats

Extremism, hate speech and cyber bullying have put Google in the spotlight. These have transformed its perception from a Californian start-up done good to a negligent platform that puts users in harm's way.

Despite promising sales of its smart speaker after its launch in the end of 2017, which was boosted by heavy discounts, it might struggle to contend with Amazon's Echo and the new HomePod .

Data, once widely regarded as "the new oil" might cause Google to come unstuck. Incoming General Data Protection Regulations (GDPR) may see a clamping down on how information Google retrieves through its search engine, Android operating system and smart speaker can be used. If Google falls foul of GDPR it faces a maximum penalty of 4pc of global annual turnover or (EURO)20m (£17.6m), depending on which is greater.

Meanwhile increasing pressure from regulators and the European Union could suck up more cash, with Google forced to pay up billions of dollars in antitrust fines .

Apple

Strengths

Apple is the world's biggest company, overtaking South Korean electronics giant Samsung to become the largest seller of smartphones. On Thursday evening, it posted the largest quarterly profit of all time, despite a fall in iPhone sales. A company that sells less, but earns more, signals greater things to come. Sales for Apple Watch and Apple TV have also improved. 

Weaknesses 

Depending on how you interpret the results, selling fewer of the expensive iPhone X is either genius or a red flag. Generally, appetite for smartphones appears to be falling slightly, which means Apple may no longer be able to count on huge sales every year it brings out a new version.

Sales of Apple Mac computers have also fallen as people spend less. 

Worldwide iPhone sales

Opportunities

Apple's hotly anticipated HomePod will launch next week, with the company taking a big step into the market for smart speakers. The £319 smart speaker will take on Amazon's Echo and Google Home, costing significantly more than both. But it is likely to appeal to its core customer base, who are looking for high quality design and sound. 

Threats

Apple has also suffered bad press in the last year. It apologised after it emerged that it was slowing down iPhones with older batteries, a suspicion long held by customers who were convinced they were being nudged to buy newer models. Apple said that it slowed older batteries to stop phones from shutting down by throttling them in a software update last year. It is now offering discounts on its battery replacement service. 

"Extraordinary growth and bigger profit than we've seen before means Apple is definitely on track to be a trillion," says Sucharita Kodali, analyst at Forrester. 

"First or not remains to be seen."

mirror.co.uk


February 1, 2018 Thursday 12:45 PM GMT 


Some porn sites will now require your name and address before you can use them - full list revealed;
The Digital Economy Act 2018 means these sites have to prove you're 18


BYLINE: By Jeff Parsons


SECTION: TECHNOLOGY; Version:1


LENGTH: 415 words


New laws set to come into force in April will mean that popular porn sites like PornHub and RedTube will require users to sign up with their names and addresses before letting them watch videos. 

The rules are a result of the Digital Economy Act 2018 and will store names, phone numbers, addresses and dates under a new system called AgeID.

Which basically mean if you want to access a porn site, you'll need to create a username and password first.

CamSoda launches the 'ultimate adult experience' where users mimic sex with models through a combination of VR and sex dolls

The laws have targeted pron giant Mindgeek, which operates the following sites - all of which will now require your name and address:

Unsurprisingly, some other porn providers aren't too happy about it.

"You can imagine how much data that is going to give MindGeek, if they're going to have stats on what people click on, what porn sites people click on, what they pay for," said porn site owner Pandora Blake at an Open Rights Group meeting in London last year.

"Once you've got a MindGeek login, you're going to be giving them your entire web browsing history, because they're going to be able to track every time you log in to anything."

Will the new restrictions stop you watching porn?

People who regularly 'sext' their partner are more insecure in their relationship, study reveals

Privacy campaigners are naturally concerned about what might happen in the event of a security breach. Last month, VR porn site SinVR was hacked and the details of 20,000 users was stolen.

But Mindgeek says that the new AgeID platform has been built from the ground up to protect user's privacy and be fully compliant with GDPR.

"We do not store any personal data entered during the age-verification process," a spokesperson said.

"Due to the encrypted nature of AgeID's login credentials, such data cannot be exposed in the unlikely event of a hack."

VR porn site is HACKED, exposing names, emails and download details of 20,000 randy users

These new age verification rules will be policed by the British Board of Film Classification (BBFC) which also polices the age ratings that are given to mainstream films.

Jim Killock, executive director of the privacy group Open Rights Group said: "The BBFC will struggle to ensure that Age Verification is safe, secure and anonymous.

"They are powerless to ensure people's privacy."
