The Sunday Times (London)


July 2, 2017 Sunday  
Edition 1;
Ireland


Don't let red tape make you feel blue;
The regulatory environment can make enterprise a chore, learns Sandra O'Connell


BYLINE: Sandra O'Connell


SECTION: BUSINESS AND MONEY;BUSINESS; Pg. 8


LENGTH: 1118 words


This year Jack Parsons, a business and law student, finished his degree, participated on a Bord Bia business accelerator and won a UCD Startup Stars award for O'Kale Krisps, the kale snack business he set up with fellow student Oisin McElhinney.

His business education is only just beginning. His first lesson: how to cope with red tape.

"We have just taken on our first staff member," said Parsons. "It's only part time, yet there are all sorts of employer's PRSI and insurance involved. We are learning as we go."

The regulatory burden takes in tax, health and safety, the environment, data protection, employment and company law - and weighs heavily on the owners of small businesses. 

According to a survey by the Small Firms Association (SFA), 10% of business owners rated bureaucracy as the biggest risk facing their business.

"Part of the problem is that it takes all sorts of different guises," said Linda Barry, the SFA acting director.

The latest employer obligation is the general data protection regulation (GDPR), a Europen Union directive which is due to be implemented within 12 months. The rules introduce tougher fines for non-compliance and breaches, and give people more say over what companies can do with their data. "Small businesses are only beginning to become aware of its possible impact - a nightmare considering the size of the fines involved if they get it wrong," said Barry.

A survey from the Office of the Data Protection Commissioner found that, with just a year to go until GDPR's introduction, only 14% of small and mediumsized enterprises had started preparing. "The capacity for small-business owners to absorb ever increasing amounts of regulation is small," said Barry.

"Owners already wear so many hats, there are only so many hours in the day, and the bottom line is that they have to get on with running their businesses."

The government's action plan for jobs contains a commitment to "think small first". It says proposed legislation should be thoroughly assessed with regard to the costs to business. This is a step in the right direction, according to Barry.

"We want small business put front of mind across all government departments," she said. "Each initiative might only add a small impact to a business, yet cumulatively they can have a big effect."

A report from the National Competitiveness Council found that, while Ireland rates well in terms of ease of starting a business, once you get going that is no longer the case.

Employment legislation is a case in point. "There are 40 pieces of primary legislation attaching to employment alone. Once you employ just one other person, you go from zero to a situation where all [laws] are immediately applicable, with heavy fines if you get it wrong," said Barry.

Hoteliers Jenny and Justin Green have developed their home, Ballyvolane House, into one of the country's most sought-after wedding venues. They were also pioneers of glamping in Ireland. Last year they launched a gin distillery, producing Bertha's Revenge, an awardwinning brand of milk gin that they export worldwide.

The red tape can be stifling, according to Jenny Green. "It is hours and hours of work - and cost to the business - that the customer never sees," she said. "You can't afford to slip up. We're not a big business, but if I didn't employ a person in the office to help me look after it all, I'd be a nervous wreck."

For Neil McDonnell, of the small-business lobby group Isme, the key point is to ensure that regulation is applied at an "appropriate level". If existing regulations were enforced before being scrapped and replaced with new ones, that would help business owners who are struggling to keep up.

"Take trucking, for example, which is seeing new limits being introduced. Why not just enforce the ones that are there?" In employment law, he believes that the balance of rights has swung too far in favour of employees, at the expense of small businesses. In an increasingly litigious environment, some employees may be encouraged to "game the system".

An aggrieved employee in the transport sector, for example, could report a business to Nera, the employment rights authority; the Health and Safety Authority's workplace contact unit; and the Road Safety Authority. "The company is required to deal with these multiple agencies," said McDonnell.

Proposed legislation in relation to zero- and low-hour contracts is causing consternation. An estimated 2.6% of the total labour market works on a constantly variable part-time basis, according to the employers' organisation Ibec.

"This legislation will remove flexibility and increase cost and administration in all operations that need to cater for peaky, unexpected demand in roundthe-clock factories and service or hospitality operations," said an aviation sector executive, who asked not to be named.

"Zero-hour contracts is the headline [and] a Trojan horse which no one really contests, but the detail affects other parttime, flexi contracts adversely." It is, he added, "the last thing we need in the current environment where we need to retain competitiveness and flexibility".

There is a balance to be struck between having a minimum standard and a gold-plated one - and there is nothing wrong with a minimum standard, claimed Ian Talbot, chief executive of Chambers Ireland.

"In hospitality there are a plethora of different licensing and health and safety requirements, with separate bodies doing separate audits," he said. "If you need to engage a solicitor to keep your licences up to date, that's time and fees.

"Few companies go to the trouble of assessing the cost of all this activity that is not selling. But [falling foul of the regulations] worries people, so they spend a disproportionate amount of time checking, and money on professional fees." Tweaking the tax code to help small businesses would help, said photographer Agata Stoinska, founder of fashion platform Maven46 and content creation agency M46 Create. She believes a reduction in employer's PRSI levels would be a boon.

"It's really killing you," she said. "You feel like you are doing a good thing employing someone, but then you have to pay a huge cost on top. We could have put the money into employing more people or paying the people we have better."

As a result, Stoinska tries to avoid the cost by hiring on a contract basis instead. "But it's not good for the worker because they don't get a stable job. It's not good for us as a business either, because if they get a better contract they will go. And it's not good for the economy as a whole because it doesn't help growth."

There is a balance to be struck between a minimum standard and a gold-plated one. There is nothing wrong with a minimum standard


LOAD-DATE: July 2, 2017


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Oisin McElhinney and Jack Parsons started the O'Kale Krisps company, and are now, for the first time, discovering the complexity surrounding employing peopleFEI YANG/CLARE KEOGH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: STS



Copyright 2017 Times Newspapers Limited
All Rights Reserved


372 of 413 DOCUMENTS




telegraph.co.uk


June 29, 2017 Thursday 8:45 PM GMT 


UK firms 'failing to prepare' for regulation changes after Brexit


BYLINE: By Grace Palmer


SECTION: BUSINESS; Version:1


LENGTH: 339 words


Over two thirds of UK businesses are "not making adequate preparations" for the UK's withdrawal from the European Union, according to senior business leaders.

A third of respondents to the survey, which was carried out by Interim Partners, said Brexit was the biggest upcoming challenge for businesses.  

However, 69pc of UK businesses are not preparing adequately for the regulatory changes thrown up by the Brexit process, according to those surveyed, meaning many businesses are likely to struggle with the fallout unless they start preparations immediately.

One respondent from the group said that businesses must "reassess their operating model and restructure to become more flexible... to adapt quickly to the shape and impact of Brexit becomes clearer". 

The group was almost evenly split over the impact of Brexit on foreign investors - whether it would cause their investments to increase or decrease. 

In light of the lack of preparation, turnaround specialists will be in high demand over the coming years, according to 41pc of the business leaders surveyed.

Brexit anniversary: what happens next? 01:32

A second issue expected to face UK businesses is digital transformation, with around 21pc of respondents saying this would be the greatest challenge in the coming years. 

Firms may not have prepared for the emergence of 5G and biometric developments, as well as the introduction of General Data Protection Regulations (GDPR). 

GDPR will come into law from May 2018, and centres around how companies manage their customer and employee data, superseding the Data Protection Act of 1998 that the UK currently uses.

Another digital issue businesses are expected to face comes from their failure to invest in data management and technology, leaving public and private sector organisations at risk from increasingly sophisticated cyber attacks.

A digital shift could be worsened by a possible difficult withdrawal from the complex digital EU regulatory framework, the survey found. 


LOAD-DATE: June 29, 2017


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDTNS



Copyright 2017 Telegraph Media Group Limited
All Rights Reserved


373 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Sunday Times (London)


June 25, 2017 Sunday  
Edition 1;
Ireland


EU data regime set to 'swamp' Irish regulator;
Watchdog warns it will need additional staff and skills when it gains greater powers under new European rules


BYLINE: Philip Connolly


SECTION: BUSINESS AND MONEY;BUSINESS; Pg. 3


LENGTH: 544 words


Ireland's data protection commissioner - the lead regulator for tech giants Facebook, Google and Twitter across Europe - has warned of being swamped under Europe's new data regime and says the office will need to almost treble in size over the next couple of years. 

Under EU rules which are set to come into force in May 2018, Ireland will act as the lead supervisory authority in Europe for all the internet multinationals based here. Helen Dixon, the data protection commissioner (DPC), said the regulator was working with PwC to analyse the requirements of its changing role.

"Individuals are acquiring new rights, data controllers new obligations and data protection authorities new supervisory functions," Dixon told this newspaper last week. "Data protection authorities in Europe are acquiring much greater enforcement powers and will have the capability to impose large fines - up to (EURO)20m or 4% of global turnover. All of these features will mean that the Irish data protection commissioner requires additional staff and skills."

The new regime extends the scope of the data protection law to all foreign companies processing data of EU residents and harmonises regulations in the EU. The Irish government has already been lobbied by internet giants about how it will handle the new general data protection regulation (GDPR).

Dixon also said that Brexit could increase the regulator's workload as more data-rich companies could relocate to Ireland. She said this "would need to be factored into staffing needs".

The budget for the data protection commissioner increased fourfold to (EURO)7.5m between 2013 and 2017. Staffing levels have risen from under 30 in 2014 to more than 70.

"We will add about 30 staff in 2017, bringing our total to between 90 and 100 by the end of the year," said Dixon.

She added that the PwC project would allow the commissioner to estimate more accurately its future staffing needs, but she expected recruitment requirements to be significant again next year.

"I anticipate the Irish DPC will need to grow to over 200 staff in the next couple of years given the span and scale of its supervisory role," said Dixon.

Earlier this month, she told the Oireachtas committee on justice and equality that she "certainly envisages" a significant increase in workload.

Some of this will be due to the regulator having a broader range of powers and functions under the new data policies. Dixon added that she believed part of the increased workload would stem more complaints as the rules would force organisations to be more transparent and accountable about what data they held and how it was used.

Both Google and Facebook sought clarity from the Irish government about how it would apply the new rules during the first four months of the year.

According to a return on the lobby register, Google held meetings about GDPR with Paschal Donohoe, who was then minister for public expenditure and reform, and Dara Murphy, then a minister for data protection.

It sought to "emphasise the need to achieve maximum harmonisation in the transposition of the GDPR across member states and to encourage regulatory investment to support the digital economy".

Facebook also held a meeting with Murphy to "seek clarity on Ireland's approach" to the new rules.


LOAD-DATE: June 25, 2017


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: Helen Dixon is working with PwC to analyse the requirements of the new data protection regulation


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: STS



Copyright 2017 Times Newspapers Limited
All Rights Reserved


374 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Times (London)


June 20, 2017 Tuesday  
Edition 1;
Scotland


Small companies run risk of hefty fines over new data rules


BYLINE: James Hurley


SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 53


LENGTH: 457 words


Small businesses are being warned that they risk enormous fines if they ignore an overhaul of data protection rules that will affect organisations of all sizes.

The biggest change in a quarter of a century in how companies process information, such as customer lists and employee records, comes into force next May, yet there is little awareness among smaller organisations. 

The general data protection regulation rules, which emanate from Brussels, are designed to hand control of personal data to individuals rather than organisations. A survey of more than 1,000 small companies, commissioned by Irwin Mitchell, a law firm, found that 78 per had not heard of the new rules, while 86 per cent were not aware of the threat of fines. Only 11 per cent had started preparing for it.

Businesses must be much clearer on how customer data is collected and stored, they have to make it easier for customers to tell organisations to "forget" them and must provide greater protection for children. Any data breaches (as a result of hacking, for example) must be communicated within three days to the Information Commissioner's Office, the data regulator.

Companies will be required to obtain an unequivocal "positive indication of agreement" to personal data being processed. Silence will no longer count as consent.

Personal data means a name, a photo, an email address, bank details, posts on social networking websites, medical information or a computer IP address.

Organisations that fail to comply can be fined up to 4 per cent of their annual global turnover, or (EURO)20 million, whichever is larger.

Matthew Pryke, partner at Hamlins, another law firm, said: "Too many businesses are complacent. Those who leave it to chance and don't prepare now could be left high and dry if the ICO finds that businesses breach regulations. Given the ICO will need to fund its operations via these fines, it seems inevitable for examples to be made and hefty fines imposed as soon as the legislation comes into force."

The European Union says that the rules will "reshape the way organisations across the region approach data privacy". The government has indicated that Britain's decision to leave the EU will not affect the introduction of the rules.

The Times understands that the Federation of Small Businesses has warned its members that the rules will increase costs. Craig Beaumont, head of external affairs at the FSB, said that GDPR would increase the already burdensome data protection regulations. He said: "Small firms across the UK and Europe do not know about it. We are asking ministers and the ICO to create an awareness-raising campaign over the summer."

The ICO is compiling guidance on how to comply with the rules, which is available on its website.


LOAD-DATE: June 20, 2017


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: TIM



Copyright 2017 Times Newspapers Limited
All Rights Reserved


375 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Guardian(London)


June 19, 2017 Monday 4:36 PM GMT 


EU seeks to outlaw 'backdoors' in new data privacy proposals;
Draft report from European parliament clashes with UK government calls to allow access to encrypted communications from WhatsApp and others


BYLINE: Samuel Gibbs


SECTION: TECHNOLOGY; Version:1


LENGTH: 741 words


The European Union is considering banning the implementation of so-called "backdoors" that allow the reading of encrypted messaging, a move that would place it in conflict with the UK government's desire to have access to all secure communications.

The draft report by the European parliament's Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs says the data protection regulations have not kept pace with advances in technology and that amendments to the 2002 Regulation on Privacy and Electronic Communications (ePrivacy) are required. 

Part of the amendments, proposed by the European Commission in January and now reviewed by the European parliament, look to deal with so-called over-the-top (OTT) services. The services replicate the functionality of traditional communications systems, such as landline telephones, but aren't not regulated in the same way and so are not affording similar protections.

For example, the UK government has repeatedly called for ways to gain access to encrypted communications such as the end-to-end encryption (E2EE) used by Signal and WhatsApp, which prevents the interception of private messages.

The EU draft proposal categorically rules out such measures. It says: "The providers of electronic communications services shall ensure that there is sufficient protection in place against unauthorised access or alterations to the electronic communications data, and that the confidentiality and safety of the transmission are also guaranteed by the nature of the means of transmission used, or by state-of-the-art end-to-end encryption of the electronic communications data.

"Furthermore, when encryption of electronic communications data is used, decryption, reverse engineering or monitoring of such communications shall be prohibited."

In the wake of terror attacks across the UK earlier this year the home secretary, Amber Rudd, backed by Downing Street, repeatedly called for access to messages sent via communications services that use E2EE. The issue was repeated in the Conservative manifesto.

Europe's draft amendments specifically ban such attempts by government: "Member States shall not impose any obligations on electronic communications service providers that would result in the weakening of the security and encryption of their networks and services."

How the impending Brexit negotiations will impact legislation such as the IPA is currently unclear. By the time amendments are made to the ePrivacy directive, the UK is likely to have completed the Brexit process.

The new proposed amendments are part of sweeping changes regarding digital communications and privacy kicked off by the new, tougher General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which is due to come into force in 2018, as well as the legislation around the single digital market.

The ePrivacy directive change proposals seek to bring the 2002 law in line with the newer GDPR and attempt to keep pace with technological development. They also cover the tracking of users for advertising, the collection of metadata and behavioural data, an the explicit consent required to do so.

The amendments will have to journey through a multi-stage process including approval by the European parliament and European council before becoming law, but they were welcomed by privacy and security experts.

Lukasz Olejnik, an independent security and privacy technology researcher said the amendments "significantly improve security and privacy properties" of the EU's regulations and that they were "a step in a great direction".

"The end-to-end aspect is additionally of interest due to the worldwide campaign of weakening cryptography and introducing backdoors. Such voices are in the USA, Australia, Germany, France and UK. These last points put ePrivacy on a potential collision course with the supposedly imminent regulations negatively affecting cybersecurity and privacy," Olejnik said.

The proposed ePrivacy amendments come at a time when the EU is suggesting it might seek to give law enforcement the power to directly access cloud storage to retrieve electronic evidence.

Part of a three-option proposal that will form the basis of future legislative reform for what EU Justice Commissioner Vera Jourova said was "an extraordinary measure for extraordinary threats", the EU is seeking to speed up the process of evidence collection in the wake of terror attacks cross Europe.


  • •

    Backdoor access to WhatsApp? Rudd's call suggests a hazy grasp of encryption 


LOAD-DATE: June 19, 2017


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBGNS

376 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Times (London)


June 15, 2017 Thursday  
Edition 1;
Scotland


Backflips and the bread and butter;
Goodbye Liz Truss, but what does the election mean for legislation? Edward Fennell reports


BYLINE: Edward Fennell


SECTION: FEATURES; Pg. 67


LENGTH: 861 words


Only time will tell whether last week's electoral diversion will lead to a better destination for the nation or mark the definitive point of decline for the UK as a global power.

"At a constitutional level, it would appear that both IndyRef2 and hard Brexit may be off the table for now," says Philip Rodney, the chairman of the Scottish firm Burness Paull, reflecting on the success of the Conservatives north of the border.

In any case, every cloud has a silver lining and for many lawyers the departure of Liz Truss from the Ministry of Justice might make the chaos seem worthwhile. As David Corker, of Corker Binning, observed: "Truss had lost the confidence of the judiciary and her move away from the justice portfolio was inevitable. A justice secretary who fails to defend the judiciary from ill-informed tabloid attacks cannot remain in post." 

So what of her successor, the almost unknown David Lidington? "While perhaps a little disappointed that the prime minister has not utilised some of the undoubted legal talent available to her, one cannot deny David Lidington's intellectual credentials," says Clive O'Connell, of McCarthy Denning.

Those intellectual credentials may have to be deployed in some neat policy backflips. For example, the much abused proposal in the Conservative manifesto to merge the Serious Fraud Office (SFO) with the National Crime Agency (NCA) looks likely to be abandoned. "Jeremy Corbyn's election success has surely sunk any chance of Theresa May's ill-starred proposal to merge the SFO with the NCA. Losing the SFO would be a serious blow for the UK's anti-fraud and corruption capability," says Corker.

The biggest backflip of all might be over Brexit. "We might now see the UK seek to retain its membership of the EU single market through renewed membership of the European Free Trade Association (EFTA) - the so-called Norway option," says Glenn Kangisser, of Haynes and Boone CDG. "If that becomes official government policy, we're already slow out of the blocks to obtain the agreement of all 27 EU members and the four members of EFTA before March 2019."

The critical juncture will be when votes are called in the House of Commons. "The government is stuck between a rock and a hard place," says Robert Bell, of Bryan Cave. "It has not got enough support for a hard Brexit [and] nor does it have a mandate. Although there is officially no need for a vote until the government comes back from Brussels with a deal, there are going to be many opportunities for opponents of a hard Brexit to force concessions."

A key moment for this, he adds, could be the passage of the Great Repeal Bill, by which time the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) might be pulling the central strings. "The DUP's keenness to keep an open border with the Republic of Ireland and the rest of the UK, could lead towards a more open mind towards remaining part of the Customs Union, which already includes the non-EU British territories of Guernsey, Jersey and the Isle of Man," points out Nicholas Evans, a partner and parliamentary agent at Bircham Dyson Bell. Despite the talk of a more centrist approach, Ed Parker, of Mayer Brown, sends out a warning note. "Uncertainty is the new certainty, and that is definitely bad for business," he says. "Rewind 12 months and the series of events we have seen has been unpredictable." The lack of certainty is not well received in the wider world, he adds. "Institutions are updating their Brexit plans, but no major decisions are likely to be taken until negotiations get under way."

Even so, as Sally Shorthose, of Bird & Bird, observes: "The EU has made it clear that exit terms are to be agreed before any discussion about trading terms, free movement and co-operation on regulations can take place. This delay and uncertainty is not good for business and may hasten the exit of company headquarters from the UK."

To stem such an exodus it is important that Brexit should not monopolise the government's attention, says Nigel Teasdale, the president of the Forum of Insurance Lawyers and a DWF partner. "It is only right that Brexit will dominate the political landscape given the range and significance of the legal and commercial issues it raises," he says.

"It is crucial, though, that the government does not lose sight of other issues. In particular, we would urge the government to press on with the Vehicle Technology and Aviation Bill, which fell by the wayside when the election was called. This bill is essential to address concerns around insurance liability for driverless vehicles and keep the UK at the forefront of developing technology."

Equally important is the implementation of General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which is due to come into force in May next year. "Retention of the GDPR in the UK is a significant issue for businesses, not least because without it, there is a greater probability that the UK will not be afforded data protection 'adequacy' status by the European Commission post-Brexit," says Aaron P Simpson, the managing partner of Hunton and Williams's London office. Upon these bread and butter pieces of legislation our future depends. They must not be overlooked.

The Independent - Daily Edition


June 1, 2017 Thursday  
First Edition


UK data privacy breach fines soar to over £3m


BYLINE: JOSIE COX BUSINESS EDITOR


SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 53


LENGTH: 302 words


The number of fines handed out for breaking UK data protection laws almost doubled last year, making Britain one of the most active regions for regulatory enforcement across Europe.

According to figures from the UK's Information Commissioner's Office (ICO) analysed by professional services firm PwC, fines for data protection breaches hit over £3.2m in 2016, putting the UK on par with Italy, where fines totaled £3.3m, but dramatically below the US where fines of approximately $250m (£195m) were served. A recent PwC survey found that 90 per cent of chief executive officers globally believe breaches of data privacy and ethics have a negative impact on stakeholder trust, and PwC warned that ahead of new regulation coming into force next year it was therefore paramount that businesses prioritise security and privacy. 

Last Thursday marked a year until the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) comes into effect. Non-compliance penalties could lead to fines of up to Euro 20m (£17.5m) or 4 per cent of a company's global annual turnover. "We've performed more than 150 GDPR readiness assessments with our clients around the world. Many struggle to know where to start with their preparations, but also how to move programmes beyond just risk reviews and data analysis to delivering real operational change," said Stewart Room, PwC's global cyber security and data protection legal services leader.

He said that the ICO can currently issue fines of up to £500,000, but considering how big the fines will be for not complying with GDPR, it is important that UK organisations use the coming months to prepare. In 2016, 35 fines were served for breaking data protection laws in the UK, compared to 18 in 2015 for a total of just over £2m. That already represented a sharp increase from the £1.2m issued in 2014.

telegraph.co.uk


May 31, 2017 Wednesday 6:54 AM GMT 


Why Project Fear 2.0 will do nothing to help the Brexit negotiations


BYLINE: By Peter Foster , Europe Editor


SECTION: NEWS; Version:2


LENGTH: 1329 words


Project Fear, as last year's Remain referendum campaign was so successfully dubbed by Brexiteers, was a failure because it failed to strike sufficient fear into the hearts of the voters.

A year after Brexit, the sky has still not fallen, and the worst of the Treasury's dire predictions - the recession, the 500,000 job losses - have still not come to pass. 

The prophesies proved empty in part because of mitigation measures the Treasury itself put in place but deliberately ignored when issuing their own warnings about a vote to leave.

This was a piece of intellectual dishonesty that even today corrodes the trust between government and governed. 

So it is doubly extraordinary, as we approach the start of Brexit negotiations proper, that history appears to be repeating itself. 

Project Fear 2.0 is more amorphous than the original version since it is not propagated by the Government this time, but it paints a similarly catastrophic and unbelievable picture of the 'no deal' and the 'bad deal' scenarios for Brexit.

<table>

No deal also means no flights, no imports/exports, no medicines, qualifications and standards not recognised, limited range of food ....etc https://t.co/VzUuf21EKk

- Helen Rushby (@HelenRushby1) May 29, 2017

And just like the Treasury mandarins before them, the Brexit Cassandras offer their warnings without reference to the steps the UK would actually take in mitigation, or to the fact that the EU would take measures to protect itself from economic blowback of a no-deal scenario.

Common predictions of doom include stock market crashes, UK aeroplanes unable to fly into Europe, troops back on the Irish border, companies lost in data limbo, the docks of Dover and Rotterdam at a standstill, and the financial markets of London all on the point of collapse.

All of these scenarios are, if the EU had an absolute death wish, possible. The EU could refuse, for example, to recognise the validity of British-registered aeroplanes' safety certifications and block all point-to-point flights in Europe, but there are very many good reasons why they would not do that.

<table>

. @theresa_may to Paxman: No deal better than a bad deal. Hope that's a negotiating tactic & not serious. No deal would mean fin mkt collapse

- Charles Grant (@CER_Grant) May 29, 2017

Firstly, the EU knows perfectly well that the UK certifications are materially valid, and that the UK as a responsible developed-world former partner, would not imperil either UK or EU citizens by cutting corners on safety. A status quo agreement is perfectly easily done.

Secondly there is commercial self-interest. London Heathrow is Europe's busiest airport, with 75 million passengers a year and EU airlines need access to that global hub. Some 60 per cent of UK air passengers land in Europe where they spend money on holidays and doing business. 

Political common sense and economic imperative says it is simply in no-one's interest to blow all that up. If the Brexit talks go pear-shaped, which they well might if the political temperature isn't lowered, the blame-game will begin in earnest and will it land squarely in the EU's court.

If air links were shut down - just think of the recent BA chaos and multiply by a thousand - then it will only be because the EU side wants to make a point, not because the UK isn't happy to agree to an interim agreement that keeps the planes in the air.

May: Corbyn would be 'alone and naked' in Brexit negotiations 01:35

By the same token, the EU could withdraw financial passporting and mutual recognition agreements from the City overnight, but again not without significant risk. It would be inflicting pain and chaos on itself, even as it punished Britain.

Similarly the EU could in theory put a stop to data-flows between the UK and the EU by refusing to recognise the UK's post-Brexit data protection regime, but it won't because data is the lifeblood of modern business and trade must go on.

Like the shutting of the airports, this risk is wildly overstated. The UK is signing into law the EU's new General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) which will in turn be swallowed by the Great Repeal Bill. There will be no real grounds to stop the flows.

It is true, when it comes to data, that national security issues will need to be taken into consideration post-Brexit, but if Israel and the US can get an adequacy agreement, there will be no reason why the UK will not too - other than political vindictiveness.

In practice, data will keep flowing - because it must - just as it did when the European Court of Justice threw out the US-EU 'Safe Harbour' data sharing agreement which was later replaced by Privacy Shield, which itself may fall in the courts. But data will still flow.

The asymmetries of the negotiation might well mean that a 'no deal' scenario would be more painful for Britain than for Europe, but that does not - as so many Remoaners would have us believe - make it painless for the European side.

Brexit | The European Union's draft negotiation principles

Commentators who say that Mrs Merkel 'won't bat an eyelid' if the UK walks away from the table are just drinking the Kool Aid. Europe, a continent riven by economic and political divisions, has plenty of skin in this game. This may be an unequal contest, but it is not a 'no-contest'.

None of this is to underestimate the technical, legal and bureaucratic complexities of resolving and duplicating such arrangements in a post-Brexit world, but this is precisely why the 'Remoaner' scaremongering is so counter-productive. 

It leaves most ordinary people rolling their eyes and - as with the original Project Fear - dismissing the actual concrete, long-term risks posed by a destructive Brexit deal: the lost decade, the slow death.

These risk are, as Mrs May now warns, very real. Our "future prosperity" depends on getting this right. Beginning on June 19, the public will be confronted rapidly with the costs, compromises and contradictions implicit in Brexit that have so far not been properly acknowledged.

Scaremongering is not useful. What is needed is a dose of cold-hearted realism, from Brexiteers and Remoaners alike.

Our manifesto: Real political insight, free for 30 days.

Rely on unrivalled insight and sharp analysis from our stellar team of Westminster insiders.

379 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Daily Telegraph (London)


May 30, 2017 Tuesday  
Edition 1;
National Edition


British businesses risking huge fines by ignoring new data rules


BYLINE: Szu Ping Chan


SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 5


LENGTH: 314 words


BRITISH companies risk being forced out of business by new EU-wide data laws that will leave ill-prepared businesses exposed to multi-billion pound fines, research shows. 

New General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) next year will require businesses across the bloc to take extra steps to protect customer data and be more transparent about how it is used.

With less than a year until the rules take effect next May, just a third of UK companies have started preparing for the shake-up, while 60pc were completely unaware of the rules, according to a survey commissioned by law firm Irwin Mitchell.

The YouGov poll of 2,000 businesses also showed that 71pc were unaware of the harsher penalties that could be enforced, with a maximum financial penalty of (EURO)20m (£17.5m) - or 4pc of global turnover. This comes despite 18pc respondents stating they would go out of business if they received the maximum punishment, while one in ten said they would need to make "significant" job cuts. Joanne Bone, a partner at Irwin Mitchell, said: "May's deadline is fastapproaching and with so much at stake, our study reveals there's a very real possibility that the majority of organisations will not be compliant in time." The new rules, which come into force a year before the UK leaves the EU, state that businesses will have to report data breaches within 72 hours to regulators where there is an impact on privacy, such as a customer database being hacked. The sweeping rules encompass a wide range of personal information including employee, payroll and pension data, and will also apply to sole-traders and partnerships.

However, a third of businesses surveyed believed the rules would not apply to them, while a quarter said they would not be able to detect a breach.

£17.5m The maximum fine firms could face if they do not comply with EU-wide data laws which are due to be introduced next year

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: DTL



Copyright 2017 Telegraph Media Group Limited
All Rights Reserved


380 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Independent (United Kingdom)


May 29, 2017 Monday 6:05 PM GMT 


Financial institutions say biggest threat of financial crime stems from cyberspace;
The risk of cyber crime moved into sharp focus after tens of thousands of individuals across almost 100 countries were affected by a massive cyber attack in mid-May


BYLINE: Josie Cox


SECTION: BUSINESS NEWS; Version:1


LENGTH: 504 words


Banking and investment management professionals think that the biggest threat of financial crime now stems from cyberspace, according to new research.

A survey of nearly 200 senior professionals working in retail banks, investment banks and asset management firms, conducted by information provider LexisNexisRisk Solutions, shows that 44 per cent currently perceive so-called evolving criminal methodologies, like cyber crime, to be the single biggest financial crime risk for their businesses. 

A total of 41 per cent say that such methodologies will represent the biggest risk over the coming 12 months, but 92 per cent said that they are concerned that their organisation's legacy technology is"a barrier to fighting financial crime over the next one to two years".

Read more

What is GDPR? What you need to know about the new cyber security rules

And a staggering 87 per cent said that their business isn't able to enhance their technology fast enough to counter evolving criminal methods.

"Criminal methodologies are constantly evolving and financial institutions are struggling to keep up with their changing tactics when implementing financial crime defences. For those tasked with combatting financial crime it can feel as if they are fighting twenty first century criminals with twentieth century tools," said Dean Curtis, managing director at LexisNexis Risk Solutions for the UK.

"Our report shows financial crime professionals do not believe the industry is doing enough to leverage the advantages of technology to fight financial crime."

The report found that the problem is being compounded by the regulatory environment and the associated costs. Increased regulations require investment in new technologies and 60 per cent of respondents to the survey cited this as a root cause of cost increases. Since 2015, 63 per cent of financial institutions say their financial crime compliance costs have increased, whilst just 2 per cent say they have decreased.

Read more

North Korea behind hack that brought chaos to hospitals, say experts

Accidental hero who saved NHS revealed

Microsoft says ransomware hack a 'wake-up call' for world governments

The risk of cyber crimemoved into sharp focus after tens of thousands of individuals across almost 100 countries were affected by a massive cyber-attack earlier this month. That attack, known as "Wannacry", was believed to be one of the largest of its kind. It affected hospitals, companies, universities and governments, including theNHS, where close to 50 health trusts were believed to have been affected.

Last month theBritish Chambers of Commerce warned that while large businesses are more likely to become the victim of an attack than their smaller counterparts, all types of companies need to ramp up security defences.

Three in four UK businesses have reported a digital skills shortage among their employees, according to a separate BCC report, despite 84 per cent of firms admitting that digital and IT skills are more important to their enterprise now than two years ago.

telegraph.co.uk


May 29, 2017 Monday 7:58 PM GMT 


British businesses risking huge fines by ignoring new data rules


BYLINE: By Szu Ping Chan


SECTION: BUSINESS; Version:1


LENGTH: 293 words


British companies risk being forced out of business by new EU-wide data laws that will leave ill-prepared businesses exposed to multi-billion pound fines, research shows. 

New General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) next year will require businesses across the bloc to take extra steps to protect customer data and be more transparent about how it is used.

With less than a year until the rules take effect next May, just a third of UK companies have started preparing for the shake-up, while 60pc were completely unaware of the rules, according to a survey commissioned by law firm Irwin Mitchell.

The YouGov poll of 2,000 businesses also showed that 71pc were unaware of the harsher penalties that could be enforced, with a maximum financial penalty of (EURO)20m (£17.5m) - or 4pc of global turnover. This comes despite 18pc respondents stating they would go out of business if they received the maximum punishment, while one in ten said they would need to make "significant" job cuts.

Joanne Bone, a partner at Irwin Mitchell, said: "May's deadline is fast-approaching and with so much at stake, our study reveals there's a very real possibility that the majority of organisations will not be compliant in time."

The new rules, which come into force a year before the UK leaves the EU, state that businesses will have to report data breaches within 72 hours to regulators where there is an impact on privacy, such as a customer database being hacked. The sweeping rules encompass a wide range of personal information including employee, payroll and pension data, and will also apply to sole-traders and partnerships.

However, a third of businesses surveyed believed the rules would not apply to them, while a quarter said they would not be able to detect a breach.


LOAD-DATE: May 29, 2017


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper; Web Publication


JOURNAL-CODE: WEBDTNS



Copyright 2017 Telegraph Media Group Limited
All Rights Reserved


382 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Times (London)


May 24, 2017 Wednesday  
Edition 1;
National Edition


Data protection changes provide safeguards and business opportunities


BYLINE: Alexandra Frean


SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 45


LENGTH: 616 words


Get used to this jumble of letters: GDPR. They stand for the new law that will give us back a measure of control over our personal data online and impose massive fines on companies that stand in our way or fail to protect it. In the tug-of-war over personal data between companies and their customers, the new regulation falls firmly in the consumer's favour. But it also offers huge benefits for companies too, if they play it right.

GDPR - it stands for general data protection regulation - comes into force a year tomorrow and will allow European consumers to ask companies to show them the personal data gathered on them and to explain why it is collected and how it is being used. It provides a crucial reminder to consumers of the value of the information that they have got used to giving away for nothing. 

Although this is European Union legislation, the government has confirmed that it will be implemented here, despite Brexit. It also applies to non-EU organisations that offer goods or services to individuals in Europe, so will also cover the American technology groups that have been hoovering up our personal data for years.

For breaches, firms will have to pay fines of 2 to 4 per cent of their global annual turnover, or (EURO)20 million, whichever is the greater. That could represent an effective deterrent. Talktalk's 2016 fine of £400,000 for security failings that allowed a data breach could have been as high as £37 million under the GDPR. A company such as Facebook, fined (EURO)150,000 in France last week for data mishandling, could face penalties as high as (EURO)500 million.

Many British businesses have said they are not fully prepared to deliver the law. As Greg Day of Palo Alto Networks, an enterprise security firm, notes, some fear that it is not prescriptive enough. One big concern surrounds a requirement for them to report certain types of data breach to regulators and, in some cases, to customers. Some fear that the regulations may encourage companies to delay notification because the rules require them to first determine whether any of a string of potential exemptions apply.

Talktalk has said that in the case of its breach it wouldn't have been clear for months whether exemptions applied, because that calculation depended on information not immediately available. Customers could be left vulnerable during the interim, while companies could be encouraged to handle breaches in a way that met exemptions, rather than to prioritise customer protection.

GDPR also gives customers the right to ask one company to "port" all the data they have built up on them over the years, to a rival provider, effectively enabling firms to poach each other's data.

Chris McMillan, a partner at Oliver Wyman, the consultancy, says that many firms may not be able to cope with the business consequences of losing their data banks in this way. But he also sees new business opportunities. It's only a matter of time, he believes, before big tech firms launch "data passport" services, seeking customers' permission to store in one place all their personal data from different sources. They could then monetise this treasure trove by shopping around for the best deals on insurance, utilities or whatever, based on a highly detailed view of a user's habits and preferences.

For all its faults, GDPR represents a huge opportunity. Crucially, it will force businesses to step back and examine the processes they have put in place throughout the time of enormous technological change since Britain's privacy laws were last updated with the 1998 Data Protection Act and question whether they can do better. They almost certainly can.

Alexandra Frean is Business Columnist of The Times


LOAD-DATE: May 24, 2017


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: TIM



Copyright 2017 Times Newspapers Limited
All Rights Reserved


383 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Times (London)


May 1, 2017 Monday  
Edition 1;
Ireland


Innovation should be the hot election topic;
We will be stuck in the economic slow lane unless we cut burdensome regulation and give free rein to new ideas


BYLINE: Matt Ridley


SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. 17


LENGTH: 1112 words


An open letter to George Freeman MP, chairman of the government's policy board.

Dear George, as a former biotech venture capitalist, you are a passionate champion of innovation. It has pulled an average of 137,000 people out of extreme poverty each and every day of the past 25 years. It's the only thing that can pay off our £1.9 trillion national debt while keeping our grandchildren prosperous. You are on record as saying: "We have a once-in-a-generation chance to seize the opportunities to make the UK the innovation capital of the world, defying the doubters and being clear that we will go on leading the world in science and technology."

I don't know what it is like down your end of the parliamentary corridor, but at ours we spend very little time talking about how to encourage and reward innovation, despite its clear importance. We are too busy instead with regulation and spending. Although it hardly features in debates or coverage of British politics, there is an entrepreneurial revolution going on in Britain, with about 600,000 business start-ups a year, more than in any other European country - driven by some excellent pro-enterprise policies started under David Cameron. 

However, most of this is in the digital economy, where innovation is comparatively "permissionless" - for now. Elsewhere, there is a real problem with bad, inconsistent or burdensome regulation stifling innovation. So here is a suggestion for the Conservative Party manifesto that I think could help unleash beneficial innovation in years to come, or at least prevent it grinding to a halt. It is called the innovation principle.

It was proposed by the European Risk Forum and is actively supported by BusinessEurope and the European Round Table of Industrialists. In essence, it says: examine every policy, plan or political strategy for the impact it could have on innovation, and if you find evidence that the policy is going to impede it, then drop, change or rethink the thing.

Twenty-two chief executives from some of the world's more innovative companies signed a letter to Jean-Claude Juncker in 2014 asking him to adopt the innovation principle, and the Dutch prime minister, Mark Rutte, endorsed it last year during his country's presidency of the EU, saying: "I particularly support ... the innovation principle. This principle requires assessing - as standard - the impact of proposed new legislation on innovation. In my view, we should position the innovation principle more prominently in the years ahead, to make the EU economy stronger and more agile." So there is a chance that the European Union will get the point, and remember Britain tends to overapply regulations anyway.

The innovation principle would complement rather than replace the precautionary principle, which is incorporated into the Lisbon treaty. At its best the precautionary principle is a good thing, preventing future thalidomide tragedies. It says: think about the risks before you adopt something new. At its worst, it does huge harm, because it says: banish potential hazards without considering the benefits of an innovation, while ignoring the hazards of an existing technology, and therefore don't do anything new.

For example, European certification of genetically modified crops is so impossibly slow, uncertain and politicised as to have frightened off all applications in recent years. The result is that Europe has missed out on the organic, insect-resistant "Bt" revolution in plant breeding and is far more reliant on pesticides instead. The newer technology of gene editing, which is being pioneered in British laboratories, has been given a green light by US regulators, while the EU has - get this - asked member states to avoid making a decision at all. What signal does that send? One chemical manufacturer tells me he estimates that to develop a new herbicide that could safely tackle black-grass, an increasingly problematic weed, it would be necessary to comply with between 15,000 and 40,000 pages of regulations and scientific guidance documents. Few companies in the world have this capability.

Next month the implementation of new European rules on vaping arrives, which restrict e-cigarette advertising, limit tank and refill sizes, and cap the strength of liquids, making it harder for this much safer new technology to continue to displace smoking at a rate of knots. Thus, in the name of the precautionary principle, the EU has been insisting on danger. Last December, BusinessEurope produced a long catalogue of cases in which EU regulation had affected innovation. The list includes two cases where regulation stimulated innovation (waste policies and sustainable mobility), but far more where it hampered change by introducing legal uncertainty, inconsistency with other regulations, technology-prescriptive rules, burdensome packaging requirements, high compliance costs or excessive precaution. For example, the EU medical devices directive has greatly increased the cost and reduced the supply of new medical devices. Don't take comfort from our many digital start-ups. As a chemical industry executive put it to me last week, the digital industry does not realise what's about to hit it. The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) comes into force next year, along with new ePrivacy regulation. The British Information Commissioner's Office has issued draft guidance that gold-plates the GDPR, with an unduly strict and burdensome interpretation that tilts the balance against the data industry in a manner not required by the regulation. Its proposed rules on opt-outs and consents would make direct marketing as presently practised here impossible. Data analysis is a growing industry in which we have the potential to be a world leader.

An abstract principle, however pious, is not going to change anything. The only way to get momentum for reform is to create a vested interest, preferably with a budget. Precaution has a wealthy constituency in the vast green lobby, whereas innovation's benefits are dispersed among consumers. So here's a suggestion. Why not pledge to set up an innovation commission, guided by the innovation principle, whose job is to examine policies and report on their likely impact on innovation? New Zealand has tried something similar, a productivity commission, which "considers whether laws, policies, regulations and institutions best support the wellbeing of New Zealanders".

Without this, we will be in the economic slow lane, which will hamper our ability to generate funds for social welfare, defence, foreign aid, education and everything else.

Yours optimistically, Matt.

New rules on vaping mean the EU is insisting on danger


LOAD-DATE: May 1, 2017


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


GRAPHIC: E-cigarette restrictions make it harder for safer vaping to displace smoking


PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


JOURNAL-CODE: TIM

All Rights Reserved


384 of 413 DOCUMENTS




The Times (London)


May 1, 2017 Monday  
Edition 1;
National Edition


Innovation should be the hot election topic;
We will be stuck in the economic slow lane unless we cut burdensome regulation and give free rein to new ideas


BYLINE: Matt Ridley


SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. 23


LENGTH: 1112 words


An open letter to George Freeman MP, chairman of the government's policy board.

Dear George, as a former biotech venture capitalist, you are a passionate champion of innovation. It has pulled an average of 137,000 people out of extreme poverty each and every day of the past 25 years. It's the only thing that can pay off our £1.9 trillion national debt while keeping our grandchildren prosperous. You are on record as saying: "We have a once-in-a-generation chance to seize the opportunities to make the UK the innovation capital of the world, defying the doubters and being clear that we will go on leading the world in science and technology."

I don't know what it is like down your end of the parliamentary corridor, but at ours we spend very little time talking about how to encourage and reward innovation, despite its clear importance. We are too busy instead with regulation and spending. Although it hardly features in debates or coverage of British politics, there is an entrepreneurial revolution going on in Britain, with about 600,000 business start-ups a year, more than in any other European country - driven by some excellent pro-enterprise policies started under David Cameron. 

However, most of this is in the digital economy, where innovation is comparatively "permissionless" - for now. Elsewhere, there is a real problem with bad, inconsistent or burdensome regulation stifling innovation. So here is a suggestion for the Conservative Party manifesto that I think could help unleash beneficial innovation in years to come, or at least prevent it grinding to a halt. It is called the innovation principle.

It was proposed by the European Risk Forum and is actively supported by BusinessEurope and the European Round Table of Industrialists. In essence, it says: examine every policy, plan or political strategy for the impact it could have on innovation, and if you find evidence that the policy is going to impede it, then drop, change or rethink the thing.

Twenty-two chief executives from some of the world's more innovative companies signed a letter to Jean-Claude Juncker in 2014 asking him to adopt the innovation principle, and the Dutch prime minister, Mark Rutte, endorsed it last year during his country's presidency of the EU, saying: "I particularly support ... the innovation principle. This principle requires assessing - as standard - the impact of proposed new legislation on innovation. In my view, we should position the innovation principle more prominently in the years ahead, to make the EU economy stronger and more agile." So there is a chance that the European Union will get the point, and remember Britain tends to overapply regulations anyway.

The innovation principle would complement rather than replace the precautionary principle, which is incorporated into the Lisbon treaty. At its best the precautionary principle is a good thing, preventing future thalidomide tragedies. It says: think about the risks before you adopt something new. At its worst, it does huge harm, because it says: banish potential hazards without considering the benefits of an innovation, while ignoring the hazards of an existing technology, and therefore don't do anything new.

For example, European certification of genetically modified crops is so impossibly slow, uncertain and politicised as to have frightened off all applications in recent years. The result is that Europe has missed out on the organic, insect-resistant "Bt" revolution in plant breeding and is far more reliant on pesticides instead. The newer technology of gene editing, which is being pioneered in British laboratories, has been given a green light by US regulators, while the EU has - get this - asked member states to avoid making a decision at all. What signal does that send? One chemical manufacturer tells me he estimates that to develop a new herbicide that could safely tackle black-grass, an increasingly problematic weed, it would be necessary to comply with between 15,000 and 40,000 pages of regulations and scientific guidance documents. Few companies in the world have this capability.

Next month the implementation of new European rules on vaping arrives, which restrict e-cigarette advertising, limit tank and refill sizes, and cap the strength of liquids, making it harder for this much safer new technology to continue to displace smoking at a rate of knots. Thus, in the name of the precautionary principle, the EU has been insisting on danger. Last December, BusinessEurope produced a long catalogue of cases in which EU regulation had affected innovation. The list includes two cases where regulation stimulated innovation (waste policies and sustainable mobility), but far more where it hampered change by introducing legal uncertainty, inconsistency with other regulations, technology-prescriptive rules, burdensome packaging requirements, high compliance costs or excessive precaution. For example, the EU medical devices directive has greatly increased the cost and reduced the supply of new medical devices. Don't take comfort from our many digital start-ups. As a chemical industry executive put it to me last week, the digital industry does not realise what's about to hit it. The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) comes into force next year, along with new ePrivacy regulation. The British Information Commissioner's Office has issued draft guidance that gold-plates the GDPR, with an unduly strict and burdensome interpretation that tilts the balance against the data industry in a manner not required by the regulation. Its proposed rules on opt-outs and consents would make direct marketing as presently practised here impossible. Data analysis is a growing industry in which we have the potential to be a world leader.

An abstract principle, however pious, is not going to change anything. The only way to get momentum for reform is to create a vested interest, preferably with a budget. Precaution has a wealthy constituency in the vast green lobby, whereas innovation's benefits are dispersed among consumers. So here's a suggestion. Why not pledge to set up an innovation commission, guided by the innovation principle, whose job is to examine policies and report on their likely impact on innovation? New Zealand has tried something similar, a productivity commission, which "considers whether laws, policies, regulations and institutions best support the wellbeing of New Zealanders".

Without this, we will be in the economic slow lane, which will hamper our ability to generate funds for social welfare, defence, foreign aid, education and everything else.

Yours optimistically, Matt.

Innovation should be the hot election topic;
We will be stuck in the economic slow lane unless we cut burdensome regulation and give free rein to new ideas


BYLINE: Matt Ridley


SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. 23


LENGTH: 1112 words


An open letter to George Freeman MP, chairman of the government's policy board.

Dear George, as a former biotech venture capitalist, you are a passionate champion of innovation. It has pulled an average of 137,000 people out of extreme poverty each and every day of the past 25 years. It's the only thing that can pay off our £1.9 trillion national debt while keeping our grandchildren prosperous. You are on record as saying: "We have a once-in-a-generation chance to seize the opportunities to make the UK the innovation capital of the world, defying the doubters and being clear that we will go on leading the world in science and technology."

I don't know what it is like down your end of the parliamentary corridor, but at ours we spend very little time talking about how to encourage and reward innovation, despite its clear importance. We are too busy instead with regulation and spending. Although it hardly features in debates or coverage of British politics, there is an entrepreneurial revolution going on in Britain, with about 600,000 business start-ups a year, more than in any other European country - driven by some excellent pro-enterprise policies started under David Cameron.

So there is a chance that the European Union will get the point, and remember Britain tends to overapply regulations anyway.

The newer technology of gene editing, which is being pioneered in British laboratories, has been given a green light by US regulators, while the EU has - get this - asked member states to avoid making a decision at all. What signal does that send? Few companies in the world have this capability.

Thus, in the name of the precautionary principle, the EU has been insisting on danger. Last December, BusinessEurope produced a long catalogue of cases in which EU regulation had affected innovation. The list includes two cases where regulation stimulated innovation (waste policies and sustainable mobility), but far more where it hampered change by introducing legal uncertainty, inconsistency with other regulations, technology-prescriptive rules, burdensome packaging requirements, high compliance costs or excessive precaution. For example, the EU medical devices directive has greatly increased the cost and reduced the supply of new medical devices. Don't take comfort from our many digital start-ups. As a chemical industry executive put it to me last week, the digital industry does not realise what's about to hit it. The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) comes into force next year, along with new ePrivacy regulation. The British Information Commissioner's Office has issued draft guidance that gold-plates the GDPR, with an unduly strict and burdensome interpretation that tilts the balance against the data industry in a manner not required by the regulation. Its proposed rules on opt-outs and consents would make direct marketing as presently practised here impossible. Data analysis is a growing industry in which we have the potential to be a world leader.

An abstract principle, however pious, is not going to change anything. The only way to get momentum for reform is to create a vested interest, preferably with a budget. Precaution has a wealthy constituency in the vast green lobby, whereas innovation's benefits are dispersed among consumers. So here's a suggestion. Why not pledge to set up an innovation commission, guided by the innovation principle, whose job is to examine policies and report on their likely impact on innovation? New Zealand has tried something similar, a productivity commission, which "considers whether laws, policies, regulations and institutions best support the wellbeing of New Zealanders".

Without this, we will be in the economic slow lane, which will hamper our ability to generate funds for social welfare, defence, foreign aid, education and everything else.

Yours optimistically, Matt.
